Sec. 6-63. - Complete execution required. An application for an alcoholic beverage license shall be completely and fully executed, and each question on the form provided shall be answered accurately. Failure of an applicant to furnish accurately all data, information and records required by the application form as well as failure to accompany the application with the payment of the prescribed fee as referenced in appendix C shall be deemed just cause for denying the application with prejudice. Sec. 6-64. - Standards for review of application; decision. (a) After the application has been completed and submitted to the city commission for a decision, in making a determination, the commission shall be guided by the following factors: (1) The report of the chief of police concerning the investigation into the application. (2) The criminal record of the applicant and outlet manager, if applicable, and the general good character, reputation and financial responsibility of the applicant, provided that nonpayment of federal, state, county or city taxes shall be prima facie evidence of lack of financial responsibility. (3) Whether all of the information or statements contained in the application are complete. (4) Evidence presented to the commission for or against the application, at the time and place set for an initial decision on the application by the commission. (5) Whether any license for the sale of alcoholic beverages previously issued for such location has been revoked for cause by the city commission. (6) Whether the applicant holds or possesses any other license for the sale of malt beverages and/or wine issued by the city. (7) The history or reputation of the building or establishment proposed for the outlet for prostitution or other sex offenses; fighting, shooting, stabbing or other violence; gambling, illegal dealing in alcoholic beverages or drugs; or other similar violations of the laws of this state or the United States of America. (8) Whether the applicant meets all of the retail license qualifications set forth in section 6-61. (9) Whether the license is for a location which comes within the provisions of prohibited locations, as such term is defined in section 6-131. (10) Whether the proposed location has adequate off-the-street parking facilities or other parking available for its patrons, and whether the location would tend to increase and promote traffic congestion and resulting hazards therefrom. (11) The nature of the neighborhood immediately adjacent to the proposed location; that is, whether the same is predominately residential, industrial or business. (b) A decision on a license application shall be made at the next regular or special meeting of the city commission under the provisions of this article. Licenses, if granted, shall be issued by the city clerk upon payment of the license fee. All decisions of the commission shall be in accordance with section 6-66. (Code 1969, § 3-22; Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03) Sec. 6-65. - Duty to report changes. Whenever there shall be a change in any of the facts reported to the city commission in the application for a license after such license has been granted, it shall be the duty of the licensee, within ten business days after such change, to report the same to the city clerk in writing. Sec. 6-66. - Compliance with other laws. (a) In addition to the provisions of this article, licensees are also charged with the responsibility for adhering to any other provisions of this Code, as well as the statutes and laws of the state and of the United States relating to the operation of their businesses. (b) All applicants for licenses, in the case of pending applications, and all licensees, in the case of issued licenses, shall forthwith report to the city clerk and chief of police any allegations of a violation of any state law or regulation or local ordinance or regulation when such allegations are made by the state department of revenue, a law enforcement officer, tax commissioner, or a prosecuting attorney in this state charging the applicant or the licensee, as the case may be, with the violation of any law or regulation which could or would, in the event of a finding of guilt, result in a suspension or revocation of such license or a denial or an application for such license. Similarly, an applicant or a licensee shall report to the city clerk and chief of police all findings of such violations by any administrative agency, the tax commissioner, or court which under this article could or would result in a revocation or suspension of a license. Failure to make reports required by this section shall itself be grounds for suspension or revocation of or the denial of an application for a license as the city commission shall determine. Sec. 6-67. - Applicant subject to the terms of article. By filing an application for an alcoholic beverage license an applicant submits to all of the terms of this article, and agrees that he will furnish such evidence, oral or written, as the city commission shall find to be reasonably necessary to the determination of the application. The applicant further agrees by the filing of such application that if a license is issued thereon, he will comply with the terms of this article. Sec. 6-68. - Decisions to be in writing; notice thereof. All decisions approving, denying, suspending or revoking any malt beverage license under the provisions of this article shall be in writing, setting forth the reasons therefor. The written decision shall be served upon the applicant or licensee as provided in section 6-69. (Code 1969, § 3-38) Sec. 6-69. - Renewal; revocation; lapse. (a) All licenses shall be issued on a calendar year basis and shall be renewable as a matter of course upon payment of the appropriate fee; provided that the applicant has not violated any of the terms and provisions of this article. (b) Each applicant shall make written application for renewal on or before November 15 of each year on forms provided for by the clerk of the city, and the license fee shall be made in full, not later than December 31 of each year. (c) The issuance of a license under this article for any calendar year or any portion thereof shall not be deemed to vest the licensee or any person having an interest in the business with any right to renewal thereof. (d) If the applicant for a license has not commenced operation of business upon the premises upon which a license has been granted within 120 days from the date of the granting of the license, this license shall lapse, become void and be of no force or effect. (e) Such renewal applications shall be referred to the chief of police, and if after appropriate investigation no violations have been discovered, the application shall automatically be granted for a renewal license for the next calendar year. (f) The city commission shall have full power and authority to suspend, revoke, refuse to renew, or partially, for a certain number of days, place on probation any licensee to sell malt beverages, wine and/or distilled spirits for violation of this chapter, other provisions of this Code or city ordinances, state or federal law or regulation, or when the continued operation of the licensed business is detrimental to the health, safety, or welfare of the public. (Code 1969, § 3-37; Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03; Ord. No. 4-2009, § 2, 3-25-09) Sec. 6-70. - Review of revocation, suspension or failure to renew. If the city commission revokes, suspends or fails to renew any license which has been issued by the commission under this article, the city commission may, notwithstanding the other provisions herein, review such revocation, suspension or failure to renew and may reinstate such license, subject to all of the following conditions: (1) Such review cannot be held until at least one year after the date of the revocation, suspension or failure to renew. (2) The original licensee against whom the revocation, suspension or failure to renew action was taken must make application in writing for reinstatement of his license after the lapse of the one-year period. (3) The original licensee must have remained in the same business, except for the selling of alcoholic beverages, at the same location continuously since such revocation, suspension or failure to renew. (4) The original licensee must, at the time of the review, be qualified in all respects for the same type license originally issued to him, except for those provisions in section 6-61 concerning violations relating to the sale of alcoholic beverages, if the revocations, suspension or failure to renew was a result of such violation. (5) The application for reinstatement shall be made in accordance with and subject to all of the same provisions, conditions and qualifications as required by article II of this chapter for the approval of an initial license. (Code 1969, § 3-39.1) Sec. 6-71. - Grounds for suspension or revocation. (a) The following shall be considered just cause for the suspension or revocation of a license issued under this article: (1) The performance of any act prohibited by this chapter or the failure to perform any act required by this chapter as well as the violation of any law, state or federal, relating to the business of the licensee. If such act, omission or violation is done by an agent, servant, employee, or officer of the licensee, the lack of knowledge on the part of the licensee or the lack of authorization for such act or omission or violation shall be no defense. (2) The entry of a plea of guilty or nolo contendere, or the conviction of any licensee, partner, or any officer, director or stockholder of a licensee corporation with respect to a charge of violation of any of the laws of the United States or of the state relating to alcohol control, or any crime, whether a felony or not, involving moral turpitude. (3) Any other act or omission with respect to the operation of a business licensed hereunder which the city commission shall find to be contrary to the public interest, or which shall render the licensee or the business location unfit for the continued operation of the business. (b) In addition to the matters enumerated in subsection (a) of this section, the following shall be considered just cause for suspension or revocation of a license for retail sales of malt beverages and/or wine for consumption on the premises: The occurrence on two or more occasions within any 12-month period of fights, disorderly conduct, drunkenness, breach of the peace, and other similar conduct whether the same be committed by the licensee or by customers or others. (Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03) Sec. 6-72. - Notice; conduct of hearing; finality of decision. (a) Prior to taking any potentially adverse action with regard to a license issued under this chapter or Code, the city commission shall afford the licensee notice of a hearing and an opportunity to be heard. The licensee shall be given at least five days' personal written notice of the hearing which may be held at a duly called regular or special meeting of the commission. (b) At the time and place appointed for a hearing, the licensee may be represented by counsel. The license holder shall have the opportunity to present testimony, documentary evidence, or any other relevant evidence it may have, and cross-examine opposing witnesses. (c) after the hearing, and after considering all evidence properly presented to it, the city commission shall take action with regard to the city alcoholic beverage license as may be warranted by the evidence, in its sole judgment and discretion. The commission shall notify the licensee of its decision in writing within ten days of said hearing. (d) Any license holder aggrieved by the city commission's decision shall have the right to appeal that decision to the Superior Court of Polk County, Georgia, within 30 days of the commission's decision. Any such appeal shall be governed by the laws of this state regarding certiorari from the municipal court to the superior court. (e) Any adverse action taken by the city with regard to a license issue pursuant to this article shall not preclude, and may be in addition to, any criminal prosecution by any proper authority of the city, county, state or federal government. (Code 1969, § 3-39; Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03; Ord. No. 4-2009, § 4, 3-25-09) Sec. 6-73. - Investigations. The city commission shall have the right to make such inquiry or investigation as it may find to be reasonably necessary to determine compliance with this chapter. Such investigation may consist, among other actions, of calling licensees for examination under oath, obtaining evidence under oath from other persons, the procurement of documents and records including records of the licensee, and inspection and examination of records and documents from whatever source obtainable. Sec. 6-74. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 4-2009, § 4, deleted § 6-74, which pertained to request for rehearing. Sec. 6-75. - No new license to be issued after revocation. When a license has been revoked under the provisions of this article, no application for a new alcoholic beverage license for the same location will be received for a period of 12 months and no application for a new license from the licensee involved shall be received for a period of 24 months. Sec. 6-76. - Transfers and assignments. Alcoholic beverage licenses issued under this article shall not be transferable or assignable to new owners. If there is a change in the ownership of a business, the new owner shall file an application for a new license as provided by this article. Changes of business interests from one party at interest named in the original application to another party at interest named in the original application and changes from one employee or manager of a social club to his successor shall not be deemed a transfer of a license. In each instance, however, the licensee shall notify the city clerk in writing of such change and make a complete disclosure of all of the facts in connection therewith, such notification to be made in writing within three days from the date of such change. Sec. 6-77. - Regulations. No holder of a license authorizing the sale of malt beverages and/or wine at retail or by the drink in the corporate limits of the City of Cedartown, nor any agent or employee of the licensee, shall engage in any of the following activities in or on the licensed premises: (1) Sell malt beverages and/or wine to a minor. (2) Sell malt beverages and/or wine to any person who is intoxicated or already under the influence of any alcoholic beverages. (3) Sell or permit to be consumed malt beverages and/or wine on the licensed premises on any day or at any time when such sale or consumption is prohibited by law. (4) Permit any disorderly conduct or breach of the peace in or on the licensed premises. (5) Possess, sell or offer for sale any liquor, spirits, or other alcoholic beverages, if the sale or possession of such beverages is not authorized under the license granted to the holder. (Ord. No. 14-1999, § 3, 10-11-99; Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03) Sec. 6-78. - Posting signs. Each outlet for the sell [sale] of malt beverages and/or wine, whether at retail or by the drink, shall post in a conspicuous place within the outlet a sign with letters at least two inches high, which shall read as follows: SALES OF BEER AND WINE TO MINORS STRICTLY PROHIBITED. (Ord. No. 14-1999, § 4, 10-11-99; Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03) Sec. 6-79. - Drug-related objects and drug paraphernalia prohibited. (a) No holder of any license issued under this chapter shall sell, offer for sale, display, lend, rent, lease, give, exchange, keep in stock, possess with intent to sell, or otherwise distribute to any person, at any place of business licensed hereunder any of the following products: (1) Any "drug-related object" as defined by O.C.G.A. § 16-13-32(a)(1), or any instrument, device, or object which is designed or marketed as useful primarily for one or more of the following purposes: a. To inject, ingest, inhale, or otherwise introduce marijuana or a controlled substance into the human body; b. To enhance the effect of marijuana or a controlled substance on the human body; c. To test the strength, effectiveness, or purity of marijuana or a controlled substance; d. To process or prepare marijuana or a controlled substance for introduction into the human body; e. To conceal any quantity of marijuana or a controlled substance; or f. To contain or hold marijuana or a controlled substance while it is being introduced into the human body. (2) Any "drug paraphernalia" which shall include, but not be limited to, objects used or intended for use in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing marijuana or any controlled substance into the human body, such as: a. Metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic, or ceramic pipes with or without screens, permanent screens, hashish heads, or punctured metal bowls; b. Water pipes; c. Carburetion tubes and devices; d. Smoking and carburetion masks; e. Roach clips, which shall mean any object used to hold burning material, such as, but not limited to, a marijuana cigarette, that has become too small or too short to be held in the hand; f. Miniature cocaine spoons and cocaine vials; g. Chamber pipes; h. Carburetor pipes; i. Electric pipes; j. Air-driven pipes; k. Chillums; l. Bongs; and m. Ice pipes or chillers. (b) In determining whether an item constitutes a drug-related object or drug paraphernalia, in addition to all other logically relevant factors, the city commission may also consider the following factors: (1) Statements by an owner or anyone in control of the object or materials; (2) Instructions provided with the object or materials; (3) Descriptive materials accompanying the object or materials; (4) National and local advertising or promotional materials concerning the object or materials; (5) The appearance of, and any writing or other representations appearing on, the object or materials; (6) The manner in which the object or materials are displayed for sale or other distribution; (7) Expert testimony concerning the object or materials; (8) Any written or pictorial materials which are present in the location where the object or materials may be found; and (9) The existence and scope of legitimate uses of the object or materials in the community. (c) Any holder of a license who violates the provisions of this section shall be subject to the license suspension and/or revocation procedures outlined in this chapter. (Ord. No. 11,2010, § 1, 7-12-10) Editor's note— Ord. No. 11,2010, § 1, adopted July 12, 2010, added § 6-80 to the Code. To maintain the numerical sequence of the Code, the new provisions have been added as § 6-79 at the editor's discretion. Secs. 6-80—6-100. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - RETAIL SALES OF WINE AND MALT BEVERAGES[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, adopted March 10, 2003, amended art. III by deleting the division designations.
Sec. 6-101. - Where permitted. The point of sale for packaged malt beverages and/or wine not to be consumed on the premises shall be compactly placed in a rear area of the place of business. In no event shall displays of malt beverages and/or wine be permitted upon the front or in the windows of places of business. (Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03) Sec. 6-102. - Sales in connection with food service. (a) Notwithstanding any provisions governing the sale of alcoholic beverages as otherwise contained in this Code, for the limited purpose of allowing a license for the retail sale of wine and malt beverages by the drink for on premises consumption, such license shall only be issued to qualified applicants in connection with a restaurant or similar eating establishments for the sale of malt beverages and/or wine in connection with sales of food therein. Such restaurant may be located in the area defined in section 2-96 of article III, chapter 2, division 3 of this Code (the boundary definitions of the C-1 downtown development business area of the city as presently enacted or as hereafter amended) as contemplated by section 6-105 hereof. (b) In connection with any license to be granted under subparagraph (a), a restaurant or other eating establishment is defined for purposes of this section as a public place, including a place available for rental by the public, engaged in the sale of prepared food for consumption by the public on the premises with a full-service kitchen. A full-service kitchen must at a minimum consist of a three-compartment pot sink, a stove or grill permanently installed, a refrigerator, and similar equipment all of which must be approved by the state health department and Cedartown Code Enforcement Officer. An eating establishment must be prepared to serve food every hour it is open and must derive at least 40 percent of its gross receipts annually from the sale of prepared meals or food as it derives from the sale of wine and malt beverages. (c) No licenses shall be issued for any establishment that does not meet the requirements of this Code section, section 6-105, and section 6-168 with regard to food service. (Ord. No. 1-2003, §§ 2, 5, 3-10-03; Ord. No. 15,2004, § 1, 10-11-04; Ord. No. 8,2010, § 2, 6-14-10) Sec. 6-103. - Sales on election days. Pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20, the sale of malt beverages and/or wine shall be permitted on election days as the same are defined in the Official Code of Georgia Annotated; provided, however, that it shall nonetheless be unlawful for any person to sell malt beverages and wine within 250 feet of any polling place or of the outer edge of any building within which such polling place is established on primary or election days. (Code 1969, § 3-32; Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03) State Law reference— Sales of alcoholic beverages on Sundays, election days and Christmas Day, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-20. Sec. 6-104. - Hours for consumption. It shall be unlawful for any licensee under this chapter to encourage or permit the consumption of any alcoholic beverages on the premises for which the permit was issued at any time other than the permitted hours of operation as set forth in sections 6-132 and 6-319 of this Code. (Ord. No. 20-2001, § 1, 9-17-01; Ord. No. 10, 2003, § 4, 9-15-03; Ord. No. 2-2004, § 2, 2-9-04) Sec. 6-105. - Sales within the downtown central business district. (a) A special location permit and license for a restaurant or eating establishment as defined in section 6-102, shall be required for each place of business when an applicant applies for the right to sell wine and malt beverages in a portion of the C-1 downtown business district. All such applicants shall file their application on forms generally required by this Code, and otherwise meet all other requirements of holding all licenses granted by the city. (b) With regard to any license within the downtown business district, which might be granted by the city commission under this section, the following rules and regulations shall apply to such license holder in addition to all other regulations and requirements of the city, or any state, or federal governing authority regarding such license holders: (1) No screen, partition, tinted windows, or other device which prevents a clear view into the interior of the retail outlet from the street, nor any booth within, shall be permitted. No advertising of prices or signs outside the restaurant, nor any "beer and/or wine for sale" or other similar alcoholic beverage descriptive sign shall be allowed to be placed either in front of the building of the eating establishment, or on any windows open for view of the public. (2) Upon the transfer of the premises, closing of the establishment, or death of the license holder, no transfer of the license from the approved license holder shall be permitted without prior approval of the city. (3) The license holder shall maintain, in proper order at all times, all books and records with regard to the sale of food within the eating establishment in proportion to the sale of wine and/or malt beverages, to be certain that the establishment derives no more than 60 percent of its gross revenues from the sale of wine and malt beverages. These records may be reviewed by the city manager, or his designee, at all times during normal business hours of the license holder. Furthermore, not less than annually at the time of renewal, the license holder shall certify, through a certified public accountant or other person capable of providing the certificate, that a thorough review of the books and records of the license holder has been conducted, and that the licensee is in compliance with the restriction of 60 percent sales as set forth in the requirements of this Code. (4) The commission shall have the right to promulgate any and all other reasonable regulations that might govern any individual eating establishments, their configuration, or requirements for continuation of a license, as might be required within the downtown business district, this section, or otherwise to comply with the intention of the commission in relation thereto. (c) Any license granted hereunder shall have affixed thereto a special location permit, which shows that the license is granted and complies with the zoning restrictions on the location of malt beverages and wine restaurant consumption licenses for the specific defined and specially zoned location, as set forth in section 94-116.1 of this Code. (Ord. No. 1-2003, § 6, 3-10-03; Ord. No. 8,2010, § 3, 6-14-10) Sec. 6-106. - Retail on-premises consumption; regulations related to consumption licensee. (a) A license, to be granted hereunder, for retail on-premises consumption of malt beverages may be granted in areas of the city properly zoned for an on-premises consumption establishment, and not otherwise prohibited by the prohibited location restriction of section 6-131 of this Code. No retail consumption licensee shall keep any beer or wine, or other alcoholic beverages, in any place except the licensed place of business. No retail consumption licensee shall be permitted to enter into any type of arrangements whereby distilled spirits ordered by the licensee or stored by a licensed wholesaler, or otherwise, are kept on the premises at any time. (b) It is prohibited for customers to leave the premises with open containers of alcoholic beverages. It is the licensee's responsibility to insure that no such open containers are carried out of the premises. Further, customers shall not gather outside of an establishment which allows consumption on the premises and consume alcoholic beverages. It is prohibited for the manager, or any employee, to allow such persons to gather outside and consume alcoholic beverages. (c) No retail consumption licensee shall permit, encourage or induce any employee or agent to solicit the purchase by a patron of any drink, whether alcoholic or nonalcoholic; or try to solicit money to insure that patrons must participate in the consumption of such beverages through promotions, discounts, or contests. Further, no licensee shall pay a commission or other compensation based solely on the frequency in which a patron purchases beverages while on the premises. (d) No retail consumption licensee shall permit excessive noise that can create a breach of the peace, a disturbance, or otherwise may be distinctly heard beyond the physical boundaries of the property upon which the license is granted. (e) No patron of any establishment which allows on-the-premises consumption under a proper license from the city shall be permitted to bring any form of wine, beer, liquor or other alcoholic beverage, onto the premises in any cooler, container, or other carrying device. Thus, the practice of "brown bagging" or "bring your own bottle" (BYOB) shall, under no circumstances, be allowed within the corporate limits of the city. (f) The chief of police, or his designee, may immediately close an establishment licensed under this chapter in case of emergency, for safety of the public, or to investigate a crime. The period of closure shall not exceed 72 hours without the right for an emergency hearing before the municipal court concerning the circumstances surrounding the emergency closure, and reasons for its continuation, or termination of closure. (Ord. No. 1-2003, § 6, 3-10-03) Secs. 6-107—6-130. - Reserved. Sec. 6-131. - Prohibited locations. (a) It shall be unlawful to grant a license for the sale of malt beverages and/or wine within the following areas in the city: (1) Any residential zoning district. (2) A measured distance of 300 feet of any girl's club, boy's club, YMCA, community center, Salvation Army Center, public park or other public playground or recreational facility owned or operated by the city. (3) A measured 300 feet of any alcoholic treatment center owned or operated by the state or any local governing authority. (4) A measured distance of 300 feet of any church, school ground, or college campus; provided that, however, in the C-1 central business district, a measured distance of 50 feet shall apply to applicants for consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises only. Such applicants shall also be subject to the requirements of subsection (5). (5) No malt beverage and/or wine sales shall be permitted within the defined area of the C-1 central business district except as described in the Downtown Development Authority Act (section 2-96 of the Code). Restaurants in that area only (not the remainder of C-1) may sell beer and wine as a part of an eating establishment pursuant to section 6-102 of the Code. (b) "Measured" for purposes of this section, shall mean measured by way of the nearest traveled road, street, highway or publicly-owned sidewalk from the front entrance of an outlet authorized to sell beer to the property line of an involved school ground, residential section, church or other prohibited property location. If the measurement crosses a road, street or highway, the measurement shall be at an intersection or authorized crosswalk. "Measured" as it relates to the distance from the front entrance of such outlet shall be the measurement from the front door of such outlet in a straight line to the nearest road, street, highway or publicly-owned sidewalk. (Code 1969, § 3-23; Ord. No. 1-2003, §§ 3, 4, 3-10-03; Ord. No. 9,2006, § 1, 9-11-06) Sec. 6-132. - Hours of sale. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, give away, offer for sale, or in any manner disperse or deliver, any malt beverages and/or wine by the package within the corporate limits of the city between the hours of 12:00 a.m. (midnight) until 12:30 p.m. on each and every Sunday; and from 11:30 p.m. on each and every Sunday until 8:00 a.m. on each and every Monday; and from 12:00 a.m. midnight Christmas Eve until 8:00 a.m. on the day following Christmas of each year; and from 12:00 a.m. midnight Easter Sunday until 8:00 a.m. on the day following Easter of each year. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, give away, offer for sale, or in any manner disperse or deliver any malt beverages and/or wine by the drink within the corporate limits of the city between the hours of 1:30 a.m. until 8:00 a.m. each and every Monday through Saturday; and from 1:30 a.m. until 12:30 p.m. on each and every Sunday; and from 11:30 p.m. on each and every Sunday, until 8:00 a.m. on each and every Monday; and from 12:00 a.m. midnight on Christmas Eve until 8:00 a.m. on the day following Christmas each year; and from 12:00 a.m. midnight Easter Sunday until 8:00 a.m. on the day following Easter of each year. (Ord. No. 2-2012, § 1, 3-12-12; Ord. No. 4-2012, § 1, 4-9-12) Editor's note— Ord. No. 2-2012, § 1, adopted Mar. 12, 2012, repealed former § 6-132 and enacted a new section as set out herein. No. 7,2006, § 1, 5-8-06. Secs. 6-133—6-160. - Reserved. Sec. 6-161. - Definitions. (a) Unless the context demands otherwise, the words and terms used in this article shall have the same definitions and meanings as stated in the applicable provisions of title 3 of the Official Code of Georgia Annotated and section 6-1. (b) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Business location or outlet means the location or proposed location of a retail malt beverage or wine outlet. (Code 1969, § 3-40; Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 6-162. - Necessity for license. It shall be unlawful to sell, store or offer to sell malt beverages and/or wine at wholesale or retail within the corporate limits of the city without having the appropriate license for such sale, or to carry on such activity in violation of the terms of such license or this chapter. (Code 1969, § 3-41; Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03) Sec. 6-163. - Separate license for each outlet; transfer of license; surrender of license upon sale or closure. (a) A separate license shall be required for each malt beverages and/or wine outlet, and separate application shall be made for each outlet. (b) Licenses under this section shall be nontransferable. (c) Immediately upon the sale or closing of an outlet, it shall be the duty of the licensee to surrender his license to the commission. (Code 1969, § 3-42; Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03) Sec. 6-164. - Classification of licenses; license fees. (a) Licenses under this article shall be classified as follows: (1) Retail malt beverages and/or wine package. The retail malt beverages and/or wine package license shall permit only the sale of malt beverages and/or wine in packages at retail. (2) Retail sales of wine for consumption on the premises. The license for retail sales of malt beverages and/or wine for consumption on the premises shall permit the sale of wine by the bottle or by the glass for consumption on the premises. (3) Wholesale. The wholesale malt beverages and/or wine distributor license shall permit only the sale of wine at wholesale. (4) Brewery. The brewery license shall permit the manufacture or brewing of malt beverages. (5) Brewpub. The license for a brewpub allows for an eating establishment to sell beer or malt beverages that are manufactured or brewed at the establishment. (6) Winery. The license for a winery allows for the manufacture of wine. (b) The following license fees shall be paid to the city clerk of the city prior to the issuance or renewal of any malt beverages and/or wine license: (1) Retail malt beverages and/or wine package. The license fee for operation of a malt beverages and/or wine retail package license for one calendar year or any part thereof shall be as set out in appendix C to this Code. No license fee shall be refunded. (2) Retail sales of malt beverages and/or wine for consumption on the premises. The license fee for retail sales of malt beverages and/or wine for consumption on the premises for one calendar year or any part thereof shall be as set out in appendix C to this Code. No license fee shall be refunded. (3) Malt beverages and/or wine wholesale distributor. The license fee for operation of a wholesale distributor for one calendar year or any part thereof shall be as set out in appendix C to this Code. No license fee shall be refunded. (4) Brewery. The license fee for operation of a brewery for one calendar year or any part thereof shall be set out in appendix C to this Code. No license fee shall be refunded. (5) Brewpub. The license fee for operation of a brewpub for one calendar year or any part thereof shall be set out in appendix C to this Code. No license fee shall be refunded. (6) Winery. The license fee for operation of a winery for one calendar year or any part thereof shall be set out in appendix C to this Code. No license fee shall be refunded. (Code 1969, § 3-43; Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03; Ord. No. 7-2013, § 2, 9-9-13; Ord. No. 7-2017 , §§ 7—12, 12-11-17) Sec. 6-165. - Wholesale license. Any wholesale dealer in malt beverages and/or wines licensed by the state, or the agent of such wholesale dealer, shall be granted a license to distribute such malt beverages and/or wines in the city upon application for a license to the clerk of the city, the payment of the fee provided for in this article, and the presentation of evidence that he understands the provisions and conditions under which retail licenses are issued. (Code 1969, § 3-45; Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03) Sec. 6-166. - License applications; qualifications and other matters governed by malt beverage and/or wine code provisions. The application, qualifications and procedures governing the issuance of a retail package malt beverages and/or wine license shall be in accordance with the requirements contained in article II of this chapter. Further, all regulations controlling the sale of malt beverages and/or wine or in any other way pertaining to the sale of beer as contained in sections 6-131 and 6-132 shall have full application to the sale of malt beverages and/or wine as if fully set out as a separate section in this division. It is the intention of this section that malt beverages and/or wine shall be sold only at a qualified malt beverage and/or wine outlet under the application procedures, license qualifications and all other rules and regulations set forth in article II of this chapter, and any further restrictions contained in this article. Nothing contained in this article shall prevent a person from applying for a retail malt beverage and/or wine license and a retail malt beverage and/or wine package license, simultaneously. (Code 1969, § 3-44; Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03) Sec. 6-167. - Application forms; fees. The application shall state that it is for a retail consumption dealer's malt beverages and/or wine license, and shall be made on forms furnished by the governing authority. The fee for this consumption license shall be as set out in appendix C to this Code as an annual fee for the operation of each calendar year, or any portion of a calendar year. (Code 1969, § 3-51; Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03) Sec. 6-168. - Licenses to be issued to certain premises only. No retail consumption dealers' malt beverages and/or wine license shall be issued to any person unless the business or proposed business to be licensed pursuant to this division is a bona fide eating establishment. For purposes of this section, a "bona fide eating establishment" shall mean any public place selling prepared food for consumption by the public on the premises and deriving at least 50 percent of its total annual gross sales from the sale of prepared meals or foods, in addition to the requirements set forth in section 6-102. (Code 1969, § 3-52; Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03; Ord. No. 15,2004, § 2, 10-11-04) Sec. 6-169. - Requirements for licensed premises. Each applicant for a retail consumption dealer's license shall attach to the application evidence of ownership of the building or proposed building or a copy of the lease if the applicant is leasing the building. If the applicant is a franchisee, then such applicant shall attach a copy of the franchise agreement or contract with the application. All premises for which a retail consumption dealer's license shall be issued shall afford therein adequate sanitary toilet facilities and shall be adequately illuminated so that all hallways, passageways and open areas may be clearly seen by the customers therein. (Code 1969, § 3-53) Sec. 6-170. - Licenses not transferable. No retail consumption dealer's license issued pursuant to this division shall be transferable or assignable to any other person or location, and if a licensed business is sold or closed, it shall be the duty of the licensee to immediately surrender the license to the governing authority. A separate retail consumption dealer's license shall be required for each place of business. (Code 1969, § 3-55) Sec. 6-171. - Licensing standards; review; application of Code. All terms, provisions and conditions contained in article II of this chapter, and this article regulating malt beverages and/or wine including, but not limited to, sale restrictions, hours of operation, revocation of licenses and any and all other provisions shall likewise apply to the on-premises consumption of malt beverages and/or wine, as though fully set forth in this article. (Code 1969, § 3-56; Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03) Sec. 6-172. - Review of revocation, suspension or failure to renew. If the city commission revokes, suspends or fails to renew any license which has been issued by the commission under this article, the city commission may, notwithstanding the other provisions in this article, review such revocation, suspension or failure to renew and may reinstate such license, subject to all of the following conditions: (1) Such review cannot be held until at least one year after the date of the revocation, suspension or failure to renew. (2) The original licensee against whom the revocation, suspension or failure to renew action was taken must make application in writing for reinstatement of his license after the lapse of the one-year period. (3) The original licensee must have remained in the same business, except for the selling of alcoholic beverages, at the same location continuously since such revocation, suspension or failure to renew. (4) The original licensee must, at the time of the review, be qualified in all respects for the same type of license originally issued to him, except for those provisions in section 6-61 concerning violations relating to the sale of alcoholic beverages, if the revocation, suspension or failure to renew was a result of such violation. (5) The application for reinstatement shall be made in accordance with and subject to all of the same provisions, conditions and qualifications as required by this division for the approval of an initial license. (Code 1969, § 3-49; Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03) Sec. 6-173. - On-premises consumption of malt beverages and/or wine. Any person who has previously been granted a malt beverage and/or wine license pursuant to the provisions of this article, may likewise apply, or in the case of an initial application or renewal, designate that the license shall include the grant of a separate license fee for the on-premises consumption of malt beverages and/or wine within the corporate limits of the city. All terms, conditions and provisions of article II of this chapter, apply to a separate license granted for the on-premises consumption of malt beverages and/or wine under the provisions of this article. (Code 1969, § 3-50; Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03) Sec. 6-174. - Malt beverage and/or wine tastings. Nothing in this article shall preclude a licensee from conducting a malt beverage and/or wine tasting, provided that the licensee complies with all regulations of the state revenue commissioner then in force relative to such malt beverage and/or wine tastings. A copy of any permit issued by the state revenue commissioner authorizing a malt beverage and/or wine tasting in the city shall be filed with the city clerk prior to conducting the malt beverage and/or wine tasting. (Code 1969, § 3-48; Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03) Sec. 6-175. - Additional regulations pertaining to the sale of malt beverages and/or wine. In addition to the regulations set forth in article II of this chapter, which shall apply to all malt beverage and/or wine licenses granted pursuant to this article, the following regulations shall also apply to the sale of malt beverages and/or wine within the city: (1) No screen, partition or other obstruction which prevents a clear view into the interior of a retail outlet from the street, nor any booth within, shall be permitted. (2) Each retail outlet shall post at least four copies of its complete price list for malt beverages and/or wines, or in lieu thereof, place a price on each bottle for sale. (3) The state laws and regulations relating to the sale and distribution of malt beverages and/or wine, as revised or hereafter promulgated by the state revenue department, are hereby incorporated into and made a part of this article as if fully set out in this article. (4) The licensee shall make an immediate report to, and receive approval from, the city commission of any change in the interest in, or ownership of, a malt beverages and/or wine outlet or malt beverages and/or wine business and/or any change in the information as stated in the original application for a license. (Code 1969, § 3-46; Ord. No. 1-2003, § 2, 3-10-03) Sec. 6-176. - Breweries. Brewer's licenses are authorized in the city; provided, however, that no individual shall be permitted to own or operate a brewery without first obtaining a proper brewer's license from the city in the manner provided in this chapter, and each holder of a brewer's license shall comply with the provisions of this chapter and all applicable state statutes, including rules and regulations promulgated by the department of revenue. ( Ord. No. 7-2017 , § 13, 12-11-17) Sec. 6-177. - Brewpubs. A limited exception to the provisions of this chapter which implement and enforce the three-tier system for the manufacture, distribution and sale of malt beverages established under state law shall exist for owners and operators of brewpubs, subject to the following terms and conditions: (1) No individual or person shall be permitted to own or operate a brewpub without first obtaining a proper brewpub license from the city commission. Each brewpub licensee shall comply with all other applicable state and local license requirements. (2) A brewpub license authorizes the holder of such license to: a. Manufacture on the licensed premises not more than 10,000 barrels of malt beverages in a calendar year solely for retail sale; b. Operate an eating establishment that shall be the sole retail outlet for such malt beverages; c. Operate an eating establishment that may offer for sale for consumption on the premises any other alcoholic beverages produced by other manufacturers which are authorized for retail sale under this chapter, including wine, distilled spirits, and malt beverages, provided that such alcoholic beverages are purchased from a licensed wholesaler; and, provided, further, that in addition to draft beer manufactured on the premises, each brewpub licensee shall offer for sale commercially available canned or bottled malt beverages from licensed wholesalers; and d. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this paragraph, sell up to a maximum of 5,000 barrels annually of such malt beverages to licensed wholesale dealers. Under no circumstances shall such malt beverages be sold by a brewpub licensee to any person holding a retail consumption dealer's license or a retailer's license for the purpose of resale; (3) Possession of a brewpub license shall not prevent the holder of such license from obtaining a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the package, excluding distilled spirits, for the same premises; (4) A brewpub license shall include the sale of malt beverages manufactured on the premises by the package for consumption off the premises; (5) Brewpubs which sell distilled spirits or wine must obtain retail consumption licenses for such beverages as a precondition to sales of distilled spirits or wine; (6) A brewpub license shall pay all state and local license fees and excise taxes applicable to individuals or persons licensed as manufacturers, retailers, and, where applicable, wholesalers under this title; and (7) Measure malt beverages manufactured on the premises and otherwise comply with applicable rules and regulations respecting excise and enforcement tax determination of such malt beverages as required by state and local law. ( Ord. No. 7-2017 , § 14, 12-11-17) Sec. 6-178. - Exception for breweries. As a limited exception to the provisions of this chapter which implement and enforce the three-tier system for the manufacture, distribution, and sale of malt beverages established under state law, a brewer's license authorizes the holder of such license to sell directly to the public on its licensed premises up to 3,000 barrels of malt beverages manufactured on such licensed premises per year for: (1) consumption on the premises; and (2) consumption off the premises (sales by the package), provided that such sales by the package shall not exceed a maximum of 288 ounces per consumer per day. Such retail sales are permitted on the days and at the times that the retail sale of malt beverages for consumption on the premises or by the package, as applicable, is authorized for other retailer licensees under this chapter. Under no circumstances shall such malt beverages be sold by a licensed brewer to a licensed retailer or retail consumption dealer for the purpose of resale. Any brewer engaging in the retail sales of malt beverages pursuant to this section shall remit all state and local excise taxes to the proper tax collecting authority. For the purposes of this article, "barrel" means 31 gallons of malt beverages. ( Ord. No. 7-2017 , § 15, 12-11-17) Sec. 6-179. - Sale by farm wineries. A farm winery may sell its wine and the wine of any other state farm winery licensee at retail in a tasting room or other facility on the premises of the winery for consumption on the premises and in closed packages for consumption off the premises and to sell its wine and the wine of any other state farm winery licensee at retail for consumption on the premises and in closed packages for consumption off the premises in tasting rooms at a location within the city that is one of the five additional locations in the state authorized by O.C.G.A. § 2-6-21.1(b), but only if the annual production of wine by the farm winery is made in state in accordance with the source of berries, fruits or grapes as provided by the laws of the state and the rules and regulations of the state department of agriculture. ( Ord. No. 7-2017 , § 16, 12-11-17) Sec. 6-180. - Licenses for farm wineries. The alcoholic beverage licenses which may be issued to farm wineries under this chapter are: (1) Wholesaler of farm winery production. A farm winery shall be granted a wholesale license for sale and distribution as provided by O.C.G.A. § 2-6-21.1. Such license shall be issued upon application and payment of established fees and upon presentation of a receipt for payment of the state annual license tax as provided by the referenced code provisions in this section. (2) Retail package sales of wine. Each retail package sales license shall require that all sales shall be by and through the farm winery tasting room at the site for which said license is issued. (3) Retail sales of wine. Each license for retail sales of wine and malt beverages for consumption on the premises shall require that all consumption shall be at the farm winery site for which said license is issued. This site shall include any wedding or dining facilities associated with the farm winery. (4) Multiple farms winery licenses. A farm winery may apply for and, if approved, may be issued multiple farm winery licenses. At the primary farm winery facility where the wine is produced, such site may be licensed for wholesale, package retail sales and on-premises consumption. For any site other than the primary farm winery facility where the wine is produced, up to the maximum number of such sites as may be permitted by state statute, such site may be licensed for package retail sales and on-premises consumption. The license created in accordance with this article shall be limited to farm winery tasting rooms licensed by the state in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 2-6-21.1 et seq., and the licensee shall be permitted to perform only acts allowed in accordance with such statues. No license is hereby created authorized any other use. (5) Alternate provision. The first license at any site shall have a cost equal to the cost of a city alcoholic beverage license at the time of the application. Any license for two or more categories of sale shall require payment of the additional license fees as provided in the city fee schedule. (6) Ratio of sales. There shall be no specified or required ratio of alcohol sales to any other income for winery operations. Farm wineries shall operate on such days and hours as are provided by the Georgia Farm Winery Act., O.C.G.A. § 2-6-21.1 et seq., as amended from time to time and by the terms of this section for sale by consumption on the premises. (7) Premises consumption. a. A farm winery may apply for a license for on-premises consumption of distilled spirits under the terms as provided under this chapter. b. A farm winery may apply for a license for on-premises consumption of wine and malt beverages (not produced under the Georgia Farm Winery Act O.C.G.A. § 2-6-21.1 et seq.) under the terms as provided under this chapter. ( Ord. No. 7-2017 , § 17, 12-11-17) Secs. 6-181—6-200. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - EXCISE TAXES DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 6-201. - Inspection and audit of books and records. The books and records of all wholesalers selling or delivering any wine and/or malt beverages to retailers made subject to the taxes levied in this article and the books and records of all retailers made subject to the taxes levied in this article shall be open for inspection and audit by the agents of the city, to ensure compliance with this article, and it shall be unlawful for any person to deny any authorized agent of the city reasonable access to such books and records. Such books and records shall, for wholesalers, contain information showing deliveries of any of such beverages to persons upon whom the tax hereby assessed and levied is imposed separately, and the monthly reports of such wholesalers shall show deliveries made to each retailer, separately, so that sales of any of the beverages described in this section may be identified with respect to each retailer upon whom the tax is imposed by this section. Sec. 6-221. - Levy. There is hereby imposed upon and levied against every licensed wholesale dealer in malt beverages an excise tax, in addition to the excise taxes presently levied by the state as set out in appendix C of this Code. Sec. 6-222. - Payment. The excise tax levied in this division and imposed upon licensed wholesalers is levied and imposed with respect to malt beverages sold or distributed by such wholesalers in the city to retailers doing business in the city. The excise tax provided for in this division shall be paid by such licensed wholesale dealers to the city on or before the tenth day of the month following the calendar month in which the beverages are sold or disposed of by such licensed wholesale dealer. Every licensee responsible for the payment of the excise tax imposed by this section shall file a monthly report itemizing for the preceding calendar month the exact quantities of malt beverages, by size and type of container, for the month. Each wholesale licensee shall report and remit to the city, on the tenth of the month next succeeding the calendar month in which such beer and malt beverages are sold or disposed of, the tax imposed by this division. Sec. 6-251. - Levy for wholesale sale. (a) In addition to the annual retail wine license fee required, there is hereby levied an excise tax computed at the rate set out in appendix C to this Code per liter of wine, which shall be paid to the city on all wine sold, displayed or stored in the city. The per liter tax shall be prorated and a proportionate tax is hereby imposed at like rates on all fractional parts of a liter. (b) The tax shall be paid to the city by the wholesale distributor on all wines sold to retailers in the city as follows: Each wholesale distributor selling, shipping or in any way delivering wine to any such retailer shall collect the excise tax at the time of delivery and shall remit the same, together with a summary of all deliveries, to each retailer on or before the tenth day of the month following. (c) Each wholesale distributor shall furnish to the city a summary of all purchase invoices for wine sold to each retailer in the city on or before the tenth of each month following such purchases. Said invoices shall show the amount of excise tax paid. (d) The city shall have the right to audit, and to require production of records from, each wholesaler supplying retailers in the city and each retailer so supplied. (e) It shall be unlawful and a violation of this article for any wholesaler to sell, ship or deliver in any manner, any wine to a retail dealer without collecting such tax. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any retail dealer to possess, own, hold, store, display or sell any wine on which such tax has not been paid. (Code 1969, § 3-47) Sec. 6-252. - Levy for per drink sale. There is hereby levied an excise tax computed at the rate per liter as set out in appendix C to this Code, which shall be paid to the governing authority on all wine sold by the drink within the corporate limits of the city. Such tax shall be paid to the governing authority by the wholesaler on all wine sold to wine retail consumption dealers in the city, as follows: Each wholesaler selling, shipping or in any way delivering wine to any wine retail consumption dealer shall collect the excise tax at the time of delivery to each retail dealer on or before the 15th day of the month following. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this section for any wholesaler to sell, ship or deliver in any manner any wine to a retail consumption dealer without collecting such tax. No. 3-2003, § 2, 8-11-03) Sec. 6-304. - Fingerprints; bond (a) Each applicant and employee thereof shall furnish a complete set of fingerprints which the city shall forward to the Georgia Bureau of Investigation, who shall search the files of the Georgia Crime Information Center for a period of ten years immediately preceding the date of such application for any evidence of criminal activity. (Ord. No. 3-2003, § 2, 8-11-03) Sec. 6-307. - Investigations and processing of applications. No. 3-2003, § 2, 8-11-03) Sec. 6-317. - Prohibited activities. (Ord. No. 3-2003, § 2, 8-11-03) Sec. 6-319. - Hours and days of operation. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, give away, offer for sale, or in any manner disperse or deliver any distilled spirits by the package within the corporate limits of the city between the hours of 12:00 a.m. (midnight) until 12:30 p.m. on each and every Sunday; and from 11:30 p.m. on each and every Sunday until 8:00 a.m. On each and every Monday; and from 12:00 a.m. midnight Christmas until 8:00 a.m. on the day following Christmas of each year; and from 12:00 a.m. midnight Easter Sunday until 8:00 a.m. on the day following Easter of each year. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, give away, offer for sale, or in any manner disburse or deliver any distilled spirits by the drink within the corporate limits of the city between the hours of 1:30 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. each and every Monday through Saturday; and from 1:30 a.m. until 12:30 p.m. on each and every Sunday; and from 11:30 p.m. on each and every Sunday, until 8:00 a.m. on each and every Monday; and from 12:00 a.m. midnight on Christmas Eve until 8:00 a.m. on the day following Christmas each year; and from 12:00 a.m. midnight Easter Sunday until 8:00 a.m. on the day following Easter of each year. (c) All businesses who hold a license for the sale of distilled spirits for consumption on the premises shall close and have all patrons or customers out of the premises within 30 minutes after the hours of sale specified in this section. (Ord. No. 2-2012, § 2, 3-12-12; Ord. No. 4-2012, § 2, 4-9-12) Editor's note— Ord. No. 2-2012, § 2, adopted Mar. 12, 2012, repealed former § 6-319 and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 3-2003, § 2, 8-11-03; Ord. No. 2-2004, § 4, 2-9-04. Sec. 6-320. - Sales in unbroken package only; minimum size. All retail dealers shall sell distilled spirits in the original unbroken package only, and shall sell no package containing less than 50 milliliters. (Ord. No. 3-2003, § 2, 8-11-03) Sec. 6-321. - Inventory and stock. (a) No holder of a license issued pursuant to this article shall buy or arrange to buy or in any way effect the transfer of any distilled spirits to its business location, except from a licensed wholesaler. (b) A holder of a package sales license issued pursuant to this article shall keep no inventory or stock of distilled spirits at any place except the licensed place of business and, within the licensed place of business, the storage area for distilled spirits shall be immediately adjacent to the retail area. Furthermore, no licensee hereunder shall enter into any type of arrangements whereby any type of contract, agreement, or other arrangement whereby distilled spirits ordered by said licensee are stored by a licensed wholesaler. (c) A holder of a license for consumption of distilled spirits by the drink shall purchase distilled spirits only from licensed wholesalers and in sizes of 750 milliliters or larger, unless a particular brand is not packaged in this size, in which case the licensee shall purchase the next largest size available in such brand. (Ord. No. 3-2003, § 2, 8-11-03) Sec. 6-322. - Food sales by consumption on the premises licensee. (a) In the C-1 downtown business district as described in this Code, all holders of a license for consumption of distilled spirits by the drink shall maintain at least 40 percent of their annual gross income from the sale of foods. In all other zones, holders of a license for consumption of distilled spirits by the drink shall maintain at least 50 percent of their annual gross income from the sale of foods. If said records indicate that the licensee is not meeting the requirements of this section, then their license may be subject to suspension or revocation under section 6-312 hereof. (b) Within 120 days after having been issued a license for consumption of distilled spirits by the drink on the premises, the licensee shall submit to the city a statement from a certified public accountant or registered public accountant that the income requirements set forth in this section have been met for the first 90 days after the applicant received his license. Thereafter, on a quarterly basis and at each and every time of the license renewal, or upon request of the city, each license holder shall submit to the city a statement from a certified or registered public accountant verifying that the income requirements as set forth in this section have been met. (Ord. No. 3-2003, § 2, 8-11-03; Ord. No. 8,2010, § 4, 6-14-10) Sec. 6-323. - Excise taxes. (a) In addition to the annual license fees imposed and required by this article, there is hereby levied and imposed an excise tax on all package sales of distilled spirits in the amount of $0.22 per liter. (b) The tax levied by this article shall be paid to the city by each wholesale dealer on all liquor sold to retail dealers and consumption on the premises licensees in the city. Each wholesale distributor selling, shipping, or in any way delivering liquor to any such retailer shall collect the excise tax at the time of delivery and remit the same to the city, together with a summary of all deliveries to each retailer, on or before the tenth day of the following month. (c) The summary report made by each wholesale distributor to the city shall show the exact quantities of distilled spirits delivered, and the exact amounts of excise tax paid. (Ord. No. 3-2003, § 2, 8-11-03) Sec. 6-324. - Audit; failure to make reports; penalties. (a) The city shall have the right to audit and require production of records from each wholesaler supplying retailers in the city as well as each retailer so supplied. (b) The failure to make a timely report and remittance under this article shall render a wholesale dealer liable for a penalty equal to ten percent of the total amount during the first 30-day period following a date such report and remittance were due, and an additional penalty of five percent of the amount of such remittance for each successive 30-day period or any portion thereof, during which such report remittance are not filed. The filing of a false, fraudulent, inaccurate, or misleading report shall render the wholesale dealer making such report liable for a penalty equal to 25 percent of the amount of the remittance which would be required under an accurate and truthful report. (c) Any retail or wholesale dealer's failure to make a timely report or remittance or filing of a false, fraudulent, misleading, or inaccurate report shall also constitute grounds for the suspension or revocation of any licenses issued to said dealer by the city. (Ord. No. 3-2003, § 2, 8-11-03) Sec. 6-325. - Sales prohibited when tax not paid. It shall be unlawful for any holder of a distilled spirits license to sell at retail or otherwise within the city any beverages taxed by this article on which the required tax has not been paid to the wholesaler, distributor, or the city. (Ord. No. 3-2003, § 2, 8-11-03) Sec. 6-326. - Display of license. Holders of licenses issued pursuant to this article shall display them prominently and in plain view at all times on the premises for which said licenses were issued. (Ord. No. 3-2003, § 2, 8-11-03) Sec. 6-327. - Licensee's responsibility regarding this article. Each holder of a license issued pursuant to this article shall keep a copy of this article in the licensed premises, be familiar with the terms hereof, and instruct any agent, employee, or other representative working there with regard to same. The licensee shall be responsible for any acts of such agents, employees, or representatives in violation of this article, the laws of the state, or the rules and regulations of the state revenue commissioner. (Ord. No. 3-2003, § 2, 8-11-03) Sec. 6-328. - Employees. It shall be the duty of all holders of licenses issued pursuant to this article to file with the clerk a list of the home addresses, telephone numbers, and places of employment of any employees, resident managers, or other agents who will be working in or on the licensed premises. Changes in the list of employees, with names of new employees, shall be submitted to the clerk within three business days of said changes. Any new employees or other agents of the licensee shall be subject to the investigative requirements of sections 6-303 and 6-304 regarding background checks and fingerprinting. (Ord. No. 3-2003, § 2, 8-11-03) Sec. 6-329. - Brown bag establishments prohibited. "Brown bag establishments" as defined in this chapter shall be prohibited within the city. (Ord. No. 3-2003, § 2, 8-11-03) Sec. 6-330. - Excise tax on sales by the drink containing distilled spirits. (a) There is hereby levied and imposed upon every purchaser of a distilled spirits purchased by the drink within this City of Cedartown, Georgia a tax in the amount of three percent. A record of each sale shall be made in writing and maintained for inspection by any authorized agent of the city. (b) Every consumption on the premises licensee shall collect the tax imposed by this section from purchasers of drinks containing distilled spirts. The licensee shall furnish such information as may be required by the city manager to facilitate the collection of the tax. (c) If requested by the purchaser, a consumption on the premises licensee shall give to the purchaser a receipt on which the purchase price and the tax imposed by this section shall be itemized separately. In all cases where the purchase is by deferred payment or credit, the licensee becomes liable for the collection and payment of the tax at the time of delivery of the drink to the purchaser. (d) All amounts of taxes levied under this section shall be due and payable monthly on or before the 20th day of every month next succeeding each monthly period. (e) On or before the 20th day of the month following each monthly period a return for the preceding monthly period shall be filed with the city clerk showing the gross sales of liquor by the drink by the licensee during the applicable period and the amount of tax collected or otherwise due under this division for the related period, and such other information as may be required by the city clerk. (f) A specific penalty of 15 percent is imposed for failure to pay any amount of tax when due and payable to the city. Delinquent amounts shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month, or fraction thereof, until paid. (g) Licensees shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting, and paying the amount due, if said amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of deduction shall be the same rate authorized for deductions from state sales and use tax ( Ord. No. 11-2018 , § 1, 12-10-18) Secs. 6-331—6-349. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - LICENSED CATERERS AND SPECIAL EVENTS[6]
Footnotes: --- (6) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 17,2010, § 2, adopted Nov. 8, 2010, amended art. VI in its entirety and enacted similar provisions as set out herein. The former art. VI derived from Ord. No. 14,2010, § 2, adopted Sept. 13, 2010. Ord. No. 14,2010 added provisions designated as §§ 6-200 through 6-207 to the Code. Inasmuch as said sections already existed as part of art. IV, the new provisions were redesignated as herein set out at the editor's discretion.
Sec. 6-350. - Definitions. In addition to the definitions provided in section 6-2, the following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this article, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Auditorium means the Cedartown Civic Auditorium. Auditorium commission means the Cedartown Auditorium Commission, as it is currently constituted or may be amended or reorganized from time to time. Authorized catered function means a scheduled special social event, reception, party, or similar activity for which a caterer or event location has prepared substantial food items to be served with appropriate serving facilities and personnel. Building inspector means the building inspector for the city. Drink means any bottle, can, or glass of beer, glass of wine, or distilled spirits beverage served for consumption on the premises, which may or may not be diluted by any other liquid. Food caterer shall mean any person who prepares food for consumption off the premises and has a license to do so. Licensed alcoholic beverage caterer shall mean any retail dealer who has been licensed pursuant to the provisions of this chapter and O.C.G.A. § 3-11-2. Licensee shall mean the person to whom an alcoholic beverage license is issued, or in the case of a partnership, corporation, or other legal entity, all partners, officers, and directors of such entity. Package means a bottle, can, keg, barrel, or other original consumer container. Purchase price means the consideration received for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink valued in money, whether received in cash or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits, and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the licensee to the purchaser, without any deduction there from whatsoever. Purchaser means any person who orders and gives present or future consideration for any alcoholic beverage by the drink. Special event means an authorized catered function as defined above, or, if no food is to be served, a social gathering, reception, party, or similar function organized in connection with a central cause, purpose, or other such event. (Ord. No. 17,2010, § 2(1), 11-8-10; Ord. No. 1-2012, § 1, 1-9-12) Sec. 6-351. - Authority to sell; license required; no distribution, sale or possession for sale without license; separate application and separate license required for each place of business. Alcoholic beverage caterers may operate in the city only under a license granted by the city on the terms and conditions provided in this chapter. Wine, beer and malt beverages, and distilled spirits shall not be distributed, sold or possessed for the purposes of sale by alcoholic beverage caterers without a license granted by the city. A separate application must be made and a separate alcoholic beverage caterer license must be obtained for each place of business. The criteria for the issuance of such a license and any renewals thereof shall be identical to the criteria for all other alcoholic beverage licenses issued under this chapter. All licenses issued hereunder shall also be subject to all regulations, ordinances, and requirements contained in chapter 6 regarding alcoholic beverages generally; except any special event conducted on public property that may occur within any zoning district of the city. (Ord. No. 17,2010, § 2(2), 11-8-10) Sec. 6-352. - Eligibility for license; application; fee. (a) Any holder of a license issued by a city or county governing authority authorizing the licensee to sell beer, malt beverages, or wine by the drink for consumption on the premises may apply for an off-premises license as an alcoholic beverage caterer to sell or distribute beer, malt beverages, or wine by the drink off premises and in connection with an authorized catered function or special event, and at the location of that function or special event. (b) Any holder of a license issued by a city or county governing authority authorizing the licensee to sell beer, malt beverages, or wine by the package for consumption off the premises may apply for an off-premises license as an alcoholic beverage caterer to sell or distribute beer, malt beverages, or wine by the drink off premises and in connection with an authorized catered function or special event, and at the location of that function or special event. (c) Any holder of a license issued by a city or county governing authority authorizing the licensee to sell distilled spirits by the drink for consumption on the premises may apply for an off-premises license as an alcoholic beverage caterer to sell or distribute distilled spirits by the drink off premises and in connection with an authorized catered function or special event, and at the location of that function or special event. (d) Any holder of a city license authorizing the licensee to sell distilled spirits by the package for consumption off the premises may apply for an off premises license as an alcoholic beverage caterer to sell or distribute beer, malt beverages, or wine by the drink off premises and in connection with an authorized catered function or special event, and at the location of that function or special event. (e) Each application for a license as an alcoholic beverage caterer shall be accompanied by a certified check for the full amount of the license fee, as follows: (1) Alcoholic beverage caterers selling wine to be consumed on the premises and at the location of the function or special event, $500.00 per year. (2) Alcoholic beverage caterers selling beer and malt beverages to be consumed on the premises and at the location of the function or special event, $500.00 per year. (3) Alcoholic beverage caterers selling distilled spirits to be consumed on the premises and at the location of the function or special event, $500.00 per year. (4) A combination license for alcoholic beverage caterers selling wine and beer and malt beverages to be consumed on the premises and at the location of the function or special event, $750.00 per year. (5) A combination license for alcoholic beverage caterers selling wine, beer and malt beverages, and distilled spirits to be consumed on the premises and at the location of the function or special event, $1,000.00 per year. (Ord. No. 17,2010, § 2(3), 11-8-10) Sec. 6-353. - Event permits; alcoholic beverage license required. (a) Any alcoholic beverage caterer who possesses a valid license from the city or another county or city in Georgia and possesses a valid license from the state to sell malt beverages, wine or distilled spirits by the drink or by the package at a fixed location within that city or county may be issued by the city an event permit authorizing such sales off premises and in connection with an authorized catered event, function, or special event, and at the location of that function or special event. (b) A licensed alcoholic beverage caterer may sell only that beverage which is authorized by the alcoholic beverage license in effect. For example, if the alcoholic beverage caterer possesses a valid license to sell malt beverages, only malt beverages can be sold by the alcoholic beverage caterer at an authorized catered event, function, or special event. If the caterer desires to sell any other alcoholic beverage for which the caterer is not licensed, the caterer may apply for such additional licenses, pursuant to this division [article]. (c) If food is to be sold or served at a special event, then any food caterer, as defined herein, operating within the city shall also apply for an alcoholic beverage caterer's license in order to distribute or sell any distilled spirits, beer, malt beverages or wine off the premises of the food caterer's business. This does not affect any requirements that the food caterer have a license to sell alcoholic beverages on the premises of the food caterer's business. Food caterers shall not be subject to any requirements of percentage sales ratios between food and alcoholic beverages at special events. (d) An alcoholic beverage caterer shall submit an application for an off-premises special event permit to the building inspector. The license may be applied for at the same time as the alcoholic beverage license(s). (e) The building inspector shall review the application and either approve or deny the permit in writing within five business days. If the application is denied, then the denial shall state the grounds therefore. An applicant may appeal the building inspector's denial of a permit to the city manager, whose decision shall be final. (f) It is unlawful for any person to engage in, carry on or conduct the sale or distribution of alcoholic beverages off premises and in connection with an authorized catered event or function or special event without first having obtained a permit as provided herein. (Ord. No. 17,2010, § 2(4), 11-8-10) Sec. 6-354. - Authorized catered function or "special event;" event permit required; application; taxes; fees; location; insurance. (a) Exclusive of the license required herein, each alcoholic beverage caterer wishing to sell or distribute distilled spirits, beer, malt beverages, or wine at an authorized catered event, function, or special event within the city must apply for an event permit.
