The application for the event shall include the following: (1) The name of the caterer and the alcoholic beverage caterer's license number; (2) The date, location, time, duration, and name of the event; (3) The sponsoring organizations, nature of the event, general purpose thereof, and whether the proceeds are for a for-profit or nonprofit organization; (4) An application for a certificate of special event insurance, covering BOTH the event itself and all persons or parties responsible for the dispensing of alcoholic beverages at the event; (5) Proof that the applicant has also applied for a special event permit with the Georgia Department of Revenue; (6) The quantity of alcoholic beverages to be transported from the licensee's primary location to the location of the event; (7) The persons who are responsible for the special event, including their names, addresses, relevant contact information, and Social Security number or other identifying information; (8) Such other information as might be required by this chapter and/or the building inspector, so as to be able to fully review all aspects of the special event application. (b) All caterers licensed pursuant to this division shall pay excise taxes at the rates set forth in this article. (1) Caterers licensed by the city shall maintain a record of all alcoholic beverages transported for each event by event, and shall submit their reports and remit taxes due with their monthly reports to the city. (2) Caterers licensed by any other jurisdiction shall maintain a record of all alcoholic beverages transported into the city for any event and submit a report of such beverages to the city within three days after the conclusion of the event. Failure to submit the reports and taxes required by this section may be grounds for denial of future permits to any caterer for similar events. (c) Each application shall be accompanied with a $100.00 fee, which shall defray the cost incurred in background investigations, review of the permit, and related matters by the building inspector, and, potentially, by the city manager. The application fee is nonrefundable. In the event a permit is granted, an additional fee of $50.00 shall be paid. With each application, a certified check for the application fee shall accompany the application. No permit shall be granted until the $50.00 fee is paid. (d) The original permit shall be kept in the vehicle at all times while transporting the alcoholic beverages to the authorized catered event or function or special event. It also shall be maintained at the site of the catered event and available for inspection both at and during such event or function or special event. (e) It is unlawful for a licensed alcoholic beverage caterer to distribute or sell alcoholic beverages off the premises of the special event or in any manner other than as authorized by the event permit. All sales or service of alcoholic beverages at the event shall take place within the primary structure of the building, within certain defined areas of the special event location, and within the basic confines of the location (excluding areas of service of alcoholic beverages), as described in the application of the caterer. No alcoholic beverages may be sold or served outside of the confines of the general location of the special event; nor, will any patron of the special event be allowed to leave the special event location with alcoholic beverages. (f) The event permit will be valid only for the length of the authorized catered event or function or special event or as approved by the city, not to exceed three days. After expiration of the event, the alcoholic beverage caterer must apply for a new event permit in the same manner as the original permit. (g) The alcoholic beverage caterer shall provide one person per 100 people at the special event to serve as security for said event. (h) Within not less than five days prior to the special event the caterer shall provide the building inspector with an insurance certificate, evidencing coverage for the special event and all persons serving alcoholic beverages at the special event location. This insurance certificate shall name the city as an additional named insured, together with any department of the city that may be the recipient of any proceeds of that special event, or otherwise may be involved in assisting with the special event in any manner. The insurance coverage shall be a minimum of $1,000,000.00 per occurrence, and $100,000.00 in property damage coverage, evidenced on the face of the certificate. (i) No employee, agent, elected official, servant, or other party affiliated in any manner with the city shall receive any percentage of the proceeds, individually (and not as a part of their official function with the city), for their involvement in the event, except as to their general rate of pay or other similar remuneration to said individual through the city. This limitation shall not apply to events and/or performances held at the Cedartown Civic Auditorium, at which the Cedartown Auditorium Commission serves as the alcoholic beverage caterer. (Ord. No. 17,2010, § 2(5), 11-8-10; Ord. No. 1-2012, § 2, 1-9-12) Sec. 6-355. - Duration and renewal of licenses. Any alcoholic beverage caterer's license issued hereunder shall automatically expire on December 31sof the year of its issuance. Each licensee shall make a written application for renewal on or before November 15 of each year. (Ord. No. 17,2010, § 2(6), 11-8-10) Sec. 6-356. - Restrictions. (a) No person under the age of 21 shall be employed by a licensed alcoholic beverage caterer, who, in the course of such employment, would dispense, serve, sell, or handle alcoholic beverages as prohibited by O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23. (b) No alcoholic beverage caterer may distribute or sell alcoholic beverages during any hours prohibited in the state or county or on any days prohibited in the state, county, or city. (Ord. No. 17,2010, § 2(7), 11-8-10) Sec. 6-357. - Violations. (a) Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of an ordinance violation, and be subject to a fine of up to $1,000.00 and/or six months in jail per violation. (b) Any person violating any provision of this chapter may also, after a hearing as provided in this chapter, have their malt beverage, wine, and/or distilled spirits license or occupational tax certificate suspended or revoked and/or be subject to other penalties as provided for in connection with violations of said license. (Ord. No. 17,2010, § 2(8), 11-8-10) Sec. 6-358. - Auditorium commission as licensee. (a) The Cedartown City Commission recognizes and appreciates the role of the Cedartown Auditorium Commission in providing a venue for the citizens of Cedartown and northwest Georgia to enjoy musical, theatrical, artistic, and other similar cultural events. The commission further recognizes and appreciates the efforts the auditorium commission has recently made and continues to make with respect to fundraising, sponsorship, advertising, concessions, and other similar efforts, so that it may eventually become not only a self-sustaining entity, but also a potential source of revenue for the city. (b) In recognition of the foregoing, the auditorium commission may apply for and be granted an alcoholic beverage catering license for events that it sponsors or promotes at the auditorium, and shall not be required to have, or provide an alcoholic beverage or food catering license, as required by section 6-352, in order to be eligible for an alcoholic beverage catering license under this article. However, the auditorium commission must pay all fees and comply with all other provisions of this article and this Code regarding alcoholic beverage catering licenses and serving alcoholic beverages generally. (Ord. No. 1-2012, § 3, 1-9-12)

div.head: Chapter 10 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 10-1—10-35. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT[1] Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Sale of adult magazines, books and material, § 58-10. State Law reference— Furnishing to, purchase of or possession of alcoholic beverages by persons under 21 years of age prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23; age of legal majority in Georgia is 18 years, O.C.G.A. § 39-1-1.
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 10-36—10-55. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - LICENSING
Sec. 10-56. - Penalty. Any person violating the provisions of the license granted under this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable pursuant to the provisions of section 1-13. Further, any person attempting to operate, conduct or maintain an entertainment establishment contrary to the provisions of this article is hereby declared to be acting unlawfully and creating a public nuisance. The city may (in addition to, or in lieu of, prosecuting a criminal action pursuant to the penalty provisions set forth above) take such other action to stop such activity. The city manager may apply to the municipal court for abatement of a nuisance, or to such other court of competent jurisdiction, to grant such relief as will abate or close such entertainment and/or restrain and enjoin any person from operating, conducting or maintaining the establishment contrary to the provisions of this article. Any violation of the provision of this article shall be per se grounds for suspension revocation of a license granted under this article. (Ord. No. 3-1993, § 3(13-210), 2-8-93) Sec. 10-57. - License required; exceptions; application fee. (a) The city commission does hereby establish the requirement of a license for any business within the city to operate a nightclub, bar, social gathering place, dancehall, private club or similar operation in which entertainment is to be provided to the patrons in the establishment. The city commission finds that it is in the public interest of the city to regulate such establishments, especially to prevent nude dancing or similar conduct which is prohibited under section 10-86. Further, the city desires to regulate closely in establishments which provide alcoholic beverages, entertainment so as to prevent criminal activity, nuisances, fighting and similar disruptive activities. For purposes of this article, "entertainment" shall be defined as dancing, live music, live entertainers, drama, vocal groups, instrumental groups or other performances which might be videotaped, stereo-recreated music or similar such entertainment which allows the patrons to dance, watch the entertainment (whether for a fee or not) or otherwise be present for a performance within the business establishment. (b) No license shall be required for any nonprofit civic organization, club, the civic arts commission or such similar organization which is engaged in eleemosynary, religious or fundraising activities, which activities may include entertainment within the general context of the definition provisions of subsection (a) of this section. (c) Any person, association, partnership or corporation desiring to obtain a license to operate, engage in, conduct or carry on any entertainment establishment shall make application to the chief of police or his designated representative. Prior to submitting such application, a nonrefundable fee in the amount set forth in the schedule of fees and charges shall be paid to the city to defray, in part, the cost of the investigation and report required by this article. (Ord. No. 3-1993, § 3(13-201), 2-8-93) Sec. 10-58. - Application contents. Each application for an entertainment establishment permit under this article shall contain the following information: (1) The applicant's full true name, social security number and date of birth. (2) The present address and telephone number of the applicant. (3) Acceptable written proof that the applicant is at least 18 years of age. (4) Business, occupation or employment history of the applicant for the five years immediately preceding the date of application; and business or employment records of the applicant, partners in a partnership, directors and officers of a corporation. (5) The business license history of the applicant and whether the applicant, in previous licensed operations in this city or any other city, state or territory, has had such license or permit for a business (especially a similar type of business) revoked or suspended, the reason therefor, and the business activity or occupation subsequent to such action of suspension or revocation of the applicant. (6) If the applicant is a corporation, the name of the corporation shall be set forth exactly as shown in its articles of incorporation, together with the place and date of incorporation, and the names and addresses of each of its current officers and directors. If the applicant is a partnership, the applicant shall set forth the same, residence address and dates of birth of all limited and/or general partners. If one or more of the partners is a corporation the provisions of this subsection pertaining to corporations shall apply. The applicant corporation or partnership shall designate one of its officers or general partners to act as its responsible managing officer. Such designated persons shall complete and sign all application forms required of an individual applicant under this article, but only one application fee shall be charged. (7) If the applicant, any partners or any corporate officers or directors, if the applicant is a corporation, have been convicted of any crime involving good moral character and/or moral turpitude in the past five years and, if so, a complete description of any such crime including date of violation, date of conviction, jurisdiction and any disposition, including any fine or sentence imposed and whether terms of disposition have been fully completed. (8) If the applicant is a person doing business under a trade name, a copy of the trade name properly recorded. If the applicant is a corporation using a trade name (other than the corporate name), a copy of the authority to do business in Georgia, trade name affidavit, if any, and last annual report, if any. (9) At least three character references from individuals who are in no way related to the applicant or individual shareholders, officers or directors of a corporation and who are not or will not benefit financially in any way from the application if the license is granted and who have not been convicted of any crime involving moral turpitude and/or character. (10) Address of the premises to be licensed. (11) Whether the premises are owned or rented. (12) Each applicant for an entertainment establishment license shall be verified and acknowledged under oath to be true and correct by: a. If the applicant is an individual, the individual. b. If by a partnership, by the manager or general partner. c. If a corporation, by the president of the corporation. d. If any other organization or association, by the chief administrative official. (13) In addition to the information required in this section, the application shall disclose the name, address, social security number and date of birth of any and all persons who have a financial interest of any type in the entity which is applying for the license. (14) Any other matter reasonably required by the chief of police. (Ord. No. 3-1993, § 3(13-202), 2-8-93) Sec. 10-59. - Investigation; granting of license. (a) The chief of police shall have 30 days to investigate the application and the background of the applicant. Upon completion of the investigation and recommendation of the chief of police, the city commission may grant the license at its next duly called and held meeting if it finds that: (1) The required fee has been paid. (2) The application conforms in all respects to the provisions of this article. (3) The applicant has not knowingly made a material misrepresentation in the application. (4) The applicant, if an individual, or any officers or directors, if the applicant is a corporation, or any of the partners, including limited partners, if the applicant is a partnership, has not been convicted in a court of competent jurisdiction of an offense involving a sex-related crime, drug-related or alcohol-related felony or convicted of an attempt to commit any of the abovementioned offenses; or convicted in any state of any offense which is a crime involving moral character and/or moral turpitude. (5) The applicant has not had an entertainment establishment permit, general entertainment license, beer license or other similar license or permit denied or revoked for cause involving moral character in this city or other local government jurisdiction located in or out of this state prior to the date of application. (6) The building, structure, equipment or location of such business, as proposed by the applicant, would comply with all applicable zoning and distance laws relating to the sale of malt beverages and would qualify to receive a certificate of occupancy. (7) The applicant is at least 18 years of age. (8) On the date the business for which a permit is required in this article commences, and thereafter, there will be a responsible person on the premises to act as manager at all times during which the business is open. (9) If alcoholic beverages are being served upon the premises, there has been no disorderly conduct, disruption, breach of the peace or significant previous problems with the establishment where the entertainment license is requested to be granted. (10) The applicant does not propose, and so states in writing, to allow nude dancing or other adult-type entertainment within the premises, which is prohibited by section 10-86. (11) The grant of such license will not cause a violation of this article or any other ordinance or regulation of the city, the state or the United States and has met the approval of the chief of police. (12) The licensee shall maintain at all times a written notification of the name, address and phone number of the manager or assistant manager in charge of the licensed premises and there shall at all times be a manager in charge and on the premises during operating hours. (b) There is hereby created a continuing obligation on the licensee to comply with all provisions of this Code. (c) The applicant shall appear before the city commission at any hearing on this issue of the grant or denial of the requested license. (Ord. No. 3-1993, § 3(13-203), 2-8-93) Sec. 10-60. - Persons ineligible for license. No license provided for by this article shall be issued to or held by: (1) An applicant who has not paid all required fees and taxes for a business at that location and/or property taxes. (2) Any person who is not of good moral character. (3) Any corporation, any of whose directors are not of good moral character. (4) Any partnership or association, any of whose partners or members are not of good moral character. (5) Any applicant who is not qualified to hold and conduct business according to the laws of the United States, the state or the city. (Ord. No. 3-1993, § 3(13-204), 2-8-93) Sec. 10-61. - Renewal. Licenses for entertainment establishments may be renewed on a calendar-year basis provided that the business continues to meet the requirements set out in this article. Renewal applications shall be submitted by November 15 of each year prior to January 1 of the year for which such license is requested. (Ord. No. 3-1993, § 3(13-205), 2-8-93) Sec. 10-62. - License nontransferable. No entertainment establishment license may be sold, transferred or assigned by a license holder, or by operation of law, to any other person. Any such sale, transfer or assignment, or attempted sale, transfer or assignment, shall be deemed to constitute a voluntary surrender of the license and the license shall thereafter be null and void; provided and excepting, however, that if the licensee is a partnership and one or more of the partners should die, one or more of the surviving partners may acquire, by a purchase or otherwise, the interest of the deceased partner without affecting a surrender or termination of the license, and in such case the license, upon notification to the city, shall be placed in the name of the surviving partner. (Ord. No. 3-1993, § 3(13-206), 2-8-93) Sec. 10-63. - Prohibition against minors. It shall be unlawful for any license holder to admit or permit the admission of minors within the licensed premises. It shall further be unlawful for any person to sell, barter or give to any minor any alcohol, ticket for entertainment or to otherwise allow such person to be upon the premises where alcohol is being sold and such live entertainment, as may be permitted by this article, is being conducted. (Ord. No. 3-1993, § 3(13-207), 2-8-93) Sec. 10-64. - Change of name. (a) No licensee under this article shall advertise, operate, conduct, manage, engage in or carry on an entertainment establishment under any name other than his name and the name of the business as specified on his license. (b) Any application for an extension or expansion of a building or other place of business where an entertainment establishment is located shall require inspection and shall comply with the provisions and regulations of this article. (Ord. No. 3-1993, § 3(13-208), 2-8-93) Sec. 10-65. - Refusal; appeal. (a) If the chief of police following investigation of the applicant deems that the applicant does not fulfill the requirements as set forth in this article, the chief shall notify the city clerk of such opinion and, within 30 days of the date of application, provide copies of the investigation report to the city clerk. The city clerk shall notify the applicant by certified mail of such denial. Any applicant who is denied a license may appeal the denial to the city commission by filing a written notice of appeal within ten days of the receipt of the notice from the city clerk. A hearing before the commission shall be scheduled within 45 days of the notice. (b) At any such hearing, the applicant shall have the right to cross examine any witnesses produced by the city concerning the denial of the application, and to present any evidence the applicant may feel pertinent to the issue of granting, suspension or denial, or nonrenewal of any entertainment license. The decision of the city commission made thereon shall be in writing, and shall be final, subject to appeal to the superior court of the county. (Ord. No. 3-1993, § 3(13-209), 2-8-93) Sec. 10-66. - Revocation; appeal. (a) The chief of police is authorized to suspend or revoke a license previously granted under this article. If the chief of police seeks to suspend or to revoke a license, the chief of police shall give written notification to the licensee of such action and the notice shall contain a specification of the violation and shall be served upon the licensee at least five days prior to a hearing on the issue. The licensee shall be given written notice of the time and place of the hearing. (b) The chief of police shall be authorized to suspend or revoke a license in the event of any one or more of the following occurrences: (1) A licensee gave false or misleading information in the original application. (2) A licensee has knowingly allowed possession, use, or sale of controlled substances on the premises and/or knowingly allowed possession, use or sale of controlled substances or alcohol to a minor on the premises. (3) A licensee has knowingly allowed the violation of an ordinance of the city or a violation of any criminal law of the state to occur on the premises. (4) A licensee has violated any provision of this article. (5) A licensee has been convicted of any drug-related, alcohol-related or sex-related crime or crime of moral turpitude (federal, state or local) regarding an offense which was committed on the premises or which would otherwise violate the provisions of this article. (6) A licensee fails to pay any fee, license fee, fine or other amount of money due to the city under this article or any other licensing ordinance of the city. (c) If the chief of police suspends or revokes any license under this article, the suspension or revocation shall be for a period of not less than one day nor more than 365 days, within the discretion of the chief of police. However, the licensee shall be authorized to continue its business operations until the date of the hearing scheduled in accordance with subsection (d) of this section. No licensee or other applicant may apply for a new license during any period of suspension or revocation. In any hearing conducted by the chief of police, the chief shall consider, among other things, the severity of the allegations, the evidence submitted and the testimony presented, in making any decision on suspension, revocation and the duration of either. (d) In the event of a suspension or revocation by the chief of police, the licensee may appeal the decision of the chief of police to the city commission by filing a written notice of appeal within ten days from the date of the decision of the chief of police. Thereafter, a hearing shall be scheduled before the commission within 30 days after the date of the notice of the appeal by the applicant. After hearing by the commission, it may take such action as it deems appropriate, including the upholding of the action of the chief of police or the imposition of such action as the commission may deed appropriate under the facts. The decision of the commission shall be final. Appeals from the decision of the commission shall be to the superior court of the county, filed within 30 days of the final action of the commission. If the licensee does not file an appeal from any decision of the chief of police, as provided in this section, the decision of the chief of police shall be final. (Ord. No. 3-1993, § 3(13-211), 2-8-93) Secs. 10-67—10-85. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - ENTERTAINMENT ACTIVITIES
Sec. 10-86. - Prohibited activities enumerated. The following types of entertainment, attire and conduct are prohibited upon any premises licensed to sell, serve or dispense alcohol beverages, or so-called juice bars or any other entertainment type or location (public or private) within the city: (1) The employment or use of any person, in any capacity, in the sale or service of alcohol and/or other beverages while such person is unclothed or in such attire, costume or clothing as to expose to view any portion of the female breast below the top of the areola or of any portion of the male or female pubic hair, anus, cleft of the buttocks, vulva and genitals. (2) Live entertainment where any person appears in the manner described in subsection (1) of this section or where such person performs acts of or acts which simulate any of the following: a. Sexual intercourse, masturbation, sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, flagellation or any sexual act which is prohibited by law. b. The touching, caressing or fondling of the breasts, buttocks, anus or genitals. c. The displaying of the male or female pubic hair, anus, vulva or genitals. (3) The holding, promoting, sponsoring or allowing of any contest, promotion, special night, event or any other activity where patrons of the establishment are encouraged or allowed to engage in any of the conduct described in subsections (1) and (2) above. (Code 1969, § 15-49; Ord. No. 2-1993, § 2(15-49), 2-8-93) Sec. 10-87. - Authorized entertainment activities; correlation with license. (a) Any person may apply for a license in an establishment selling alcoholic beverages (pursuant to proper licenses within the city) or any other business that wishes to have entertainment, for a license authorizing entertainment on the premises. This entertainment may be in the form of live music, drama, vocal groups, instrumental groups, videos, stereo-recreated music or similar such entertainment; provided that none of the entertainment, nor the employees within the establishment, shall violate any of the provisions of a properly granted entertainment license. (b) Nothing contained in this section shall act as a prohibition to a properly granted entertainment license obtained through the provisions of section 10-57 et seq. However, no person granted such entertainment license shall engage in any of the activities prohibited by section 10-86. (Ord. No. 2-1993, § 2(15-49.1), 2-8-93) Sec. 10-88. - Violations; hearing, penalties. (a) Any party who violates the provisions of section 10-86 shall be punished, upon conviction thereof, pursuant to the provisions of section 1-13. Each day any such conduct occurs which is violative of section 10-86 shall be considered a separate and continuous violation for which criminal punishment pursuant to section 1-13 may be imposed. (b) Any person attempting to operate, conduct or maintain a business or entertainment establishment which violates the prohibited acts of section 10-86 is hereby declared to be an unlawful activity and a public nuisance. The city may (in addition to, or in lieu thereof, proceeding with a criminal action pursuant to the penalty provisions hereinabove set forth) take such other action to stop such activity. The city manager may apply to the municipal court for abatement of a nuisance or to such other court of competent jurisdiction to grant such relief as will abate or close the entertainment establishment and/or restrain and enjoin any person from operating, conducting or maintaining such business or establishment contrary to the provisions of section 10-86. (c) Any person who may hold a valid entertainment license, or otherwise hold a valid business license, within the city who is alleged to be violating the provisions of section 10-86 shall be entitled to a hearing for any suspension or revocation of any business license within the city under the same terms and conditions as hearings contemplated in section 10-65 concerning the granting of entertainment licenses. (Code 1969, § 15-49; Ord. No. 2-1993, § 2(15-49.2), 2-8-93) Secs. 10-89—10-110. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - BILLIARDS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- State Law reference— Authority to license and regulate billiard rooms, O.C.G.A. § 43-8-2.
Sec. 10-111. - Definition. The terms "billiards," or "pool," as used in this article, shall mean any of the several games played on a table surrounded by an elastic ledge of cushions, with balls which are impelled by a cue, and shall include all forms of the games known as carom billiards, pocket billiards (formerly called pool), and English billiards. The term "billiard room" shall mean any public place where the game of billiards is permitted to be played and for which a charge is made for use of equipment. Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 10-112. - Provision for local licensing. The purpose of this article is to provide for local licensing and regulation of billiard rooms. Pursuant to the authority of O.C.G.A. § 43-8-16 the provisions of O.C.G.A. ch. 8, tit. 43 shall not apply within the corporate limits of the city. Sec. 10-113. - Applicability of provisions. The provisions of this article shall not be construed to include billiard tables or billiard rooms operated by private or industrial concerns, religious orders, charitable institutions, state, county or city institutions, fraternal orders or bona fide clubs, using such tables for members or employees only. Sec. 10-114. - License required. It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or operate within the city any pool room or billiard room or any place of like character, without first having made application to the city clerk and, after paying the prescribed fees, having received a license to maintain and operate such business. No license shall be issued to any person under the age of 18 years or to any person who has been convicted of a felony within the past five years. All licensees must be bona fide residents of the county or the city. Sec. 10-115. - Obstructing view of interior. It shall be unlawful for any person running or operating a billiard room to use in such room any screens at the doors and windows, or to use on the doors or windows any painted or stained glass so as to obstruct a clear view of the interior. Sec. 10-116. - Enclosed rooms prohibited; exceptions. No closed rooms, stalls or other enclosures wherein the game of pool is played shall be permitted within the licensed premises. This provision, however, shall not be construed to prohibit the maintenance of washrooms and toilet rooms for proper purposes, nor the maintenance of closets for storage purposes exclusively. Sec. 10-117. - Access by police officers; reports of disorderly conduct. (a) All law enforcement officers shall have free access to the licensed premises at any time any person is present in the licensed premises. (b) It shall be the duty of every person owning or managing a pool or billiard room in the city to report to the police department every person guilty of disorderly conduct in the pool or billiard room immediately after the conduct comes to the knowledge of the owner or manager. Sec. 10-118. - Separate license required to serve alcoholic beverages. It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any establishment licensed under the provisions of this article to permit any alcoholic beverages being brought or kept upon the premises of the licensed establishment without first obtaining a license to permit the consumption of alcoholic beverages on the premises. Sec. 10-119. - Multiple license requirements. Any person who holds an alcoholic beverage pouring and/or alcoholic beverage consumption license on the premises and in which establishment billiards or pool are allowed to be played by patrons of the establishment shall also have a license under this article. The licensee shall comply with all the requirements of this article, and in addition thereto, those requirements concerning coin-operated amusement devices if such pool or billiard tables are coin-operated. Sec. 10-120. - Operation during legal hours for drinking. It shall be unlawful for any person running or operating a pool room or billiard room within the city wherein alcoholic beverages are licensed to be consumed on the premises to keep the room open or permit the playing of any pool or billiards within the licensed premises at any time other than the legal hours for drinking and possession of open containers as set out in chapter 6 of this Code. Sec. 10-121. - Restriction on minors' presence. It shall be unlawful for any person running or operating a pool room or billiard room within the city to permit persons under 18 years of age, unless accompanied by a parent or guardian, to enter the licensed premises of the pool room if the establishment also holds an alcoholic beverage license for consumption on the premises. Secs. 10-122—10-140. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT MACHINES
Sec. 10-141. - Definitions. The following words, terms, or phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this Section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Amusement game room means any location where one or more bona fide coin-operated amusement machines are operated that permit noncash redemption as provided in O.C.G.A. § 16-25-35(d)(1). Bona fide coin-operated amusement machine means the same as this term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-17-1(2) and any applicable regulations of the state and includes Vegas-style video machines as defined herein. Location means a business within the city that has complied with the provisions of the ordinances of the city and all requirements as to occupation taxes and business licenses required by local and or state law. Operator means any person who operates an amusement game room, owns the property on which the game room is located, sets up an amusement game room for operation by themselves or by another, or leases or distributes for the purpose of operation by another any amusement game room whether any setting up for operation, leasing or distribution is for a fixed charge or rental; or on the basis of a division of the income received from such game rooms, or otherwise. Vegas-style video machines means any video game machine or device, operated for any consideration, for the simulated play of slot machines (matchup or lineup games) poker, blackjack, or any other card game described in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-20, that except for meeting the payout exceptions in O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35(d), would otherwise classify as an illegal gaming device and activity. (Ord. No. 9-2009, § 2, 8-10-09) Sec. 10-142. - Owner information. Operators of an amusement game room within the corporate limits of the city shall submit to the city clerk the following information: (a) Name, address, and age of the operator of the business and owner of the premises. (b) Address or place where the bona fide coin-operated amusement machine or machines are to be offered to the public for play and the other business or businesses operated at that address or place; (c) Name and address of the owner of the machine or machines and a copy of the owner's master license(s); (d) List of any other licenses or permits from the city held by the operator and/or by the owner of the premises. (e) A detailed list of each machine operating at the location. The operator shall update this information when any changes are made and shall provide updated information to the city clerk yearly. (Ord. No. 9-2009, § 2, 8-10-09) Sec. 10-143. - Violations. Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of an offense, subject to the penalties provisions contained in this chapter. (Ord. No. 9-2009, § 2, 8-10-09) Sec. 10-144. - Inspection. Each operator under this article shall, at all times, keep every portion of the premises being used for the operation of an amusement game room open for inspection by the police department and other city departments for the purpose of enforcing any provisions of this article or other laws. (Ord. No. 9-2009, § 2, 8-10-09) Sec. 10-145. - Distance. Every amusement game room in the city shall comply with the proximity provisions for businesses licensed to sell alcohol set out in section 6-131 of the Code of Ordinances. (Ord. No. 9-2009, § 2, 8-10-09) Sec. 10-146. - Number of bona fide coin-operated amusement machines at a location. No amusement game room in the city shall offer to the public more than six Vegas-style video machines at the same location. (Ord. No. 9-2009, § 2, 8-10-09) Sec. 10-147. - Gambling prohibited. Nothing herein shall be deemed to authorize, license or permit any gambling devices whatsoever, or any mechanism which has been judicially determined to be a gambling device; or in any way contrary to law or that may be contrary to any future law of the state. Any operator, proprietor, individual, firm, partnership or corporation that shall permit in any way, directly or indirectly, gaming or gambling in the use of any device or machines shall be subject to immediate confiscation of such device or machines by the police department as contraband, and shall be punishable as a misdemeanor, unless other punishment is authorized under the laws of the state. (Ord. No. 9-2009, § 2, 8-10-09) Sec. 10-148. - View of machines; prohibited use. Bona fide coin-operated amusement machines shall be operated in areas clearly visible from the entrance and windows of the building in which they are operated. No screens, shades, partitions or other devices of like character shall be allowed which shall have the effect of obstructing the view through the windows or doors of the location of the amusement game room. Further, no bona fide coin operated amusement games shall be allowed to be located in back rooms or other restricted access rooms not accessible or open to the general public. (Ord. No. 9-2009, § 2, 8-10-09) Sec. 10-149. - Gross receipts from amusement machines and from business. Income from Vegas-style video machines offering noncash redemption in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35 shall not constitute more than 50 percent of the income from any location. Compliance with this section requires both the availability of records for inspection and compliance with 50-percent-of-income requirement. (Ord. No. 9-2009, § 2, 8-10-09) Sec. 10-150. - Notice requirement. Every amusement game room shall post a conspicuous sign with the following similar words: "Georgia law prohibits giving or receipt of any money for winning a game or games on an amusement machine; giving or receipt of any money for free replays won on an amusement machine; giving or receipt of money for any merchandise, prize, toy, gift certificate, or novelty won on an amusement machine; or awarding any merchandise, prize, toy, gift certificate, or novelty of a value exceeding $5.00 for a single play of an amusement machine." The owner or operator of each amusement game room shall inform every employee of the acts and omissions prohibited by O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35 and by this article, and of the penalties for violation O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35 and this article. (Ord. No. 9-2009, § 2, 8-10-09) Sec. 10-151. - Compliance with O.C.G.A. provisions relating to master licenses and stickers for individual machines. Bona fide coin-operated amusement machines may be used in an amusement game room within the city only if the machines are owned by a person who holds a valid master license in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-17-2, and each machine offered to the public for play has a valid permit sticker in accordance with O.C.G.A. § 48-17-9. The city official in charge of issuing business licenses shall notify the State Commissioner of Revenue of any observed violation of O.C.G.A. § 48-17-2 or 48-17-9. (Ord. No. 9-2009, § 2, 8-10-09) Sec. 10-152. - Penalties for violations by owners or operators of amusement game rooms. In addition to penalties set out by Georgia law for failure to comply with the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 16-12-35 (a) through (j), the owner or operator of an amusement game room, upon violation of any requirement of this article or any law, which violation is directly attributable to the operation of an amusement game room or bona fide coin-operated amusement machine, may be subject to the general penalty section of the Cedartown Code for each such violation and further may be subject to the following administrative restrictions to be imposed by the Cedartown City Commission at their discretion: (1) First offense. Suspension for not more than six months of the owner or operator's conditional use permit for operating an amusement game room at the location where the violation occurred. (2) Second offense. Suspension for more than six months or permanent revocation of the owner or operator's conditional use permit for operating an amusement game room in the location where the violation occurred, and possible suspension of other permits and licenses granted to the operator or owner of the premises by the city, including licenses for the sale of alcoholic beverages for up to six months if the same premises is involved. Prior to any action being taken against a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages, the notice and hearing requirements of the City Code shall be followed. (3) Multiple offenses. Offering one or more bona fide coin-operated amusement games in violation of any suspension or revocation of a conditional use permit for the operation of any amusement game room at the location is punishable as a separate violation of this section and if said violation occurs during a suspension period, shall result in revocation of the conditional use permit for an amusement game room at the location. Further, any person found to have received money or any other illegal payout as a reward for the successful play or winning of any coin-operated amusement machine shall be in violation of this ordinance and subject to the general penalty section of the Cedartown Code for each violation. (Ord. No. 9-2009, § 2, 8-10-09)

div.head: Chapter 14 - ANIMALS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Health and sanitation, ch. 50. State Law reference— Authority to exercise animal control, Ga. Const., art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3(a)(3); livestock running at large or straying, O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq.; permitting dogs in heat to roam or run free, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-6; Dangerous Dog Control Law, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.; Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq.; control of rabies, O.C.G.A. § 31-19-1 et seq.; cruelty to animals, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-4; liability of owner or keeper of vicious or dangerous animal for injuries caused by animal, O.C.G.A. § 51-2-6.
Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Abandoned animal means an animal that is unattended and uncared for and is: (1) Placed on public property or within a public building. (2) Placed on private property or within a private building without the consent of the private property's owner, custodian or tenant. (3) On or within the property of the animal's owner or custodian and has remained unattended and uncared for in excess of 36 hours. Animal means any living nonhuman species of animal, domestic or wild. At large means off the premises of the owner and not under the control of the owner, a member of his immediate family or some other person, either by leash, cord, chain or some other holding device. Control means that an animal is under the control of its owner if it is on his private property. If the animal is off the owner's property, control is defined in section 14-6. Dangerous animal means any wild mammal, reptile or fowl which is not naturally tame or gentle but is of a wild nature or disposition and which, because of its size, vicious propensity or other characteristics, would constitute a danger to human life or property if not kept or maintained in a safe manner or in secure quarters; and any domestic mammal, reptile or fowl which, because of its size, vicious propensity or other characteristic, would constitute a danger to human life or property if not kept or maintained in a safe manner or in secure quarters. Dangerous dog means any dog that, according to the records of an appropriate authority: (1) Inflicts a severe injury on a human being without provocation on public or private property. (2) Aggressively bites, attacks or endangers the safety of human beings without provocation after the dog has been classified as a potentially dangerous dog and after the owner has been notified of such classification. Owner means any natural person or any legal entity, including, but not limited to, a corporation, partnership, firm or trust owning, possessing, harboring, keeping or having custody or control of a dog, dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog within this city. Potentially dangerous dog means any dog that at any time and without [provocation] bites, injures, or behaves in an aggressive manner toward a human being that would cause a reasonable person to be in fear of imminent injury or bodily harm from the dog. Poundkeeper means any person engaged by the city to maintain facilities for impounding animals under this chapter and otherwise carrying out the provisions of this chapter. Proper enclosure means an enclosure for keeping a dangerous or potentially dangerous animal securely confined indoors on the owner's property. If the animal is not kept indoors, a proper enclosure shall be a securely enclosed and locked fence, pen or other structure suitable for both preventing the animal's escape and small children's entry. Such a structure shall have secure sides and a secure top and provide the animal protection from the elements. If the animal is confined within a fence, all sides of the fence shall be high enough to prevent the animal from escaping over it, and the bottom of the fence shall be constructed so as to prevent the animal from escaping underneath it. Records of an appropriate authority means records of any state, county or municipal law enforcement agency; records of any county or municipal animal control agency; records of any county board of health; records of any federal, state or local court; or records of a dog control officer provided for in this article. Severe injury means any physical injury that results in broken bones or disfiguring lacerations requiring multiple sutures or cosmetic surgery or a physical injury that results in death. Stray means an animal running at large in the city without a proper license as provided for in this chapter. (Code 1969, § 4-1; Ord. No. 10-1998, § I, 3-9-98) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 14-2. - Enforcement, jurisdiction. (a) The city may contract or enter into agreements with any other municipality or county for any joint dog control services or for the implementation of dog control services required by the dangerous dog control law of the state (O.C.G.A. § 4-8-20 et seq.). This joint dog control service may include, but is not limited to, the use of joint personnel, facilities, equipment, dog control officers, animal control boards or any other joint services as may be expeditious and deemed advisable by the city. (b) The city manager may appoint such animal and/or dog control officers, police officers or such other personnel as may be necessary to effectuate the purposes of the provisions of this chapter. All persons so appointed shall have the power to enforce all ordinances and codes relating to animal control of the city, shall perform all duties assigned to them by the city manager, shall investigate any animal nuisances, advise on animal control regulations and problems, educate the public concerning animal control and generally supervise all activities required by this chapter. Further, the individuals shall administer the provisions of the dangerous dog control law of the state. (c) The city commission does hereby delegate unto the municipal court of this city jurisdiction for the enforcement of the provisions of this article, including the right to conduct such hearings, make such fines and require the enforcement of these ordinances as may be generally provided by this Code or the laws of this state. (Code 1969, § 4-16(a)—(c)) Sec. 14-3. - Penalty. Any person violating the terms of this chapter shall be punishable as provided in section 1-13 and appendix C. (Code 1969, § 4-16(d); Ord. No. 23-1998, § 1, 8-10-98) Sec. 14-4. - Certain animals declared public nuisance. (a) An animal shall be declared to be a public nuisance if it: (1) Is found at large in violation of sections 14-5 and 14-6. (2) Is a dangerous animal running at large. (3) Produces, because of quantity, manner or method in which the animals are domesticated or maintained, unsanitary conditions in the city. (4) Attacks passersby or passing vehicles. (5) Makes or causes frequent or long-continued noise which disturbs the comfort or repose of any person in the vicinity. (6) Is inimical to the public health, welfare or safety according to rules and regulations promulgated by the county board of health. (b) Any person who knowingly keeps, owns, harbors or acts as custodian of an animal constituting a nuisance shall be guilty of an unlawful act and shall be punishable as provided in this chapter. (Code 1969, § 4-2) Sec. 14-5. - Running at large. It shall be unlawful for any person to allow any dog to run at large at any time within the corporate limits of the city. (Code 1969, § 4-3; Ord. No. 10-1998, § II, 3-9-98) Sec. 14-6. - Duty to keep animal under restraint while off owner's property. It shall be the duty of the owner or possessor of any animal to keep said animal under control at all times while the animal is off the real property limits of the owner or possessor. For the purposes of this section, an animal is deemed under control when it is confined within a vehicle, parked or in motion, secured by a leash or other device held by a competent person or is properly confined within an enclosure with permission of the owner of the property where the enclosure is located. (Code 1969, § 4-4) Sec. 14-7. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 10-2012, § 1, adopted Aug. 13, 2012, repealed § 14-7, which pertained to licensing of dogs and derived from Code 1969, § 4-5. Sec. 14-8. - Investigations by dog control officer; notice of classification as dangerous dog. (a) Upon receiving a report of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within a dog control officer's jurisdiction from a law enforcement agency, animal control agency, rabies control officer or county board of health, the dog control officer shall make such investigations and inquiries with regard to such report as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this chapter. (b) When a dog control officer determines to classify a dog as a dangerous dog or reclassify a potentially dangerous dog as a dangerous dog, the dog control officer shall notify the dog's owner in writing by certified mail to the owner's last known address of such classification or reclassification pursuant to section 14-9. (Code 1969, § 4-6.1) Sec. 14-9. - Procedures for classification as dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog; notice; hearing. (a) As applied to the owners of potentially dangerous dogs, the procedures provided for in this section must be carried out as a necessary condition for the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter against such owners. As applied to the owners of dangerous dogs, the procedures provided for in this section shall not be an essential element of any crime provided for in this chapter. (b) When a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog is classified as such, the dog control officer shall notify the dog's owner of such classification. (c) The notice to the owner shall meet the following requirements: (1) The notice shall be in writing and mailed by certified mail to the owner's last known address or hand delivered to the owner by the animal control officer or a city police officer. (2) The notice shall include a summary of the dog control officer's findings that formed the basis for the dog's classification as a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog. (3) The notice shall be dated and shall state that the owner, within 15 days after the date shown on the notice, has a right to request a hearing on the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog. (4) The notice shall state that the hearing, if requested, shall be before the municipal court. (5) The notice shall state that if a hearing is not requested, the dog control officer's determination that the dog is a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog will become effective for all purposes under this chapter on a date specified in the notice, which shall be after the last day on which the owner has a right to request a hearing. (6) The notice shall include a form to request a hearing before the municipal court and shall provide specific instructions on mailing or delivering such request to the court. (d) When the municipal court receives a request for a hearing as provided in subsection (c) of this section, it shall schedule such hearing within 30 days after receiving the request. The court shall notify the dog owner in writing by certified mail of the date, time and place of the hearing, and the notice shall be mailed to the dog owner at least ten days prior to the date of the hearing. At the hearing, the owner of the dog shall be given the opportunity to testify and present evidence. The court shall also receive such other evidence and hear such other testimony as it may find reasonably necessary to make a determination either to sustain, modify or overrule the dog control officer's classification of the dog. (e) Within ten days after the date of the hearing, the court shall notify the dog owner in writing by certified mail of its determination on the matter. If such determination is that the dog is a dangerous dog or a potentially dangerous dog, the notice shall specify the date upon which that determination is effective. (Code 1969, § 4-6.2; Ord. No. 10-1998, § III, 3-9-98) Sec. 14-10. - Requirements for possessing dangerous or potentially dangerous dog. (a) It is unlawful for an owner to have or possess within this state and the city a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog without a certificate of registration issued in accordance with the provisions of this section. This certificate shall be in addition to any standard dog license and fees or other requirements of this chapter (see section 14-7). (b) Subject to the additional requirements of subsection (c) of this section for dangerous dogs, the dog control officer shall issue a certificate of registration to the owner of such dog if the owner presents to the dog control officer or the dog control officer otherwise finds sufficient evidence of: (1) A proper enclosure to confine the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog; and (2) The posting of the premises where the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is located with a clearly visible sign warning that there is a dangerous dog on the property. This sign shall be as designed by the department of natural resources and shall be posted in a conspicuous place so that it may be seen by the general public. (c) In addition to the requirements of subsection (b) of this section, the owner of a dangerous dog shall present to the dog control officer evidence of: (1) A policy of insurance in the amount of at least $250,000.00 issued by an insurer authorized to transact business in this state insuring the owner of the dangerous dog against liability for any personal injuries inflicted by the dangerous dog; or (2) A surety bond in the amount of $250,000.00 or more issued by a surety company authorized to transact business in this state payable to any person injured by the dangerous dog. (d) The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer within 24 hours if the dog is on the loose, is unconfined, has attacked a human, has died or has been sold or donated. If the dog has been sold or donated, the owner shall also provide the dog control officer with the name, address and telephone number of the new owner of the dog. (e) The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog shall notify the dog control officer if the owner is moving from the city. The owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog who moves from this city to another jurisdiction within the state shall register the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog in the new jurisdiction within ten days after becoming a resident. (f) Issuance of a certificate of registration or the renewal of a certificate of registration by the city does not warrant or guarantee that the requirements specified in subsections (b) and (c) of this section are maintained by the owner of a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog on a continuous basis following the date of the issuance of the initial certificate of registration or following the date of any annual renewal of such certificate. (g) A dog control officer is authorized to make whatever inquiry is deemed necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this chapter. (h) The city does hereby levy and charge against the owner of any dangerous dog for the purpose of registration pursuant to this section, and in addition to any other license fees required generally for dogs within the city, the sum set forth in the schedule of fees and charges as a fee to register the dog as a dangerous dog pursuant to the ordinances of the city. All certificates of registration shall be renewed on an annual basis. At the time of any renewal, the animal control officer shall require evidence from the owner or make such investigation as may be necessary to verify that the dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog is continuing to be confined in a proper enclosure and that the owner is continuing to comply with all of the provisions of this Code which might apply to this situation. (Code 1969, § 4-6.3) Sec. 14-11. - Restrictions on permitting dangerous or potentially dangerous dogs to be outside proper enclosure. (a) It is unlawful for an owner of a dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is muzzled and restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is under the physical restraint of a responsible person. The muzzle shall be made in a manner that will not cause injury to the dog or interfere with its vision or respiration but will prevent it from biting any person. (b) It is unlawful for the owner of a potentially dangerous dog to permit the dog to be outside a proper enclosure unless the dog is restrained by a substantial chain or leash and is under the restraint of a responsible person. (Code 1969, § 4-6.4) Sec. 14-12. - Confiscation of dogs; grounds, disposition. (a) A dangerous dog shall be immediately confiscated by the dog control officer or by a law enforcement officer or by another person authorized by the dog control officer if the: (1) Owner of the dog does not secure the liability insurance or bond required by section 14-10(c). (2) Dog is not validly licensed as required by section 14-7. (3) Dog is not maintained in a proper enclosure. (4) Dog is outside a proper enclosure in violation of section 14-11(a). (b) A potentially dangerous dog shall be confiscated in the same manner as a dangerous dog if the dog is: (1) Not validly licensed as required by section 14-7. (2) Not maintained in a proper enclosure. (3) Outside a proper enclosure in violation of section 14-11(b). (c) Any dog that has been confiscated under the provisions of subsection (a) or (b) of this section shall be returned to its owner upon the owner's compliance with the provisions of this chapter and upon the payment of reasonable confiscation costs. If the owner has not complied with the provisions of this chapter within 20 days of the date the dog was confiscated, the dog shall be destroyed in an expeditious and humane manner. (Code 1969, § 4-6.5) Sec. 14-13. - Vaccination of dogs. All owners of dogs within the corporate limits of the city shall have said dogs properly vaccinated with anti-rabies vaccine by a licensed veterinarian. Any dog owner who fails to comply with the requirements of this Code section shall be punished as provided in section 1-13 of this Code. (Code 1969, § 4-7; Ord. No. 10-1998, § IV, 3-9-98) Sec. 14-14. - Suspected rabies cases. (a) If a dog is believed to have rabies, or has been bitten by a dog believed to have rabies, such dog shall be confined by a leash or chain on the owner's premises and shall be placed under the observation of a veterinarian at the expense of the owner for a period of two weeks. The owner shall notify the poundkeeper of the fact that his dog has been exposed to rabies, and the poundkeeper shall have discretion to have the dog removed from the owner's premises to a veterinary hospital and placed under observation for a period of two weeks at the expense of the owner. (b) It shall be unlawful for any person knowing or suspecting a dog to have rabies to allow such dog to be taken off his premises or beyond the limits of the city without the written permission of the poundkeeper. (c) Whenever a dog is ascertained to be rabid, the poundkeeper shall be notified and he shall cause such dog to be removed to the city pound or summarily destroyed. (Code 1969, § 4-8) Sec. 14-15. - Biting dogs; exemptions from dangerous dog classification. (a) Whenever any dog bites a person, the owner of the dog shall immediately notify the poundkeeper who shall order the dog held on the owner's premises or shall have it impounded at the owner's expense for a period of two weeks. The dog shall be examined immediately after it has bitten anyone and again at the end of the two-week period. If at the end of the two weeks a veterinarian is convinced that the dog is then free from rabies, the dog shall be released from quarantine or from the pound as the case may be. If the dog should die in the interim, its body shall be sent to the poundkeeper or a veterinarian for examination for rabies. (b) A dog shall not be a dangerous dog or potentially dangerous dog within the meaning of this chapter if it inflicts an injury upon a person when the dog is being used by a law enforcement officer to carry out his official duties. A dog shall not be a dangerous or potentially dangerous dog within the meaning of this chapter if it inflicts injury upon a person who at the time: (1) Was committing or attempting to commit a willful trespass or other tort. (2) Was committing or attempting to commit a crime. (3) Was tormenting, abusing or assaulting the dog. (4) Had in the past been observed or reported to have tormented, abused or assaulted the dog. (Code 1969, § 4-9) Sec. 14-16. - Muzzling ordered by proclamation. Whenever it becomes necessary to safeguard the public from the dangers of hydrophobia, the chairman of the city commission has discretion to issue a proclamation ordering every person owning or keeping a dog to confine it securely on his premises unless such dog shall have a muzzle of sufficient strength to prevent its biting any person. Any unmuzzled dog running at large during the time of the proclamation shall be seized and impounded in the manner provided in section 14-18, unless such dog shall be noticeably infected with rabies, in which case it shall be summarily disposed of. (Code 1969, § 4-10) Sec. 14-17. - Impoundment facility. The city is hereby authorized, by and through its duly elected officials, to enter into a private contract for the impoundment, disposition and control of animals under the provisions contained in this chapter. Further, the chief of police may authorize the poundkeeper to participate in the enforcement of this chapter. (Code 1969, § 4-11) Sec. 14-18. - Impoundment of animals running at large. (a) Authority; records. It shall be the duty of every police officer or the poundkeeper to seize all animals running at large in violation of the provisions of this chapter and to impound such animals in the city pound or other suitable place. Upon receiving any such animal, the city poundkeeper shall enter upon the records of the pound, in a book to be kept by him for such purpose, the date of impounding, a description of the animal impounded and a record as to whether or not such animal has been licensed and tagged. (b) Notice. Not later than two days after the impounding of any animal under the provisions of this chapter, if the animal has been licensed and tagged, the poundkeeper or other city official shall attempt to notify the owner thereof. Any animal so licensed and tagged shall be kept, before disposition, pursuant to the provisions of subsection (d) of this section. In addition to an attempt to notify the owner, written notice shall be posted for at least three days in a conspicuous place at the police department's location in the city. This notice shall describe the animal, indicate the place and time of taking and if the dog is licensed, and indicate the registration name of the owner. (c) Redemption of animals. The owner of any animal impounded by the city poundkeeper may redeem the animal by paying all the costs, charges and penalties assessed that have accrued up to the time of making the redemption. When the costs and other fees are paid to the designated officer of the city, the city shall give the owner a release slip to be taken to the city poundkeeper who shall immediately release the animal from the pound and deliver it to the owner thereof. (d) Disposition of animals. (1) Unclaimed animals. If, after four days from the date of posting the first notice as provided in subsection (a) of this section, an animal impounded under this section, which is not licensed and tagged as provided by this chapter, has not been redeemed by the owner or some other person, such animal may be disposed of in a humane manner. If, after 14 days, an animal licensed and tagged under this chapter has not been redeemed, either by the owner or some other person, then such licensed animal may be disposed of in a humane manner. (2) Infected animals. Any animal which appears to be suffering from rabies, hydrophobia, mange or any other infectious or dangerous disease shall not be released, but may be destroyed as soon as such infection or disease is discovered, after the poundkeeper has received the opinion of a licensed veterinarian that it would be in the best interest of the public health and welfare to destroy the animal. Otherwise, the animal shall be kept until in the opinion of a licensed veterinarian it may be released to the owner. (Code 1969, § 4-12) Sec. 14-19. - Confinement of female in heat. Every female dog in heat shall be confined in a building or other enclosure in such a manner, that such female dog cannot come in contact with another animal, except for planned breeding purposes. (Ord. No. 11-2002, § 1, 5-13-02) Sec. 14-20. - Cruelty to animals; generally. It shall be unlawful for any owner, person or harborer of a domestic animal to do the following acts, omissions and/or engage in these types of unlawful activities: (1) Willfully or maliciously kill, abuse, mame, or disfigure any animal. (2) Willfully or maliciously administer poison to any animal or expose any poisonous substance to an animal with the intent that this substance shall be taken and/or ingested by such animal. (3) Willfully or maliciously torturing, tormenting, or depriving any animal or necessary sustenance or shelter. (4) Willfully or maliciously carrying in or upon any vehicle, any animal in a cruel or inhumane manner. (Ord. No. 11-2002, § 1, 5-13-02) Sec. 14-21. - Responsible animal care. It shall be unlawful for any owner, person, or harborer of a domestic animal not to provide for the animal: (1) Sufficient quantity and quality of good and wholesome food and water; (2) Proper protection and shelter from the weather; (3) Veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering; (4) Humane treatment; and (5) Prompt removal and sanitary disposal of all excreta deposited by the animal. (Ord. No. 11-2002, § 1, 5-13-02) Sec. 14-22. - Slaughtering prohibited. No person shall slaughter any animal at any residence or other location within the corporate limits of the city. This prohibition shall include the indiscriminate killing and slaughtering of animals, the killing of animals for the purpose of cooking same, ritualistic or symbolic slaughtering activities, or any other activities whatsoever. This prohibition shall not apply to duly licensed commercial and/or industrial manufacturing operations within the city. (Code 1969, §§ 11-100, 11-101; Ord. No. 9-1996, § I, 8-12-96) State Law reference— Sale of dog meat for human consumption prohibited, O.C.G.A. § 26-2-160. Sec. 14-23. - Livestock, swine, poultry raising prohibited; exceptions. (a) On and after September 9, 1996, no person may raise, keep or otherwise engage in any practice of maintaining, in a fence, pen, barn or other type of enclosure, any cattle, pigs, poultry, domestic animals, wildlife or any other type of creatures being raised as a part of any type of residential, commercial and/or industrial farming, agricultural or other similar types of operation whatsoever. The keeping of any type of animal, as defined in section 14-1, for any agricultural, commercial and/or industrial business or processing shall be unlawful within the corporate limits of the city. (b) In addition to the prohibition set forth in subsection (a) of this section, it shall be unlawful for any resident or any person within the corporate limits of the city to maintain any type of livestock, goats, pigs, cattle or similar animals for the purpose of raising these animals to slaughter, as a potential food source or for any and all similar type purposes. (c) This section shall have no effect upon bona fide agricultural operations within the corporate limits of the city as they presently exist, where cattle, livestock or other similar operations are being carried on within the corporate limits. However, should the owner, lessee or any other party in control of the property hereafter eliminate the use of the property for any such operations as is generally prohibited by this section, then these operations may not again commence upon the property. (Ord. No. 13-1996, § 1(4-17), 9-9-96) Sec. 14-24. - Animals prohibited in Northwest Park. It shall be unlawful and a violation of this Code section for any person to have or bring any animal into Northwest Park, whether or not such animal is running at large or under the owner's restraint or control. The city manager, animal control officers, and any other city agent or employee authorized to enforce the provisions of this chapter may place signs throughout the park to inform citizens of the prohibitions of this section. (Ord. No. 6-1999, § 1, 5-18-99) Sec. 14-25. - Keeping domestic animals under control. (a) It shall be unlawful for any owner of a domestic animal not to control the animal at all times through one of the following means: (1) On a leash when off the property of the owner; (2) Within the passenger area of a vehicle driven or parked on the streets; (3) Within the property limits of its owner and attended by its owner; or (4) Confined within the property limits of its owner or of another with the permission of the person in control of the property. Confined means in a building, pen or fenced area or other structure built to prevent intrusion or escape by any dog. (b) It shall be unlawful for any owner of a domestic animal to chain, tie, fasten or otherwise tether the animal to dog houses, trees, fences, vehicles or other stationary objects as a means of confinement except that the animal may be temporarily confined by a tether while attended by its owner. (c) Exemptions. Feral cat colony caretakers are exempt from the requirements of this section. ( Ord. No. 1-2017 , 1-9-17) Sec. 14-26. - Specific requirements for confinement. It shall be an offense for any owner of a domestic animal not to satisfy the following requirements: (1) Any tether used to temporarily confine an animal while attended by its owner must be attached to a collar or harness and shall not be wrapped directly around the animal's neck. Such tethers shall not be excessively heavy or weighted so as to inhibit the animal's movement. (2) All domestic animals shall be provided with sanitary shelter from the elements. Said shelter shall be designed, constructed and maintained to protect the animal from rain, snow, ice, excessive cold, excessive heat and excessive direct sunlight, and of a size to allow the animal sufficient space to stand, turn around, and lie down, and make all other normal body movements in a normal and comfortable position appropriate to the age, size, and health of the animal. Examples of inadequate shelter include, but are not limited to, lean-tos, metal or plastic drums, boxes, vehicles, or the area on or beneath exposed porches or decks. Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to prevent the transportation and temporary confinement of a domestic animal within the passenger area of a vehicle provided that the animal is provided adequate ventilation and temperature control in order to protect the animal from excessive heat or cold. (3) All domestic animals shall be provided with clean, potable water at all times. (4) An owner must promptly remove and dispose of animal excrement and food waste and debris so as to minimize vermin infestation, contamination, odors, and disease hazards. (e) All domestic animals shall be provided with a safe and sanitary confinement area constructed to confine the animal, to protect the animal from injury, and of a sufficient space to allow for adequate exercise suitable to the age, size, species, and breed of animal. The area shall have a means to rapidly eliminate excess water and minimize mud. (f) Exemptions. Feral cat colony caretakers are exempt from the requirements of this section. ( Ord. No. 1-2017 , 1-9-17) Sec. 14-27. - Prohibitions for domestic animals. It shall be unlawful for any person to permit a domestic animal under his or her ownership or possession to do the following: (1) Go upon the property of any person other than its owner or keeper without the express consent of such other owner or occupant. (2) Attack or act so as to menace pedestrians or other persons using public ways or on the property of another. Pending an adjudication for any citation for a violation of this subparagraph (2), the person cited shall be required to maintain the dog in a proper enclosure, as defined in this chapter. Any person convicted of violating this subsection, in addition to penalties provided for in section 1-13 and appendix C, shall be required to maintain the dog in a proper enclosure, as defined in this chapter. (3) Disturb the peace of any other person by loud, persistent, habitual barking, howling, growling, yelping or whining. No person shall be charged with violating this subsection unless written warning has previously been issued within 90 days of the charged violation. No citation for violation of this subsection shall be issued unless there are at least two complaining witnesses who shall have signed a written statement stating the address of the dog owner, a description of the dog and of the offense and the date, time and location of the offense. (4) Reserved. (5) Be in heat and not be confined in an enclosure to the property of its owner or keeper. (6) Exemptions. Feral cat colony caretakers are exempt from the requirements of this section. ( Ord. No. 1-2017 , 1-9-17)

div.head: Chapter 18 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Environment, ch. 38; fire prevention and protection, ch. 42; floods, ch. 46; health and sanitation, ch. 50; historical preservation, ch. 54; solid waste, ch. 66; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70; utilities, ch. 82; vegetation, ch. 86; zoning, ch. 94. State Law reference— Authority of city or county to provide codes, including building, housing, plumbing and electrical codes, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3(12); state-wide application of minimum standard codes, codes requiring adoption by municipality or county, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25; enforcement of codes, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-26; providing of fire escapes by building owners, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-50; access to and use of public facilities by physically handicapped persons, O.C.G.A. § 30-3-1 et seq.; authority to repair, close or demolish unfit buildings or structures, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-7; county or municipal ordinances relating to unfit buildings or structures, O.C.G.A. § 41-2-9.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 18-1. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 12,2006, § 1, adopted Oct. 9, 2006, deleted § 18-1, which pertained to moratorium on new construction, modification or additions to existing billboards, signs, etc. and derived from Ord. No. 2402001, §§ 3, 4, adopted Jan. 14, 2002. Similar provisions can be found in ch. 94, art. IX, titled Signs, enacted by Ord. No. 22-2002, §§ 1, 2, adopted Dec. 9, 2002. Secs. 18-2—18-35. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - CONSTRUCTION CODES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Charter reference— Codes, § 3.18.
Sec. 18-36. - Technical building and construction codes adopted. The following technical building and construction codes are adopted by reference as the Georgia State Minimum Codes in their most current version and as may be amended from time to time in later editions, as required by the Georgia Uniform Codes Act, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-25: (1) International Building Code. (2) International Fuel Gas Code. (3) International Mechanical Code. (4) International Plumbing Code. (5) National Electrical Code. (6) International Fire Code.
