(7) International Energy Conservation Code. (8) International Residential Code. (9) International Property Maintenance Code. (10) International Existing Building Code. Said codes are adopted and shall be enforced in addition to other powers the city may have elsewhere in this Code. It is the intent and purpose of this section to adopt the most current versions of these codes under state law and to provide for the automatic adoption of any amendments or revisions to these codes without the necessity of adopting a new ordinance any time there are such revisions or amendments to these codes. (Code 1969, §§ 5-1, 5-6, 5-16, 5-36, 5-48, 5-64, 12-1; Ord. No. 2-1995, 1-9-95; Ord. No. 3-1995, 1-9-95; Ord. No. 4-1995, 1-9-95; Ord. No. 5-1995, 1-9-95; Ord. No. 6-1995, 1-9-95; Ord. No. 19,2006, § 1, 12-11-06) Sec. 18-37. - Enforcement official. The term "building official" as used in the adopted codes shall mean the building inspector, or any other officer of the city designated by the city commission, having the authority to enforce the building regulations of the city. (Code 1969, § 5-3) Sec. 18-38. - Penalty. Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this article, and any occupant or owner of premises who shall refuse to allow or prevent or interfere with the building inspector in the discharge of his duties under this article, shall be guilty of an offense, and upon conviction shall be punished as provided in section 1-13. (Code 1969, § 5-50) Sec. 18-39. - Permits to be applied for in advance. All building permits shall be applied for at least 48 hours in advance of the intended construction. The building official shall have such time as reasonably necessary to act upon any such application. (Code 1969, § 5-4) Sec. 18-40. - Permit fees. On all buildings, structures or alterations requiring a building permit as set forth in this chapter, a fee for such building permit shall be paid as required at the time of filing the application in accordance with and in the amount set forth or recommended in the edition of the Standard Building Code and such other pertinent construction codes adopted by the city and in force at that time. (Code 1969, § 5-5) Sec. 18-41. - Requirements for installation, maintenance of grease traps by food handlers. (a) Any person serving prepared food for retail sale (within the city limits and those outside the city limits using city sewage) are hereby required to install and maintain a grease trap apparatus designed to catch and prevent grease and oils from being deposited into the city sewage system. Such handlers of food are hereby required to maintain the equipment in good working condition and to clean the equipment on a regular basis, taking into consideration the extent and amount of greases and oils used and discarded in their business. (b) The building inspector for the city shall periodically inspect the premises and equipment and maintain such records as necessary so as to enforce the provisions of subsection (a) of this section. If the building inspector finds that a handler of food has failed to adequately maintain such equipment, the building inspector shall notify such person and give the establishment a reasonable time in which to remedy the same. (c) If any person is found guilty of failing to install and/or maintain a grease trap as provided in this section after reasonable notice from the building inspector and an opportunity to be heard before the judge of the municipal court, such person may be punished for such violation according to section 1-13. (Code 1969, § 5-16.2) Secs. 18-42—18-49. - Reserved. Sec. 18-50. - Inspection of vacant buildings. Any structure which has been vacant or has not had electrical power or other utilities for more than six consecutive months must be fully inspected and approved by the city building inspector or his designee before the issuance of any building permits or the resumption or restoration of electrical service or other utilities. (Ord. No. 12-2011, § 1, 7-11-11) Secs. 18-51—18-65. - Resesrved. ARTICLE III. - FLOW RATE RESTRICTIONS ON PLUMBING FIXTURES[3]
Footnotes: --- (3) --- State Law reference— Flow rate restrictions on plumbing fixtures, O.C.G.A. § 8-2-3.
Sec. 18-66. - Requirements for water-saving facilities; toilets, shower heads, urinals and faucets. (a) As used in this section, the term "construction" means erection of a new building or the alteration of an existing building in connection with its repair or renovation or in connection with making an addition to an existing building, and shall include the replacement of a malfunctioning, unserviceable or obsolete faucet, showerhead, toilet or urinal in an existing building. The term "commercial" means any type of building other than residential. The term "residential" means any building or unit of building intended for occupancy as a dwelling, but shall not include a hotel or motel. (b) No construction may be initiated within the city of any residential building of any type which: (1) Employs a gravity tank-type, flushometer-valve, or flushometer-tank toilet that uses more than an average of 1.6 gallons of water per flush; provided, however, this subsection shall not be applicable to one-piece toilets until July 1, 1992. (2) Employs a shower head or faucet that allows a flow of more than an average of 2.5 gallons per minute at 60 pounds per square inch of pressure. (3) Employs a urinal that uses more than an average of one gallon of water per flush. (4) Employs a lavatory faucet or lavatory replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than two gallons of water per minute. (5) Employs a kitchen faucet or kitchen replacement aerator that allows a flow of more than 2.5 gallons of water per minute. (c) Exemptions. New construction and the repair or renovation of an existing building shall be exempt from the requirements of subsection (b) under the following conditions: (1) When the repair or renovation of an existing building does not include the replacement of plumbing or sewage systems servicing toilets, faucets, urinals or shower heads within such existing building. (2) When such plumbing or sewage system within such existing building, because of its capacity, design or installation, would not function properly if the toilets, faucets, urinals or shower heads required by this Code were installed. (3) When such system is a well or gravity flow from a spring and is owned privately by an individual for use in such individual personal residence. (4) When units to be installed are: a. Specifically designed for use by the handicapped; b. Specifically designed to withstand unusual abuse or installation in a penal institution; or c. Toilets for juveniles. (d) The owner, or his agent, of a building undergoing new construction or repair or renovation who is entitled to an exemption as specified herein shall obtain the exemption by applying at the office of the building inspector for the city. A fee as set out in appendix C to this Code shall be charged for the inspection and issuance of such exemption. (e) This section shall be enforced by the building inspector of the city. Violations may be issued by the chief building inspector of the city. (f) Any person violating this section shall be subject to penalty as provided in section 1-13. (Code 1969, § 5-16.1) Secs. 18-67—18-85. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - PLANNING COMMISSION[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- Cross reference— Boards, authorities and commissions, § 2-56 et seq.; zoning, ch. 94; planning commission established, powers and duties, etc., § 94-201 et seq.
Sec. 18-86. - Jurisdiction. The planning commission, through the zoning chapter of the city and through other ordinances and laws that might establish procedures for hearings, shall be the appropriate body to hear appeals from decisions made in the enforcement of the zoning chapter, or any other ordinance from which an appeal is taken alleging an error in any order, requirement, decision or determination made by the building inspector. This shall include any appeal from alleged failures of any party to comply with any of the standard codes adopted by the city pursuant to this chapter. Further, if there should be any dispute or controversy which could be construed as an appeal from any decision of a city official affecting buildings, construction or other general matters pertaining thereto, all such appeals shall be within the jurisdiction of, and be decided by, the planning commission. (Code 1969, § 5-75) Sec. 18-87. - Procedures for appeals. Appeals taken by any person aggrieved or by any officer, department, board or bureau of the city affected by any decision of the building inspector, or other city officials authorized to administer any of the codes set out in section 18-236, shall be made to the planning commission under the same terms, conditions and procedures as set out for appeals under the zoning chapter of the city. (Code 1969, § 5-76) Sec. 18-88. - Effect of article on construction codes and other conflicting provisions. Any and all provisions of any of the construction codes mentioned in section 18-87 establishing boards to hear appeals are hereby repealed and any and all other ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this article are also repealed. (Code 1969, § 5-77) Sec. 18-89. - Variance expiration. Any variance, ruling or other decision granted by the planning commission which requires the performance of any construction or is based upon an applicant's desire to perform any work, building or other construction within the city shall be started by the issuance of a building permit to the applicant within not more than 120 days from the date of the granting of such variance. Failure of the applicant or other party to comply with the conditions of the variance granted by the planning commission or to otherwise obtain a building permit and commence the construction of the improvements which is the subject matter of the variance within the aforesaid time limitation shall cause the variance to terminate. Failure to so comply shall require the applicant to reapply for a variance with the planning commission; provided, however, that regardless of the prior decision on the application or grant of variance, all new considerations upon a reapplication for a variance shall be based upon the evidence, circumstances and matters then existing and shall not be governed by the former decision of the planning commission. (Code 1969, § 5-78) Secs. 18-90—18-110. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - MOVABLE HOUSING
Sec. 18-111. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Building permit means the written document authorizing the construction of works of improvements, alterations or other construction activities concerning any movable housing, as defined in this section, within the city. Movable housing means any house, dwelling, building or other structure (not a manufactured home as defined in O.C.G.A. § 8-2-131(3)) which has been extracted from its foundation or other permanent location by means of dollies, jacks or other devices so as to be made portable, movable or otherwise subject to being transported or hauled; when in fact the structure was not constructed or designed for that purpose. Moving permit means that written document required to authorize the moving, transportation or relocation of any movable housing either within or without the corporate limits of the city. (Code 1969, § 5-86) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 18-112. - Regulations, restrictions for use of public streets. (a) No person shall use the streets within the corporate city limits of the city to move, transport or relocate any house, dwelling, building or other structure of a width more than 12 feet at its widest point, or a length of more than 60 feet at its longest point, or a height of 14 feet at its highest point without first obtaining a permit from the building inspector, or his designated agent (hereafter referred to as the issuer). (b) No structure shall be moved upon any street within the city limits between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 9:30 a.m., 11:30 a.m. and 1:30 p.m., and 3:30 p.m. and 6:00 p.m. No movement shall be made between sunset and sunrise unless special permission is granted by the city commission. Movement times may also be changed by issuer or permit when special situations exist. (c) The application for the permit shall designate: (1) The type of load to be moved. (2) The exact route and streets to be used. (3) The time of day or night that the moving shall take place. (4) The fact that Southern Bell Telephone, Georgia Power Company, Falcon Cable TV Company and any and all other public utilities whose facilities may be affected, have been notified. (5) Such other matters as the issuer deems proper. The terms of the permit shall be strictly adhered to by the mover; no deviation therefrom shall be permitted without the express written permission of the issuer. (d) Application for a permit must be made at least 15 days prior to the proposed moving, at which time the issuer shall notify the chief of police, who shall furnish, at the time of moving, such necessary police escort to the mover as the police chief deems necessary to ensure the safety of the public. (e) A sign evidencing that a structure is to be removed or located, as the case may be, upon any real property within the city shall be placed upon the property at least 15 days prior to the proposed removal or relocation. This sign shall comport with the general size requirements of signs evidencing a proposed change of property zoning within the city. (f) The fee for such moving permit shall be as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges. In addition thereto, the movers shall deposit with the issuing authority of the city an amount as set forth in the schedule of fees and charges for each such movable housing structure to be transported either within or without the city, as a bond for damages to public property. This sum shall be returned to the mover within 15 days after such moving if no damage is done to public property. In case of such damage, the amount of the refund will be the total deposit less actual damages, including repair, replacement, labor and incidental expenses. If damage costs exceed the deposit, the mover shall be liable to the city for all additional expenses. (Code 1969, § 5-87) Sec. 18-113. - Restrictions on transportation. (a) When any part of movement is on a state route, the provisions of this section are in addition to those required by the state for its permit. No city permit shall be issued under this article in such cases unless the mover has first obtained a state permit for such movement. (b) In no event shall permission be granted to remove into or within the city any building which any government or governmental agency has found unfit for human habitation or use or which has been constructed of defective materials, or which has become defective from age, fire, abuse or other cause. When any doubt exists, the building inspector shall make a complete inspection for such faults. (c) When movement is on streets with overhead signals, cables, wires or other devices, the mover shall take such precautions as are necessary to guide and handle the wires and/or devices and to prevent damage thereto. (d) The issuer of the permit may contact the city fire chief as soon as the permit is issued. Changes in the predetermined route may be made at the discretion of the fire chief. (e) All extreme points on the structure being moved shall be visibly marked with flags or lights or both. If movement at night is permitted, lights shall be required. (Code 1969, § 5-88) Sec. 18-114. - Building permits required; fees. (a) Building permit fees in addition to the moving permit shall be as prescribed in the business license section of the city as provided in this Code. (b) No permit as required by the building code shall be issued until the prescribed fee has been paid, nor shall an amendment to a permit be approved until the additional fee, if any, due to an increase in the estimated cost of the building or structure has been paid. (c) Where work for which a permit is required by this Code is started or proceeded with prior to obtaining the permit, the fees specified shall be doubled, but the payment of such double fee shall not relieve any person from fully complying with the requirements of this Code in the execution of the work nor from any other penalties prescribed in this article. (Code 1969, § 5-89) Sec. 18-115. - Standards for review of issuance of permit. The building inspector of the city is charged with the authority for the enforcement of this article. As such, in determining whether to issue a moving permit, he shall use the following criteria: (1) No permit for movable housing shall be issued until notice of an application for a permit, to be made on forms approved by the city, has been given to the owners of all adjoining property upon which the building or structure is to be moved. Each adjoining property owner, including those adjacent to the property and across the street directly therefrom, shall be allowed to be heard before the building inspector before the granting of a permit occurs. (2) Whether the proposed housing can be properly brought to the level of minimum standard requirements contained in the building code of the city, and as generally required pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 8-2-1 et seq. The aforesaid provisions of state law generally deal with the construction or alteration of buildings. Those sections of this Code or state law applicable to movable housing shall be used as criteria for determining the feasibility of issuing a permit to the applicant. (3) Whether the structure, when complete, will have a fair market value which is not less than 80 percent of the assessed fair market value of adjoining comparable properties, for tax purposes, in the general vicinity and neighborhood within the city where this structure is to be located. The purpose of this provision is to ensure that the structure's presence in the area will not diminish property values. (4) Whether the structure can safely and properly, using reasonable construction standards and those contained in this Code, be properly placed upon the property, constructed, repaired and maintained as a residential dwelling unit fit and safe for occupancy by the general public. (5) Whether the placing of a movable housing structure, together with all work or other construction to be accomplished in the vicinity of the property will create a health, safety or public hazard or nuisances within the corporate limits of the city. In determining whether the conditions could constitute a nuisance, the building inspector shall consider the criteria contained in section 38-61. (6) Whether the applicant has, within five years before the date of the application, had a building permit revoked, failed to comply with code standards and requirements of the building inspector or otherwise been cited for significant violations of the building codes and ordinances of the city. (Code 1969, § 5-90) Sec. 18-116. - Permit not transferable, subject to denial, revocation, suspension or amendment. (a) A permit, once issued, may not be transferred from one person to another, or from one licensed location for the moving of a structure contemplated by this article to another location, without the express written consent of the building inspector having been first obtained. (b) The building inspector shall have full power and authority to deny, revoke, refuse to grant, suspend or amend, as might be needed, any moving permit to be granted under this article. (c) Since the criteria and establishment of this permit also requires later enforcement and compliance with this article, this permit and the accompanying building permit shall be subject to revocation for cause. (d) Before taking any action adverse to an applicant or permit holder, the building inspector shall conduct a hearing at which all interested parties may be heard concerning the grant, renewal, refusal or suspension of any license privileges granted under this article. Appeal of any decision of the building inspector shall be to the city commission. (Code 1969, § 5-91) Sec. 18-117. - Hearing. Upon written application within 30 days of the decision of the building inspector, any applicant or other party aggrieved by any decision pursuant to this article shall be afforded an opportunity for a hearing before the city commission. At that time the aggrieved party shall be allowed to present evidence, cross examine opposing witnesses, or present any and all documentation concerning the application or decision. Failure to make timely appeal of the decision within the time period shall cause the decision to become final and unappealable. The hearing shall be conducted within 30 days from the date of a timely application and the final decision of the city commission in this regard shall be accomplished in writing and communicated to the aggrieved party. The review before the city commission shall be conducted pursuant to the criteria contained in this article for review by the building inspector, and shall be considered a de novo consideration of the decision. (Code 1969, § 5-92) Sec. 18-118. - Penalty. Any person found in violation of any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to punishment as contained in section 1-13. (Code 1969, § 5-93)

div.head: Chapter 22 - BUSINESSES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; health and sanitation, ch. 50; solid waste, ch. 66; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70; taxation, ch. 74; utilities, ch. 82; vehicles for hire, ch. 90; zoning, ch. 94.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 22-1. - Tent shows, carnivals; special permit required. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or conduct a tent show or carnival within the city limits except upon special permission of the city commission. (Code 1969, § 13-21) State Law reference— Traveling motion picture shows, carnivals and circuses to obtain fire prevention regulatory license from state fire marshal, O.C.G.A. § 25-2-20. Sec. 22-2. - Business user fees for municipal facilities and services. The city manager, with the approval of the city commission, shall have the authority to establish fees, charges or rents as may be determined necessary and proper for the use of various business-related services, recreational activities or other use of city facilities. These fees are informally known as user fees and are set out in appendix C to this Code. By resolution the city commission shall adopt, promulgate or amend the schedule of fees for use of city facilities, equipment or any other services determined by the city manager to require special fees, costs, charges or assessments. A copy of any resolution adopting such fee schedules shall be open for public inspection during normal business hours of the city. (Code 1969, § 13-27) Sec. 22-3. - Yard, garage, and rummage sales defined; regulations; penalties for violations. (a) Yard, garage or rummage sales are defined as the displaying of wares, clothing, merchandise and goods for the purposes of sale or trade which are placed for sale by any person to the public on which the yard sale is to take place. Multiple yard sales shall be governed by this section and regulated as in subsection (c)(1). (b) No yard, garage, or rummage sales as defined herein shall be conducted without first applying for and obtaining a permit from the City of Cedartown. Any permit issued by the City of Cedartown must be prominently displayed or at least available for inspection by city officials during the sale. The application for such a permit shall, at a minimum, include the following information: (1) The person, firm, or entity who is conducting the sale; (2) The location of the sale; (3) The proposed date and time of the sale; (4) The expected duration of the sale; (5) A general description of the items to be included in the sale; (6) Any other information that the city deems necessary or appropriate in reviewing the application. (c) Yard sales are regulated as follows: (1) Two yard, garage or rummage sales are allowed per year per person and/or location, on a calendar year basis and on residential property only. Yard sales shall consist of not more than two consecutive days. Yard sales may only be held on Friday and Saturday. Evidence of sale must be removed by the following Monday of permitted event. (2) Special exceptions may be considered for local or regional events upon prior written approval by the city manager or his/her designee. (3) Churches and synagogues are allowed to hold yard, rummage or garage sales on church owned and operated property without restrictions to number per year. (4) Any person convicted of violation of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-13 of the City Code. (Code 1969, § 13-28; Ord. No. 18-1998, § 1, 5-11-98; Ord. No. 3-2012, § 1, 4-9-12; Ord. No. 4-2015, § 1, 7-13-15) Sec. 22-4. - No fee for veterans. Veterans of wars who are entitled under the laws of the state to carry on or engage in any trade, business, vocation, calling or profession, without paying any license fee, charge or tax, shall before commencing such trade, business, vocation, calling or profession exhibit his veteran's license or certificate to the city clerk and shall be required to register as required under this chapter and receive from the city through the clerk a no fee veteran's license, and no charge whatever shall be made for such registration or license. The person must be a local resident of the city. (Code 1969, § 13-9) Sec. 22-5. - Farmer selling own products exempt. The legal right of the farmer and producer to sell the products of his own farm, orchard, dairy, poultry yard, etc., is recognized, but any other person in the corporate limits of the city offering for sale such articles as eggs, chickens, butter, milk, fruits, vegetables, coffee, tea, spices, soaps, washing powders or other groceries, or any other articles not specifically covered in the provisions of this chapter relating to occupation taxes as set forth in section 22-21 et seq., shall be deemed a peddler and every such peddler selling directly to the consumer, even though the delivery may be on orders previously taken, shall be required to purchase a peddler's license from the city. No peddler's license is required from any bona fide farmer who is selling the products of his own farm, orchard, dairy, poultry yard, etc. (Code 1969, § 13-10) State Law reference— Establishment of roadside market incentive program, O.C.G.A. § 2-10-130 et seq.; exception for persons selling agricultural products, O.C.G.A. § 43-32-6; exemption from municipal taxation of agricultural products and livestock raised in state, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-356. Sec. 22-6. - Subcontractor's license; responsibility of prime contractor. Any contractor engaged in the construction, alteration or repair of buildings or in the installation of equipment or fixtures in connection with such construction, and who has subcontractors working under him in accordance with a portion of the work, shall be responsible to see that every such subcontractor has a current city license permit before he allows such subcontractor to begin any portion of the subcontracting work. Upon the failure of the general contractor to require each subcontractor to purchase and pay for any current license permit, the general contractor shall be responsible for and be required to pay to the city the amount of any such subcontractor's license tax as set forth in the provisions of this chapter relating to occupation taxes as set forth in section 22-21 et seq. (Code 1969, § 13-11) State Law reference— Electrical contractors, plumbers, conditioned air contractors, low-voltage contractors, and utility contractors, O.C.G.A. § 43-14-1 et seq. Sec. 22-7. - Sidewalk sales and displays regulated. No retail business sales shall be permitted upon any streets, sidewalks, or public alleys within the city except by a permit granted by the city manager permitting such use; except any sales accomplished pursuant to an activity approved by the Downtown Cedartown Association, the city commission or the city manager shall be considered a "permitted use" pursuant to this section. Any person denied the right to conduct such sales shall have the right to appeal the decision of the city manager to the city commission. (Code 1969, § 13-16) Sec. 22-8. - Sale of used motor vehicles upon real property in the city. (a) An owner or lessee of any real property shall not authorize more than five used motor vehicles within any 12 months, to be displayed or parked on such real property; nor more than two used vehicles at the same time to be so displayed or parked, for the purpose of selling or advertising for sale such used motor vehicles by the owner or lessee of such vehicles. (b) An owner or lessee of any used motor vehicle shall not display or park such used motor vehicles on the real property of another for the purpose of selling or advertizing as set forth in this section, in a manner that violates subsection (a). Nor shall any such motor vehicle be placed on the property of another, unless the owner or lessee of such vehicle has the prior permission of the owner or lessee of the real property. (c) These prohibitions concerning the sale of used motor vehicles shall not apply under the following circumstances: (1) If the owner or lessee of the vehicle displayed or parked is employed by the owner or lessee of the real property, and is on the property accomplishing any work, task or other function upon said property, and is not there for the purpose of displaying or parking a motor vehicle upon the property for sale; (2) If the owner or lessee of the vehicle displayed or parked is conducting business with the owner or lessee of the real property; or (3) If the real property on which the vehicle is displayed or parked is a parking lot for which a fee is charged for the use of said parking lot, and the owner or lessee of the vehicle displayed or parked has paid the fee for the use of said parking lot. (d) No owner or lessee of any real property shall authorize any used motor vehicle to be displayed or parked upon the property for purposes of selling or advertising the motor vehicle for sale, if the vehicle is not lawfully titled and registered in the name of the individual or entity offering such vehicle for sale, in accordance with the provisions of Georgia law. (e) No person shall advertise, display, sell, or offer for sale any used motor vehicle unless such vehicle is lawfully titled and registered in such person's name, in accordance with Georgia law. Any law enforcement officer, the building inspector, or other person authorized by Georgia law, or the owner or lessee of any real property upon which a vehicle is displayed or parked in violation of this Code section for longer than 24 consecutive hours, may have any such vehicle towed from the real property and stored at the expense of the owner or lessee of the vehicle. Further, the vehicle may then be disposed of, provided that the disposition is in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. tit. 40, ch. 11, relating the disposition of abandoned motor vehicles. (f) A violation of this Code section shall constitute an unfair or deceptive act or practice and shall likewise be a violation of state law, under the present provisions of O.C.G.A. tit. 10, ch. 1, art. 15, pt. 2 known as the "Fair Business Practices Act of 1975." (g) Any person who violates any provisions of this section shall be deemed to be a licensee for purposes of imposing any sanctions and penalties which might be applicable under Georgia law. Such violations may also carry any sanction or imposition of a penalty as contained in the general penalties section of this Code. (Ord. No. 1-1999, § 2, 3-8-99) Sec. 22-9. - Exemptions to section 22-8. Code section 22-8 shall not apply to any person licensed under state law, or to any franchised motor vehicle dealer, or any subsidiary wholly owned or controlled by such dealer. Further, nothing contained in this Code section shall eliminate or change the requirement for any person to obtain a license under this chapter, if such person engages in any conduct or activity for which a license is required under this Code, and a separate license under any applicable provisions of the laws of the State of Georgia. (Ord. No. 1-1999, § 3, 3-8-99) Sec. 22-10. - Outside storage of new or used tires prohibited. All business within the corporate limits of the city shall be prohibited from storing new or used tires on the exterior of any structure on their property or leaving said tires uncovered so as to permit the accumulation or collection of standing water in the tires, as prohibited by section 50-101 of this Code. It is the purpose and intent of this section to keep the tires from being potential breeding grounds for mosquitoes and other disease carrying insects. Any business owner who violates the provisions of this Code section shall be subject to the general penalties provisions contained in section 1-13 of this Code. (Ord. No. 8-2003, § 2, 10-13-03) Sec. 22-11. - Drug-related objects and drug paraphernalia prohibited. (a) No holder of any license issued under this chapter shall sell, offer for sale, display, lend, rent, lease, give, exchange, keep in stock, possess with intent to sell, or otherwise distribute to any person, at any place of business licensed hereunder any of the following products: (1) Any "drug-related object" as defined by O.C.G.A. § 16-13-32(a)(1), or any instrument, device, or object which is designed or marketed as useful primarily for one or more of the following purposes: a. To inject, ingest, inhale, or otherwise introduce marijuana or a controlled substance into the human body; b. To enhance the effect of marijuana or a controlled substance on the human body; c. To test the strength, effectiveness, or purity of marijuana or a controlled substance; d. To process or prepare marijuana or a controlled substance for introduction into the human body; e. To conceal any quantity of marijuana or a controlled substance; or f. To contain or hold marijuana or a controlled substance while it is being introduced into the human body. (2) Any "drug paraphernalia" which shall include, but not be limited to, objects used or intended for use in ingesting, inhaling, or otherwise introducing marijuana or any controlled substance into the human body, such as: a. Metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic, or ceramic pipes with or without screens, permanent screens, hashish heads, or punctured metal bowls; b. Water pipes; c. Carburetion tubes and devices; d. Smoking and carburetion masks; e. Roach clips, which shall mean any object used to hold burning material, such as, but not limited to, a marijuana cigarette, that has become too small or too short to be held in the hand; f. Miniature cocaine spoons and cocaine vials; g. Chamber pipes; h. Carburetor pipes; i. Electric pipes; j. Air-driven pipes; k. Chillums; l. Bongs; and m. Ice pipes or chillers. (b) In determining whether an item constitutes a drug-related object or drug paraphernalia, in addition to all other logically relevant factors, the city commission may also consider the following factors: (1) Statements by an owner or anyone in control of the object or materials; (2) Instructions provided with the object or materials; (3) Descriptive materials accompanying the object or materials; (4) National and local advertising or promotional materials concerning the object or materials; (5) The appearance of, and any writing or other representations appearing on, the object or materials; (6) The manner in which the object or materials are displayed for sale or other distribution; (7) Expert testimony concerning the object or materials; (8) Any written or pictorial materials which are present in the location where the object or materials may be found; and (9) The existence and scope of legitimate uses of the object or materials in the community. (c) Any holder of a license who violates the provisions of this section shall be subject to the license suspension and/or revocation procedures outlined in this chapter. (Ord. No. 11,2010, § 2, 7-12-10) Secs. 22-12—22-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - OCCUPATION TAXES AND REGULATORY FEES[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Charter reference— Occupation taxes and business license fees, § 6.12.
Sec. 22-21. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Administrative fee means a component of any occupation tax which approximates the reasonable cost of handling and processing the occupation tax. Dominant line means the type of business, within a multiple-line business, from which the greatest amount of income is derived. Employee means an individual whose work is performed under the direction and supervision of the employer and whose employer withholds FICA, federal income tax or state income tax from such individual's compensation or whose employer issues to such individual for purposes of documenting compensation a form I.R.S. W-2, but not a form I.R.S. 1099. Location or office means and includes any structure or vehicle where a business, profession or occupation is conducted, but shall not include a temporary or construction worksite which serves a single customer or project or a vehicle used for sales or delivery by a business or practitioner of a profession or occupation which has a location or office. Occupation tax means a tax levied on persons, partnerships, corporations or other entities for engaging in an occupation, profession or business for revenue raising purposes. Person means and includes sole proprietors, corporations, partnerships, nonprofit associations or any other form of business organization. "Person" shall not include charitable organizations exempt from taxation pursuant to section 22-32. Practitioner of profession or occupation is one who by state law requires state licensure regulating such profession or occupation. "Practitioner of professions and occupations" shall not include a practitioner who is an employee of a business, if the business pays an occupation tax. Regulatory fees means payments, whether designated as license fees, permit fees or by another name, which are required by a local government as an exercise of its police power and as a part of or an aid to regulation of an occupation, profession or business. The amount of a regulatory fee shall approximate the reasonable cost of the actual regulatory activity performed by the city. A regulatory fee may not include an administrative fee. Development impact fees as defined by O.C.G.A. § 36-71-2(8) or other costs or conditions of zoning or land development are not regulatory fees. (Ord. No. 1-1995, § 2, 1-9-95; Ord. No. 18-1995, § 2, 12-11-95) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 22-22. - Tax required for business dealings in the city. For the year 1995 and succeeding years thereafter, each person engaged in any business, trade, profession or occupation in the city, whether with a location in the city; or in the case of an out-of-state business with no location in the state which exerts substantial efforts within the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7, shall pay an occupation tax for such business, trade, profession or occupation. This tax and any applicable registration shall be displayed in a conspicuous location in the place of business, if the taxpayer has a permanent business location in the city. If the taxpayer has no permanent business location in the city, such business tax registration shall be shown to the city clerk, business license clerk or to any police officer of the city upon request. (Ord. No. 1-1995, § 1, 1-9-95) Sec. 22-23. - Purpose and scope of tax. The occupation tax levied in this article is for revenue purposes only and is not for regulatory purposes, nor is the payment of the tax made a condition precedent to the practice of any such profession, trade or calling. The occupation tax only applies to those businesses and occupations which are covered by the provisions of O.C.G.A. §§ 48-13-5 to 48-13-26. All other applicable businesses and occupations are taxed by the local government pursuant to the pertinent general and/or local law and ordinance. (Ord. No. 1-1995, § 10, 1-9-95) Sec. 22-24. - Tax levied; restrictions. (a) An occupation tax shall be levied upon those businesses, practitioners and occupations with one or more locations or offices in the state, corporate limits of the city or upon the applicable out-of-state businesses with no location or office in the state pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-7 based upon the number of employees of the business, trade, profession or occupation. (b) Occupation tax computation: (1) Number of employees. The tax rate determined by the number of employees for each business, trade, profession or occupation is as follows and may be changed, altered or updated from time to time by the city commission:
(2) Full-time or part-time employees. No. 1-1995, § 25, 1-9-95) Sec. 22-45. - Lien taken for delinquent occupation tax. Any person violating any provisions of this article shall, upon conviction before the municipal court, be fined in an amount as contained in section 1-13, subject to the provisions of section 22-31 or other penalty provision in this article. (Ord. No. 1-1995, § 17, 1-9-95) Sec. 22-53. - Penalty; suspension or revocation. (a) Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be punishable as provided in section 1-13 of the Cedartown Code of Ordinances. (Ord. No. 12,2010, § 1, 7-12-10) Sec. 22-54. - Grounds for suspension or revocation. Grounds for the revocation and/or suspension of any business license or occupational tax certificate issued by the city shall include, but not be limited to: (1) Violation of any provision of this chapter; (2) Violation of any provision of the Cedartown Code of Ordinances; (3) Violation of any laws, ordinances, statutes, regulations of the city pertaining to the carrying on of such businesses as would affect the health, safety, welfare, and morals of the public or the city; (4) Violation of a law of the United States or the state which affects the public's health, welfare, safety and morals of the citizens of the city; (5) Fraudulent business practices; (6) A misstatement or misrepresentation of any kind contained in the business application and any supporting documents submitted to the city in connection with a request for a business license and/or occupational tax certificate, or any other documents authorizing the conduct of a business within the city limits of the City of Cedartown; (7) A nuisance caused by the operation of the business. For purposes of this Code section, the term "nuisance" shall be defined pursuant to Georgia statutes and appellate case authority. (Ord. No. 12,2010, § 1, 7-12-10) Sec. 22-55. - Investigation; hearing. (a) Where it is reported to any city official that the holder of a city business license or occupational tax certificate is engaged in any activity which could form a basis for the suspension or revocation of said business license or certificate under this chapter, the building inspector shall conduct a preliminary investigation in order to determine whether there is a basis for such reports. If the building inspector's preliminary investigation reveals that there may be a basis for a revocation or suspension of the license or certificate, the holder will be notified to appear before the city manager for a hearing. (b) If city officials believe that the licensee's alleged violations constitute or otherwise pose an immediate threat to the health, safety, or welfare of any citizen, then the city manager may schedule a preliminary hearing to address these concerns. No suspension or revocation shall take effect until written notice of the alleged violation has been provided to the licensee no less than 48 hours prior to the time of the preliminary hearing. If the evidence before the city manager at such hearing demonstrates an imminent threat or danger to the health, safety, or welfare of any citizen, and further that such violations are likely to continue, then it shall be grounds for an immediate temporary suspension of the license or certificate pending a full administrative hearing on the issue. (c) All administrative hearings with respect to alleged violations of this article and possible suspension or revocation of a business license or occupational tax certificate shall be held no later than ten business days from the date of notice of said violations. If the city manager has held a preliminary hearing as set forth in subsection (b) above, then the administrative hearing shall be no less than ten business days from the date of said preliminary hearing. (d) At the time set for said administrative hearing, the city manager shall receive all relevant testimony and evidence from city personnel, interested parties, and from the licensee. The city manager shall make findings of fact as to whether or not a violation of the Code has occurred and notify the licensee, in writing, of its findings and decision within five business days of the hearing. (e) Upon finding that a violation justifying a suspension or revocation of the license or certificate has occurred, the city manager shall have the authority to take such action as it may deem appropriate with regard to the license or certificate, including, but not limited to, warnings, suspension, revocation, probation, or the imposition of other conditions designed to deter future violations of the Code. (f) Any license holder aggrieved by the decision of the city manager shall have the right to appeal in writing to the city commission within ten (10) days of the date of the manager's decision. The city commission shall review the evidence submitted to the city manager and issue a decision on the appeal within ten days. The decision of the city commission shall be final. (Ord.
