The Main Street opportunity zone shall include: Tax map and parcel numbers: C19-122, C19-123, C19-124, C19-125, C19-126, C19-127, C19-127A, C19-128, C19-128A, C19-129, C19-130, C19-131, C19-132, C20-040, C20-043, C20-043A, C20-043B, C20-043C, C20-044, C20-046, C20-047, C20-048, C20-049, C20-050, C20-051, C20-052, C20-053, C20-054, C20-055, C20-056, C20-057, C20-058, C20-059, C20-060, C20-061, C20-062, C20-075, C20-076, C20-077, C20-078, C20-078A, C20-080, C20-081, C20-082, C20-083, C20-084, C20-085, C20-086, C20-086A, C20-087, C20-088, C20-091, C20-093, C20-094, C20-107, C20-108, C20-109, C20-110, C20-111, C20-114, C20-115, C20-115A, C20-115B, C20-115C, C20-115D, C20-116, C20-117, C20-118, C20-119, C20-120, C20-121, C20-151, C20-152, C20-153, C20-154, C20-155, C20-156, C20-157, C20-158, C20-159, C20-160, C20-161, C20-162, C20-163, C20-163A, C20-164, C20-165, C20-168, C20-169, C20-170, C20-172, C20-193, C20-194, C20-195, C20-196, C20-196A, C20-198, C20-200, C20-226, C20-227, C20-228, C20-229, C20-230, C20-231, C20-232, C20-233, and C20-234. (c) The Gibson Street enterprise and opportunity zones. 1. Gibson Street enterprise zone. The city hereby designates the Gibson Street enterprise zone. This zone meets the qualifications and criteria of the Act due to the existence of the following: a. Pervasive poverty. Within the Gibson enterprise zone area, including all census tracts and block groups as identified by the U.S. Bureau of Census (2000), there are high levels of persons with an income-to-poverty ratio less than 1.0. All of the individual block groups within the census tracts within this corridor suffer from poverty levels above 15 percent% thus qualifying the area as a pervasive poverty area under O.C.G.A. § 36-88-6(b)(2). b. Underdevelopment. The area within the Gibson enterprise zone is severely underdeveloped as compared with other areas of the city. Most of the structures within this area are dilapidated and idle. Such disrepair and inactivity satisfies the criteria of O.C.G.A. § 36-88-6(e). c. General blight. The proposed enterprise zone is within an approved urban redevelopment area thus meeting the criteria of O.C.G.A. § 36-88-6(f) demonstrating blight. d. Legal description. The area to be included in the Gibson Street enterprise zone is specifically described as follows: Beginning at the intersection of the centerline of the Seaboard Railroad and the centerline of Jones Avenue, the boundary runs north along the east right-of-way of Jones Avenue to the rear property line of commercial properties facing Gibson Street; then east along that rear property lien to the centerline of Park Street; then south along the centerline of Park Street to the centerline of Gibson Street; then east along the centerline of Gibson Street to centerline of the Norfolk-Southern Railroad; then south and east along that centerline of that railroad to the centerline of the Seaboard Railroad; and, then north and west along the centerline of the Seaboard Railroad to the beginning at the centerline right-of-way of Jones Avenue. 2. The Gibson Street opportunity zone. The city has determined that a certain area within the Gibson Street enterprise zone further qualifies as an opportunity zone. To further encourage economic revitalization and investment and to qualify this area for additional incentives and tax credits, the city hereby designates the following area within the Gibson Street enterprise zone as the Gibson Street opportunity zone subject to approval by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs and Georgia Department of Revenue: a. Legal description. The following area is best referenced by tax map and parcel number in accordance with the designations of the Polk County Tax Assessor's records. The Gibson Street opportunity zone shall include: Tax map and parcel numbers: C28-041, C28-042, C28-043, C28-044, C28-045, C28-046, C29-001, and C29-002. (d) Southside enterprise zone. In accordance with the amended urban redevelopment plan, the Georgia Enterprise Employmnent Act, O.C.G.A. § 36-88-1 et seq. (hereinafter "the Act"), the Georgia Department of Community Affairs or the Georgia Department of Revenue, the city hereby designates the Southside Enterprise Zone within the Cedartown Urban Redevelopment Area. This zone meets the qualificaions and criteria of the Act due to the existence of the following: 1. General distress. The high crime rate and presence of abandoned structures within the southside district satisfies the ctiteria of O.C.G.A. § 36-88-6(d) for general distress. 2. Underdevelopment. The area within the southside enterprise zone is severely underdeveloped as compared with other areas of the city. Most of othe structures within this area are dilapidated and many are empty. Such disrepair and inactivity satisfy the criteria of O.C.G.A. § 36-88-6(e). 3. General blight. The proposed enterprise zone is within an approved urban redevelopment area as amended. This satisfies the criteria of O.C.G.A. § 36-88-6(f) demonstrating blight. 4. Legal description. The area to be included in the southside enterprise zone is specifically described as follows: all of the proporty within the corporate limits of the City of Cedartown lying south of Canal Street, west of South Main Street, east of Cedar Creek and north of the east to west city limit line connecting Cedar Creek and South Main Street. (Ord. No. 15-2009, § 1, 11-16-09; Ord. No. 16-2011, § 1, 12-12-11)

div.head: Chapter 74 - TAXATION[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Property tax, § 6.10; other taxes, § 6.17. Cross reference— Alcoholic beverages, ch. 6; businesses, ch. 22. State Law reference— Taxation power of municipal and county governments, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 4, par. 1; limitation on taxing power of municipalities and counties, Ga. Const., art. 9, sec. 2, par. 8; ad valorem taxation of property, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-1 et seq.; municipal taxation, O.C.G.A. § 48-5-350 et seq.; specific, business and occupation taxes, O.C.G.A. § 48-13-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 74-1. - Wissahickon Avenue opportunity zone. (a) In accordance with the Cedartown Urban Redevelopment Plan and O.C.G.A. § 48-7-40 et seq., the city hereby designates the Wissahickon Avenue opportunity zone with the intent to qualify the designated area for applicable tax incentives and credits subject to approval by the Georgia Department of Community Affairs and the Georgia Department of Revenue. (b) This zone meets the qualifications and criteria set forth in applicable law including: (1) Pervasive poverty. The western portion of Cedartown suffers from pervasive poverty that is widespread throughout the nominated area and is evidenced and established by the fact that the Census tract and block group containing the Wissahickon Avenue opportunity zone, as identified by the U.S. Bureau of Census (2000), demonstrates a high level of persons with an income to poverty ratio less than 1.0 and suffer from a poverty level above 15 percent. (2) Unemployment. Further, the general economic conditions of the Census blocks surrounding the Wissahickon Avenue opportunity zone area have deteriorated due to adverse economic conditions. The area has experienced significant job loss due to the recent closings or relocations of vital manufacturing plants including Zartic Foods, Rome Plow and Varitech. Additionally, one of the largest remaining manufacturers, the HON company, reduced its work force by as many as 100 employees in the last year. (3) General blight. The existence of general blight within this area is evidenced by the area being located within the Cedartown Urban Redevelopment Plan as defined by O.C.G.A. § 36-61-2 which plan has been adopted by the city in accordance with the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 36-61-1 et seq. (4) Legal description. The following area is best referenced by tax map and parcel number in accordance with the parcel designations of the Polk County Tax Assessors' records. The Wissahickon Avenue opportunity zone shall include: That property commonly known as 701 Wissahickon Ave which in accordance with the Polk County Tax Assessor Records is identified as Tax Map and Parcel # C04-086 consisting of approximately 16 acres. The property is further described in that deed from NOPCO Chemical Co. to Diamond Shamrock dated November 20, 1986, and recorded at deed book 276 page 539 of the Deed Records of the Clerk of the Superior Court of Polk County. A map of the area is attached and along with a detailed legal description shall be retained by the city clerk and made available for public inspection at City Hall, 201 East Avenue, Cedartown, Georgia. (Ord. No. 3,2010, § 2, 1-11-10) Secs. 74-2—74-10. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - AD VALOREM TAXATION
Sec. 74-11. - Property tax. All owners of real or personal properties within the corporate limits of the city shall make returns of their property to the tax commissioner of the county or other designated authority in the method required by state law to identify all property, real and personal, located within the city subject to taxation. All properties are subject to taxation by the city on January 1, after the property is acquired, improved or changed so as to affect taxation of such property in the city. Sec. 74-12. - Homestead exemption. For each taxable year, the city does hereby grant to each person who is 65 years of age or over an exemption from all ad valorem taxes levied by the city in an amount of $2,000.00 on the homestead owned and occupied as a residence on January 1. There shall be no more than one such exemption per homestead. The value of the homestead in excess of the exempted amount shall remain subject to ad valorem taxation by the city. No resident shall be qualified to receive the benefits of such homestead exemption unless an affidavit is filed with the city clerk or county tax authority, giving the resident's age and any additional information as may be required to enable a proper determination to be made as to whether such owner is entitled to the exemption. After approval of homestead exemption it shall not be necessary to annually apply for the exemption. It shall be the duty of the owner to notify the proper taxing authority if the residence becomes ineligible for exemption because of transfer of title, death or failure to reside in the residence. The exemption application must be filed between January 2 and March 31 of each year, as required. Failure to timely file will result in no exemption being allowed for that taxable year. Sec. 74-13. - Tax millage established; billing. (a) Following receipt of the state approved tax digest, evaluations submitted in accordance with the state law from the county, with adjustments unique to the city for matters such as franchises, freeport, city homestead exemptions and public acquired properties after the assessment date, the city commission shall set a tax millage for taxation of all taxable properties within the city as deemed to be in the best interest of the citizens to provide services, provide for payment of public debt, and all other revenue purposes and needs of the city as authorized by the Charter and state law. (b) The city clerk shall promptly prepare, or have prepared, final tax bills on all properties contained in the tax digest with the due date for payment of taxes stated therein. Sec. 74-14. - Due dates and penalties. All taxes levied pursuant to the Charter and this article shall be due and payable upon receipt of the tax bill; provided, however, that the amount billed shall be past due and delinquent as provided in the bill. Interest shall be charged at the maximum allowed by state law on tax delinquencies on all past due tax assessments. In addition, following 90 days from the delinquent date, except where the tax is $500.00 or less on homestead property, a penalty of ten percent of the amount of the tax due and not paid, together with interest, shall be assessed. Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit the commission from authorizing special billing in accordance with state law when a timely tax digest is not submitted by the county. Sec. 74-15. - Delinquent tax executions; liens; related matters. (a) As soon as practicable after the last due date for payment of taxes, the city clerk, or other official of the city, is authorized and directed to issue executions for the principal amount of all taxes due, and any interest and penalty up to the date of issuance of execution. All executions shall bear teste in the name of the chairman of the city commission or other authority. Such execution shall be directed to the chief of police, or other law enforcement officer within the city, and shall contain information as to the type of tax execution, the amount owed and such other pertinent information as may be appropriate to ultimately levy, should this become necessary, upon the property, either real or personal, for collection of taxes. All tax executions which are levied against property shall be advertised and sold pursuant to the provisions of the Charter and Code of the city, and all governing provisions of state law. (b) All charges authorized by state law in connection with the execution and levying of taxes shall be made by appropriate officials of the city, and included in each execution and assessment for delinquent taxes within the city. Each execution issued under this section shall be a general lien against the person against whom the levy and execution is made. Further, this execution shall constitute a special lien against the property, returned or assessed for taxation for which the writ of execution was issued. (c) All executions issued under this section shall be entered upon the appropriate dockets of the county to give notice of the levying and fi. fa. of such execution. The cost of entry shall be added to such execution, and collected with all other principal, interest, penalties and other costs as may be authorized and collectable by law. Sec. 74-16. - Erroneous assessment; uncollectible personal property. (a) Any property which is assessed in error may be corrected through the appropriate tax assessment officials of the county by application of any party who receives notice of taxes due, levied and/or executed in error within the corporate limits of the city. For purposes of this section, "error" does not mean that the owner thereof desires to contest the amount of taxes owed, but only refers to clerical errors in billing, incorrect property, incorrect ownership, or other technical irregularities in the tax digest. (b) Any personal property assessments and taxes within the city which are deemed uncollectible after diligent attempts have been made to collect same by the city clerk may be brought to the attention of the city commission, at a regular meeting thereof. Explanation concerning the reason that personal property assessments cannot be collected shall be given, and all taxes which are uncollectible may be removed from the tax digest, or other appropriate records of the city. This removal shall only be accomplished pursuant to the approval of the city commission. Sec. 74-17. - Sale of property for delinquent taxes, assessments or other monies owed the city. The police chief, after approval of the city clerk, or any other taxing authority of the city, shall have the authority to sell property, pursuant to this article, the Charter of the city and all state laws applicable to such sale, for delinquent taxes, assessments, license fees or other revenue assessments of the city. Notice of sale, method of advertisement of sale and all other matters concerning such sale shall be governed by the provisions of state law, which generally regulate sales upon tax executions. Secs. 74-18—74-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS BUSINESS TAX
Sec. 74-31. - Tax levied; amount. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93 there is hereby levied upon state and national banking associations, federal savings and loan associations and state building and loan associations an annual business license tax in the amount of 0.25 percent on the gross receipts of the institution. "Gross receipts" shall mean gross receipts as defined in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, the minimum amount of business license tax due from any depository financial institution pursuant to this article shall be $1,000.00 per year. (Code 1969, § 13-101) Sec. 74-32. - Due date; filing of return. Each depository financial institution within the city shall file a return of its gross receipts with the city on March 1 of the year following the year in which such gross receipts were measured. The returns shall be in the manner and in the form prescribed by the commissioner of the department of banking and shall be based upon the allocation method set forth in O.C.G.A. § 48-6-93(d). The tax levied pursuant to this article shall be assessed and collected based upon the information provided in the return. The due date of taxes levied by this article shall be April 1 of each year. (Code 1969, § 13-102) Secs. 74-33—74-39. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - EXCISE TAX ON HOTEL-MOTEL ROOMS, LODGINGS AND ACCOMMODATIONS
Sec. 74-40. - Definitions. The following words, terms, and phrases shall, for the purposes of this chapter and except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, be defined as follows: City means the City of Cedartown, Georgia. Clerk means the clerk of the city commission of the City of Cedartown. Due date means the twentieth day after the end of the quarterly period for which tax is to be computed. Guest room means a room occupied, or intended, arranged, or designed for occupancy, by one or more occupants in a motel for the temporary purpose of living quarters or residential use. Motel means any structure or any portion of a structure, including any motel, lodging house, rooming house, dormitory, hotel, motor hotel, auto court, inn, bed and breakfast inn, public club, or private club, containing guest rooms and which is occupied, or is intended or designed for occupancy by guests, whether rent is paid in money, goods, labor, or otherwise. Such term does not include any jail, hospital, asylum, sanitarium, orphanage, prison, detention center, or other building in which human beings are housed and detained either involuntarily or under illegal restraint. Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession of any room or apartment in a motel, or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the room. Occupant or guest means any person who, for a consideration, uses, possesses, or has the right to use or possess any room in a motel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license to use, or other agreement, or otherwise. Operator means any person operating a motel in the City of Cedartown, Georgia, including, but not limited to, the owner or proprietor of such premises, the lessee, sublessee, lender in possession, licensee, or any other person otherwise operating such motel. Person means an individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, social club, fraternal organization, joint stock company, corporation, nonprofit, corporation or cooperative nonprofit membership, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, trustee, syndicate, or any other group or combination acting as a until, the plural as well as the singular number, excepting the United States of America, the State of Georgia, and any of their political subdivisions upon which the city is without power to impose the tax herein provided. Rent means the consideration received for occupancy, valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits, and property or services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the operator to the occupant, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. Return means any return filed or required to be filed as herein provided. Tax means the tax imposed by this chapter. (Ord. No. 31-1998, § 2, 12-17-98; Ord. No. 8-2018 , § 1, 9-10-18) Sec. 74-41. - Imposition and rate of tax. (a) There is hereby levied and imposed, and there shall be paid to the clerk of the city a tax of eight percent of the rent for every occupancy of a guest room in a motel in the city. (b) Such tax shall be paid upon any occupancy occurring on or after August 1, 2010, although such occupancy is had pursuant to a contract, lease, or other arrangement made prior to such date. Where rent is paid, or charged or billed, or falls due on either a weekly, monthly or other term basis, the rent so paid, charged, billed or falling due shall be subject to the tax herein imposed to the extent that it covers any portion of the month of January 1, 1999, and any portion of any monthly period thereafter. (c) No tax shall be levied as provided in this section upon the fees or charges of any rooms, lodgings, or accommodations furnished for a period of more than ten consecutive days or for use as meeting rooms only and not as guest rooms for lodging purposes. (d) The additional taxes attributable to the increase of the previous hotel/motel tax rate from five percent to the new rate of eight percent shall be allocated pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(b)(5) and expended as follows: (1) An amount equal to not less than 50 percent of the total amount of taxes collected that exceed the amount of taxes that would be collected at the rate of five percent shall be expended to the Downtown Cedartown Association ("DCA"), as a destination marketing organization, for promoting tourism, conventions and trade shows by and through the operation of the Cedartown Depot. (2) The remaining amount of taxes collected that exceed the amount of taxes that would be collected at the rate of five percent which are not otherwise expended under the immediately preceding paragraph, shall be expended in furtherance of the Cedartown Civic Auditorium as a tourism development product, the operation of which improves Cedartown's destination appeal for visitors." (e) Nothing in this section shall be construed to impair, or authorize or require the impairment of, any existing contract or contractual right. (f) At no time shall the city levy simultaneously more than one tax pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 48-13-51(b)(1) et seq. (Ord. No. 31-1998, § 2, 12-17-98; Ord. No. 5,2007, § 1, 5-14-07; Ord. No. 10,201, §§ 1—5, 6-24-10) Sec. 74-42. - Collection of tax by operator. It shall be the duty of every operator of a motel located within the city to collect from the occupants the tax levied and imposed upon the occupancy of guest rooms by the provisions of this article. (Ord. No. 31-1998, § 2, 12-17-98) Sec. 74-43. - Exemptions. Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, no tax shall be levied as provided by this article upon the fees or charges of any room, lodgings, or accommodations: (a) Furnished for use by state or local government officials or employees when traveling on official business; or (b) Furnished to any persons who certify that they are staying at such location as the result of the destruction of or significant damage to their home or residence by fire, storm, or other casualty. (Ord. No. 31-1998, § 2, 12-17-98) Sec. 74-44. - Registration of operator. (a) Every person engaging or about to engage in business as an operator of a motel in this city shall immediately register with the clerk of the city commission on a form provided by said clerk. Persons engaged in such business must so register not later than 15 days after the date this article becomes effective, but such privilege of registration after the imposition of such tax shall not relieve any person from the obligation of payment or collection of tax on and after the date of imposition thereof. Such registration shall set forth the name under which such person transacts business or intends to transact business, the location of his place or places of business and such other information which would facilitate the collection of the tax as the clerk may require. The registration shall be signed by the owner if a natural person; by a member or partner in case of ownership by an association or partnership; and by an executive officer in the case of ownership by a corporation. (b) A separate registration shall be required for each place of business of an operator, if he or she maintains or operates more than one such place of business in the city. (c) In order to facilitate registration, the clerk may prescribe administrative provisions other than those provided in this section. Such provisions shall be made to effect the purposes of this article, and, once adopted, shall be specifically incorporated herein and made a part hereof by reference. (Ord. No. 31-1998, § 2, 12-17-98) Sec. 74-45. - Certificate of taxing authority. Upon the consideration of an operator as hereinbefore provided, the clerk shall issue to such operator without charge a certificate of authority to collect the tax from the occupants, stating the name and location of the business to which it is applicable. Such certificates shall be nonassignable and nontransferable, and shall be returned immediately to the secretary upon the cessation of business by the registered operator at the location named, or upon sale or transfer of such business at said location. (Ord. No. 31-1998, § 2, 12-17-98) Sec. 74-46. - Due date of taxes. All taxes levied and imposed by this article shall be due and payable to the City of Cedartown or its designee on a monthly basis on or before the twentieth day of the month next succeeding each respective monthly period in which such taxes are collected. (Ord. No. 31-1998, § 2, 12-17-98; Ord. No. 8-2018 , § 2, 9-10-18) Sec. 74-47. - Returns and time of filing; remittance of tax. (a) On or before the twentieth day of the month following each monthly period, a return for the preceding monthly period shall be filed with the clerk in such form as the clerk may prescribe, by every operator liable for the payment of tax hereunder. (b) All returns shall show the gross rent, exempt rent, taxable rent, amount of tax collected or otherwise due for the monthly period for which filed, and such other information as may be required by the clerk, and shall be accompanied when filed by remittance of the net amount of tax due. (Ord. No. 31-1998, § 2, 12-17-98; Ord. No. 8-2018 , §§ 3, 4, 9-10-18) Sec. 74-48. - Collection fee allowed operator. Operators collecting the tax levied hereunder shall be allowed a percentage of the tax due and accounted for and shall be reimbursed in the form of a deduction in submitting, reporting, and payment of the amount due, if said amount is not delinquent at the time of payment. The rate of the deduction shall be the same rate authorized for deductions from state sales and use tax under O.C.G.A. § 48-8-50, as now or hereafter amended. (Ord. No. 31-1998, § 2, 12-17-98) Sec. 74-49. - Deficiency determinations. (a) Recomputation of tax; authority to make; basis of recomputation. If the clerk is not satisfied with the return or returns of the tax or the amount of the tax required to be paid to the city by any operator, he or she may compute and determine the amount required to be paid upon the basis of any information which is or may come into his or her possession. One or more than one deficiency determination may be made of the amount due for one or more than one monthly period. (b) Interest on deficiency. The amount of the unpaid tax found to be due shall bear interest at the rate of three-fourths of one percent per month from and after the twentieth day of the month following the monthly period for which the amount should have been returned until the date of payment of such tax and interest. (c) Offsetting of overpayments. In making a determination of deficiency, the clerk may offset overpayments for a period, or periods, against unpaid tax found to be due for another period or periods, against penalties, and against the interest on such unpaid tax. (d) Notice of determination; service of. The clerk or any other agent of the city shall give to the operator written notice of any determination of deficiency. The notice may be served personally or by mail, or both. If by mail, such service shall be addressed to the operator at his address as it appears in the records of the clerk. (e) Time within which notice of deficiency determination to be mailed. Except in the case of a failure to make a return, every notice of a deficiency determination shall be mailed within one year after the twentieth day of the calendar month following the monthly period for which the amount is proposed to be determined, or within one year after the return is filed, whichever period shall last expire. (Ord. No. 31-1998, § 2, 12-17-98; Ord. No. 8-2018 , §§ 5—7, 9-10-18) Sec. 74-50. - Determination if no return made. (a) Estimate of gross receipt. If any operator fails to make a return, the clerk shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts of the operator or, as the case may be, of the amount of the total rentals in this city which are subject to the tax. The estimate shall be made for the period or periods during which the person failed to make the return and shall be based upon any information which is or may come into the possession of the clerk. Upon the basis of this estimate the clerk shall compute and determine the amount required to be paid the city, adding to the sum this determined a penalty equal to 15 percent thereof. One or more determinations may be made of the amount due for one or more than one monthly period. (b) Offsetting of overpayments. In making a determination under this Code section, the clerk may offset overpayments for a period, or periods, against unpaid tax found to be due for another period or periods, against penalties, and against interest on unpaid tax found to be due. (c) Interest on amount found due. The amount of the unpaid tax found to be due shall bear interest at the rate of three-fourths of one percent per month from and after the twentieth day of the month following the monthly period for which the amount should have been returned until the date of payment of such tax, penalties, and interest. (d) Notice of determination; service of. Promptly after making his determination, service of this notice shall be either by personal service or by mail, at the operator's address as it appears in the records of the clerk. (Ord. No. 31-1998, § 2, 12-17-98; Ord. No. 8-2018 , §§ 8, 9, 9-10-18) Sec. 74-51. - Collection of tax and enforcement. (a) Action for tax; time for. When it is determined by a return filed, or by the clerk having made a determination under the provisions of section 74-49 or 74-50 of this article, that tax is due and payable to the City of Cedartown under the provisions of this article, the city manager may at any time within three years after determination that such tax is due and payable bring an action in the court of this state, or any other state, or of the United States in the name of the city to collect the amount of tax payable to the city together with interest thereon and penalties, court costs, attorney's fees, and other legal fees incident thereto. The bringing of such an action shall not be a prerequisite for the issuance of a Fi.Fa. under the provisions of subparagraph (d) hereof. (b) Duty of successors or assignees of operator to withhold tax from purchase money. If any operator liable for any amount of tax under this article sells or transfers his business, his successors or assigns shall withhold a sufficient amount from the purchase price of the business to cover such amount of tax, interest thereon, and penalties, and pay such sum over to the city, unless the operator liable for such tax delivers to such purchaser or transferee, as the case may be, at the time of such sale or transfer of a certificate from the clerk showing that all tax returns required of such operator have been filed and all taxes shown to be due and payable on said returns have been paid in full. (c) Liability for failure to withhold time to enforce successor's liability. If the purchaser or transferee of a business governed by this article fails to withhold the required amount of any delinquent taxes due hereunder from the purchase price, he shall be personally liable for the payment of the amount required to be withheld by him to the extent of the purchase price, valued in money. The time within which the obligation of a successor may be enforced shall start to run at the time the operator sells or transfers his business, or at the time that the determination against the operator becomes final, whichever event occurs later. In addition, the city may refuse to issue a certificate of authority to collect the tax due under this article to any purchaser failing to withhold any past due taxes from the purchase price until such taxes have been paid and any deficiency or other tax liability of the prior operator hereunder have been satisfied. (Ord. No. 31-1998, § 2, 12-17-98) Sec. 74-52. - Issuance of Fi.Fa. Taxes payable on rental fees for guest rooms hereunder shall constitute a lien against the real property on which the hotel or motel is located. The clerk is hereby authorized to issue a Fi.Fa. for execution and levy to satisfy the amount of any tax, penalty or interest due but not paid under the provisions of this article, whether as a result of a deficiency determination, failure to file returns, or any other reason. (Ord. No. 31-1998, § 2, 12-17-98) Sec. 74-53. - Administration of article. (a) Authority of the clerk. The clerk, under supervision of the city manager, shall administer and enforce the provisions of this article for the levy and collection of the tax imposed by this article. (b) Rules and regulations. The clerk shall have the power and authority to make and publish reasonable rules and regulations not inconsistent with this article or other ordinances of the city, or the laws of the State of Georgia, or the constitution of this state or the United States, for the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this article and the collection of the taxes hereunder. (c) Examination of records; audits. The clerk or any person authorized in writing by the city may enter on the hotel/motel premises and examine the books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment, and other facilities of any operator in order to verify the accuracy of any return made, or if no return is made by the operator, to ascertain and determine the amount of tax required to be paid. (e) Authority to require reports; contents. In administration of the provisions of this article, the clerk may require the filing of the reports by any person or class of persons having in their possession or custody information relating to rentals of guest rooms which are subject to the tax. The reports shall be filed with the clerk when required by the clerk and shall set forth the rental charged for each occupancy, the date or dates of occupancy, and such other information as the clerk may require. (f) Limitation on disclosure of business of operators, etc. The clerk or any person having an administrative duty under this article shall not make known in any manner the business affairs, operations, or information obtained by an audit of books, papers, records, financial reports, equipment and other facilities of any operator or any other person visited or examined in the discharge of official duty, or the amount or source of income, profits, losses, expenditures, or any particular thereof, set forth or disclosed in any return, or permit any return or copy thereof or any book containing any abstract or particulars thereof to be seen or examined by any person not having such administrative duty under this article, except in case of judicial proceedings or other proceedings necessary to collect tax hereby levied and assessed, or as required by the Georgia Open Records Act, O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70, et seq., or any other laws of this state or United States. Successors, receivers, trustees, executors, administrators, assignees, and grantors, if directly interested, may be given information as to the items included in the measure and amount of unpaid tax or amounts of tax, interest and penalties required to be collected. If the city or its agents are required to disclose any such information described in this paragraph pursuant to court order or the Open Records Act or any similar such legal compulsion, the city shall not be liable to any operator or other person for damages claimed to have arisen due to such disclosure. (Ord. No. 31-1998, § 2, 12-17-98) Sec. 74-54. - Agents for receiving notices. When registering pursuant to section 74-44 hereof, each operator shall appoint, in writing, an agent to receive any notice required to be given to the operator under the provisions of this article, stating the full name, street address, mailing address and telephone number of such agent. Such agent shall be either an individual resident of the city or an employee of the operator who regularly works at the operator's place of business on a daily basis, and the appointment of the agent must be accompanied by the written consent of such agent to serve as agent for the operator. Such agent may be changed from time to time by written appointment of, and consent of a successor agent, and the operator may serve as that agent. The operator is required to have such an agent at all times and should any agent cease to be a resident of the city or an employee regularly working at the operator's place of business in the city, as the case may be, the operator shall immediately file a written appointment of a new agent and such agent's consent to serve as such with the clerk. Any agent so appointed by an operator shall be authorized to receive for and on behalf of the operator any notice required to be given to the operator by the provisions of this article. Delivery of any such notice to such agent, in person or by mail, shall be sufficient to meet the requirements of this article and such notice shall be binding on the operator. This method of giving notice to operators is supplemental and cumulative of the other methods of giving notice set forth in this article. (Ord. No. 31-1998, § 2, 12-17-98) Sec. 74-55. - Violations; fines and punishment. (a) Any person violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction thereof shall be punished as provided in section 7-1 of this Code. Each person shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation of any provision of this article is committed, continued, or permitted by such person, and shall be punished accordingly. (b) It shall be unlawful and a violation of this Code section for any operator or other person to fail to register as required herein, or to furnish any return required to be made, or to fail or refuses to furnish a supplemental return or other data required by the clerk, or to render a false or fraudulent return. It shall also be unlawful and a violation of this Code section for any person who is required to make, render, sign, or verify any report to make any false or fraudulent report, with intent to defeat or evade the determination of an amount due required by this article to be made. Anyone who violates the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon convictions thereof shall be punished as aforesaid. (Ord. No. 31-1998, § 2, 12-17-98)

div.head: Chapter 78 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Cross reference— Prosecution of traffic violations, § 34-49; offenses and miscellaneous provisions, ch. 58; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70; vehicles for hire, ch. 90; streets closed; named; renamed, app. A; traffic schedule, app. B. State Law reference— Authority to provide devices to control the flow of traffic, Ga. Const. art. 9, sec. 2, par. 3(a)(4); Uniform Rules of the Road, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.; power of local authorities generally, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-371; adoption of uniform rules of the road by local authorities, O.C.G.A. § 40-6-372; prosecution of traffic offenses, O.C.G.A. § 40-13-1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 78-1. - Uniform Rules of the Road adopted. (a) Pursuant to O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-372—40-6-376, O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-2—40-6-395, known as the Uniform Rules of the Road, and the definitions contained in O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1, are hereby adopted as and for the traffic regulations of the city with like effect as if recited in this section. (b) Unless another penalty is expressly provided by state law, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this section shall be punished in accordance with section 1-13. Sec. 78-2. - Vehicles with cleats; running on rims. It shall be unlawful for any automobile, truck, road machine, or other machines with beaded wheels, rims or tires that dig into or tend to injure the street pavement, to be operated on any street in the city paved with asphalt, or to operate such vehicles thereon using rims without tires. (Code 1969, § 14-7) State Law reference— Wheels causing pounding on road pavement, O.C.G.A. § 40-8-3. Sec. 78-3. - Occupant of motorcycles. It shall be unlawful for more than one person to ride or be upon a motorcycle, motorbike or other motorized cart or similar vehicle as defined by state law, unless such vehicle is designed for two or more passengers. (Code 1969, § 14-6) Sec. 78-4. - Riding on exterior of vehicle prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or occupy the running boards, fenders or bumpers of any automobile, truck or other motor driven vehicle or motorcycle. (Code 1969, § 14-8) Secs. 78-5—78-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - PARKING, STOPPING AND STANDING
Sec. 78-31. - Adoption of state law. All provisions of state law which deal with the stopping, parking or other maneuvering of automobiles, either contained in the Uniform Rules of the Road or in other traffic law sections of the state, are deemed incorporated and adopted as traffic regulations of this city, with like effect as if recited in this section. Sec. 78-32. - Actual loading and unloading defined. The term "actual loading and unloading" shall mean the parking of vehicles for the purpose of loading and unloading merchandise or other commodities, and when such loading and unloading is completed, vehicles to which this article applies shall, within 30 minutes after such loading or unloading is completed, vacate the space occupied by them while loading or unloading, and shall not, within two hours, again occupy the same space or a space within 100 feet of such space, unless for the purpose of again loading or unloading. (Code 1969, § 14-29) Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 78-33. - Passenger vehicles only to be parked in residential areas; exceptions. It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked, except temporarily or for actual loading and unloading purposes, any motor truck, motor bus, bulldozer, earth-moving machine, motor tractor, wagon or any other vehicle, whether motor-propelled or animal-drawn, except automobiles and other vehicles which are usually intended for use as passenger automobiles and passenger vehicles, along or against the curb or curbline of any residential area. (Code 1969, § 14-31) Sec. 78-34. - Parking of vehicles for hire. It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked on any street or portion of the streets of the city listed below, any taxicab, motor bus or other vehicle, whether common, contract or other carrier of passengers for hire, except for the purpose of taking on passengers who are, at the time of the parking of any such vehicle, then ready to be taken into such vehicle or ready to be discharged therefrom, and who are, at the time of the parking of such vehicle, actually discharged therefrom or taken into same, such streets and portions of streets being as follows: (1) Prior Street, from the west line of Main Street to the east line of College Street. (2) Main Street, from East Avenue to Gibson Street. (3) Grace Street, from College Street to Main Street. (4) Woodland Street, from College Street to Philpot Street. (5) East Avenue, from College Street to Main Street. (6) West Ware Street, from College Street to Main Street. (7) West Gibson Street, from College Street to Main Street. (Code 1969, § 14-37) Sec. 78-35. - Parking of truck with refrigeration unit limited. It shall be unlawful for any person to park, or cause to be parked, any refrigeration unit truck or trailer, with the refrigeration unit in operation, within the city limits nearer than 500 feet of a dwelling, cultural building or business establishment for a continuous period of longer than one hour, except in cases where the truck is being loaded, unloaded or serviced. (Code 1969, § 14-38) Sec. 78-36. - No parking areas, zones. The city manager, police chief or other designated official of the city is hereby authorized to designate, with approval of the city commission, those portions of streets, alleys or other rights-of-way within the city where parking shall be prohibited. Further, these authorities shall designate any areas where parking time limits may be established, handicapped parking established or similar parking restrictions are deemed appropriate within the city. Sec. 78-37. - Temporary or emergency no parking zones. The chief of police, or other law enforcement officer of the city, is authorized and directed, when necessary for protection of the public from congestion and danger during parades, public performances or similar functions, to designate certain zones including portions of streets, alleys or other rights-of-way as areas within which vehicles may not be parked, driven and/or stopped. (Code 1969, § 14-32) Sec. 78-38. - Obstruction of alley. No vehicle shall be parked so as to interfere with ingress or egress to any public or private alley, or driveway, within the city. (Code 1969, § 14-34) Sec. 78-39. - Use of house and travel trailers as residences prohibited. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to stay, reside, or generally use a house trailer or travel trailer as a permanent residence on any public or private property within the corporate limits of the city. (b) For purposes of this Code section, the phrases "house trailer" and "travel trailer" shall mean a trailer designed for temporary residence, and not intended to be permanently affixed to any real property, whether such trailer is capable of being towed behind a separate vehicle, or capable of being driven as a vehicle. (c) For purposes of this Code section, a person shall be deemed to be using the travel trailer or house trailer as a permanent residence if he or she resides therein for more than 30 consecutive days in any location and can provide proof of no other fixed residence address. (Ord. No. 16-1999, § 1, 11-8-99) Sec. 78-40. - Parking and/or storage of vehicles in residential areas. (a) No person, except a licensed motor vehicle dealer, shall accumulate, store, park, or allow to remain outside of any structure on real estate which is zoned in a residential classification any licensed motor vehicles exceeding the number of licensed drivers, plus two, who reside in the household where the vehicles are located and have so resided for a period of 14 consecutive days. Licensed motor vehicles exceeding the number of licensed drivers, plus two, who occupy and reside upon the subject property shall be in violation of this ordinance, regardless of whether the vehicles are operable or have a current tag. (b) All vehicles in residential areas shall be parked on a hard-surfaced driveway (i.e., asphalt, concrete, gravel, or, if approved by the city building inspector, a turf-reinforced driveway). In the event there is not an appropriate area to park vehicles on a hard-surfaced driveway, then vehicles shall be parked on the street, or adjacent to the point of ingress and egress to the residence; or otherwise in such manner as to not clutter, block the front entrance of a residence, or be left unattended and parked around large areas of the front yard of any residence. One purpose of this provision is to help accomplish enforcement of subparagraph (a) and to ensure that an entrance to a premises is open and easily accessed by emergency vehicles, or law enforcement entities who may have to enter the premises. (c) Subparagraph (b) shall not apply to any resident who is having an organized party, family function, or other social gathering on the premises. (Ord. No. 18,2010, § 1, 11-8-10) Secs. 78-41—78-70. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - OPERATION OF VEHICLES
Sec. 78-71. - Truck-trailer traffic restricted. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Designated truck route means specific streets authorized for truck-trailer traffic within the corporate limits of the city. Those streets or roads are designated as U.S. 27 bypass and State Route 100 bypass (Canal Street and Martin Luther King, Jr. Boulevard). Truck-trailer means a motorized vehicle having ten wheels or more and/or tandem axles which generally has attached thereto a trailer for the purposes of hauling. (b) Prohibited truck-trailer travel; exceptions. Through truck-trailers not stopping for pickup or deliveries in the city are prohibited from traveling along any streets within the city limits of the city, except along the designated routes as set forth in this section. Truck-trailer deliveries or pickups within the corporate boundaries of the city are permitted. (c) Violation; penalty. Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable upon conviction pursuant to the provisions of section 1-13. (Ord. No. 1-1996, §§ 2—4, 2-10-96) Sec. 78-72. - Speed of emergency vehicles. It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any emergency vehicle, ambulance, police car or fire truck at a speed which is greater than reasonably prudent considering the nature of the emergency to which the vehicle is responding. In any event, such emergency vehicle shall be operated at a speed reasonably prudent to allow the vehicle to be maintained at all times in control by the operator thereof. (Code 1969, § 14-65) Sec. 78-73. - Authority of city manager to establish truck routes, erect signs. The city manager is hereby authorized to establish zones, portions of streets or other areas within the city where travel by any vehicle having more than six wheels, which is primarily designed for the transportation of property or is known as a "truck-tractor" as defined pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 40-1-1, shall be prohibited. Signs prohibiting these vehicles from traveling in these locations shall be erected by designation of the city manager. Violation of this prohibition for trucks traveling in such areas shall be punished pursuant to section 1-13. (Code 1969, § 14-69) Secs. 78-74—78-100. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - RAILROADS
Sec. 78-101. - Speed limit. No railroad train or engine while inside the corporate limits of the city shall be operated at a greater rate of speed than 25 miles per hour. (Code 1969, § 14-117) Sec. 78-102. - Bell or horn to be sounded at grade crossing. The bells or horns of all railroad trains and engines shall be tolled or sounded at all times while they are within 200 feet of all public grade crossings in the city. (Code 1969, § 14-118) Sec. 78-103. - Blocking crossing; limitation on time. No railroad train, portion thereof, or railroad engine (hereafter called "train") shall blockade any public street, avenue, lane, alley, sidewalk or any portion thereof in the city for more than five minutes at anytime, and then only when absolutely necessary in the proper usage of rail service; provided, that through passenger trains may be permitted to blockade any street, avenue, lane, alley, sidewalk or portion thereof for as long as eight minutes at any one time if such time is necessary in order to load and unload passengers, baggage, express or mail; and provided further that after such train has cleared such street, avenue, lane, alley, sidewalk or portion thereof, no other train shall be permitted to blockade such street or other area for any length of time whatever, until traffic and pedestrians have been given time to pass over such street, avenue, lane, alley, sidewalk or other area. (Code 1969, § 14-119) Secs. 78-104—78-124. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - MOTORIZED CARTS[2]
Footnotes: --- (2) --- Editor's note— Ord. No. 12,2004, § 1, adopted Sept. 13, 2004, created §§ 78-90—78-95. Inasmuch as said sections had already been reserved for use in art. III, these provisions were added to the Code as §§ 78-125—78-129 at the editor's discretion to maintain the numeric continuity of the Code. Cross reference— Schedule of streets where motorized carts are authorized to be operated, app. B, § 4.
Sec. 78-125. - Findings; definition. The city commission finds that certain streets located within certain residential subdivisions of the city and under its jurisdiction are constructed so as to safely permit their use by operators of motorized carts. Motorized carts are defined as those electric- and gasoline-powered pleasure carts, commonly called golf carts, which do not exceed 20 miles per hour. This article shall not apply to any golf or country clubs or other such organized entities which own such carts and make them available to members of the public on a rental basis. (Ord. No. 12,2004, § 1, 9-13-04) Sec. 78-126. - Condition of carts. (a) Every gasoline-powered cart shall at all times be equipped with an exhaust system in good working order and in constant operation, meeting the following specifications: (1) The exhaust system shall include the piping leading from the flange of the exhaust manifold to and including the muffler and exhaust pipes or include any and all parts specified by the manufacturer. (2) The exhaust system in its own shall be securely fastened, including the consideration of missing or broken brackets or hangers. (3) The engine and power mechanism of every gasoline-powered cart shall be so equipped, adjusted, and tuned, as to prevent the escape of excessive smoke or fumes. (b) It shall be unlawful for the owner of any cart to operate or permit the operation of such cart on which any device controlling or abating atmospheric conditions, which is placed on the cart by the manufacturer, to render the device unserviceable by removal, alteration, or other interference with its operation. (c) All carts shall be maintained in working order and kept in good condition and shall be subject to inspection by city officials at reasonable times and intervals. (d) All carts shall be maintained in such conditions so that they are incapable of "backfiring", or otherwise operating so as to make loud noises; or create noise as a result of an operators equipping the cart with a certain device. (Ord. No. 12,2004, § 1, 9-13-04) Sec. 78-127. - Operation regulations. (a) All operators shall abide by all traffic regulations applicable to vehicular traffic when using the city streets and other areas accessible to such carts by the public in the city, including the uniform rules of the road contained in O.C.G.A. §§ 40-6-2 thru 40-6-395 and adopted in section 78-1 of this Code. (b) Motorized carts shall not be operated on sidewalks designated or customarily used by pedestrians at any time. (c) Motorized carts may be operated over those authorized city streets and in those areas accessible by the public only during daylight hours, unless such motorized carts are equipped with functional headlights, tail lights, and reflective tape that would make the cart visible at night. No carts may be operated after 9:00 p.m. at night. (d) Motorized carts shall only be permitted in designated areas, by schedule, which initial schedule of designated street areas is attached hereto as exhibit "A" to this section. This schedule, and any amendments thereto adding other areas where carts are permitted shall be placed in the appropriate appendix of the Code of the City of Cedartown. (e) No motorized carts shall be operated on private property without the owner's permission. (f) No person younger than 13 years of age shall be authorized to operate any motorized cart. Further, no person whose driver's license is revoked, suspended or invalid shall operate such carts. (g) No more than two persons shall ride or sit on any part of any golf cart while it is in operation. (Ord. No. 12,2004, § 1, 9-13-04) Sec. 78-128. - Hazardous activities prohibited; special rules. (a) No individual or group utilizing motorized carts shall engage in any dangerous, reckless, or hazardous activities on the city streets or other areas accessible by the public for motorized carts. Such activities shall include, but not be limited to, racing in any form, except for special events approved by the city, blocking of any public access, except for special events approved by the city, and reckless or aggressive driving. (b) It shall be unlawful for anyone to consume or have in their possession any open container of alcoholic beverages while operating a motorized cart under this article. (c) All operators and passengers must remain seated at all times during the movement and/or operation of the golf cart. (d) A warning or announcement shall be given by operators of golf carts when approaching pedestrians from the rear. This warning or announcement may be verbal, but it is recommended that golf-cart operators equip their vehicles with a warning device such as a horn or bell. (Ord. No. 12,2004, § 1, 9-13-04) Sec. 78-129. - Liability. Every person using motorized vehicles on city streets is liable for his or her own actions. Liability insurance coverage varies, and each person owning or operating a golf cart on the city streets or in those areas accessible by the public should verify coverage. The city does not require mandatory liability coverage in order to operate motorized carts. (Ord. No. 12,2004, § 1, 9-13-04) Sec. 78-130. - Penalties. Any person who violates the terms of this article shall be punished as provided in section 1-13 of this Code. (Ord. No. 12,2004, § 1, 9-13-04)

div.head: Chapter 82 - UTILITIES[1]
div.p:
Footnotes: --- (1) --- Charter reference— Sewer fees, § 6.15. Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18; businesses, ch. 22; environment, ch. 38; fire prevention and protection, ch. 42; floods, ch. 46; health and sanitation, ch. 50; solid waste, ch. 66; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 70.
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 82-1. - Reserved. Editor's note— Ord. No. 5-2008, § 1, adopted April 14, 2008, deleted § 82-1, which pertained to interference with utility property and derived from Code 1969, § 22-1. Sec. 82-2. - Opening fire hydrant. If any person shall open any fire hydrant, fireplug, gate, or lift or remove the cover of it, without license of the city commission or other city official, except in case of fire, and then only by direction of the fire department, the offender shall be punished as provided in section 1-13. (Code 1969, § 22-2) Sec. 82-3. - Repair of leaking service pipes. If the service pipes, stopcock or pipes through the premises of any person shall become leaky for want of repairing, it shall be the duty of such persons to have them repaired, and upon failure to have them repaired within 48 hours after notice, the supply of water may be stopped to the location by the city. (Code 1969, § 22-4) Sec. 82-4. - Water and sewer specifications. There is hereby adopted by the city, for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the installation, alteration, removal, location and maintenance of all water and sewer systems of the city, that certain work entitled Specifications for Installation of Water and Sewer Lines—City of Cedartown. These specifications are dated June 10, 1985, and are incorporated in this article by reference, and adopted save and except such portions thereof as may be hereafter deleted, modified or amended. A copy is currently on file at the office of the city clerk. This specifications document is hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length in this article; and the provisions thereof shall be controlling in the installation of water and sewer lines, and all related work concerning same, within the corporate limits of the city or any adjacent area to the corporate limits that may be served by water and sewer systems of the city. (Code 1969, § 22-17) Sec. 82-5. - Water and sewer testing services. (a) Permission required. Any person who desires to use the city's employees, agents or servants for any laboratory services, testing facility or other similar testing; using equipment of the city for water and/or wastewater testing, must first obtain the permission of the city manager in writing to conduct such testing. Further, the party shall execute such contracts, waivers or other documents as might be deemed appropriate by the city to indicate that such testing is accomplished by the city on an independent contract basis for such requesting party pursuant to the provisions of subsection (c) of this section. (b) Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply: (1) Testing means any procedure, review, analysis or similar method by which water and/or wastewater may be analyzed, reviewed or processed to obtain certain measurements or results which may be required by federal or state regulations governing the defined parameters of such procedures. (2) Independent contractor shall be construed to mean that any testing done for any requesting party pursuant to this section shall be upon contract service by the city. The city shall act independently, and without liability, for such testing and not as an agent, employee or servant of the requesting party. (3) Designated test means that testing procedure accomplished by the city on behalf of any requesting party as set forth in the contractual agreement between the city and the requesting party. (4) Requesting party means any person who may engage the city to conduct any water and/or wastewater testing. (c) Independent contracting status of testing and analysis. Any designated testing procedure shall be accomplished under such terms, conditions and agreements as may be required by the city manager. Any such party requesting the testing shall execute an agreement which, among other things, provides that the city accomplishes this testing on an independent contract basis for the party. Further, the party shall hold the city harmless from any claim, injury or damage as a result of improper testing, improper analysis or for other negligent acts. It is understood and agreed that the city is only accomplishing this testing as an accommodation for other public or private agencies, firms and corporations and does not undertake to assume any liability, responsibility or risk of loss for this testing. (d) Rates and charges. Attached to any agreement for testing shall be a schedule of all rates, charges and other reimbursable expenses to be paid to the city for testing. The rates to be charged shall be promulgated by the city manager and approved by the city commission (see appendix C to this Code for laboratory fees). Rates are subject to change with 60 days' notice to any requesting party. (Code 1969, § 22-18) Sec. 82-6. - Water and sewer tap charges. (a) Water and sewer tap charges shall be in the amounts set forth in appendix C to this Code. (b) The following regulations shall govern the construction and installation of any water and/or sewer taps which may occur upon either of these systems of the city: (1) Each construction unit is required to have an individual tap for water and/or sewer service. All taps shall be charged on a per unit basis. Tap fees shall be charged when a physical connection is made between any newly constructed or existing unit and the city's water and/or sewer infrastructure. Additionally, a constructed unit which imparts an additional water demand or waste load to the water or sewer system shall be charged a tap fee, even if an existing tap is used. For purposes of this regulation, "unit" is defined as a dwelling house, apartment, or other structure which is being constructed or tied-on to the water or sewer system. (2) On each two-inch or larger water tap or larger than four-inch sewer tap, a minimum charge as set forth in appendix C shall be assessed upon the tap application being made. Once construction and all expenses have been calculated pursuant to appendix C, if the cost exceeds the minimum amounts set forth in appendix C, the actual cost shall be billed and due and payable immediately upon billing. Failure to pay shall result in a levy of other fines and/or penalties pursuant to the applicable codes of the city. (3) All tap sizes, type of materials used in any tap and related construction of the tap shall be within the discretion of the appropriate employees of the city. No water or sewer tap shall be allowed outside of the corporate limits of the city without the prior approval of the city commission. (4) If the appropriate official of the city should determine that engineering drawings, reviews of construction or similar requirements are necessary in order to appropriately make any construction taps for water and sewer, all such costs and/or expenses shall be paid by the applicant. (Code 1969, § 5-17; Ord. No. 25-2001, § 1, 12-17-01) Sec. 82-7. - Right of entry; right to terminate service. Designated city personnel shall have the right to enter upon the premises, including private property, where city water and/or sewer services are used, provided or distributed for the general purposes of enforcing this chapter and specifically for purposes of inspecting pipes, fixtures, settings, readings and repairing meters, commencing or discontinuing service or similar general activities enforcing rules and regulations applicable to water and sewer use within the city. Water and/or sewer service may be terminated, or temporarily stopped, in case of public emergency, necessity for repair, extension of the systems or for similar such necessary action by the city. Reasonable notice, as may be practicable, shall be given to all persons affected by periods of interrupted service. Any person denying city agents, servants and/or employees a right of entry for purposes of this section shall be punished, upon conviction, as set forth in section 1-13. Sec. 82-8. - Liability for insufficient water and/or sewer service. The city shall not be liable for inadequate, insufficient or other types of failure of water and/or sewer service to any person being supplied such services by the city. This shall include any alleged water pressure problems, stoppage or interruption in sewer lines, system failures and similar service problems which may arise in the water and/or sewer systems of the city. Sec. 82-9. - Other unauthorized use of utility services. No person shall permit a third party, without the consent of the city, to use any service of the city by virtue of an improper tap, tying on to service or similar action. Any party violating this section shall be punished, upon conviction, as provided in section 1-13. Sec. 82-10. - Irrigation meters. The charge for setting and connecting the irrigation meter within the city shall be set forth in Appendix C, entitled "Schedule of Fees." (Ord. No. 12-2012, § 2, 8-13-12) Secs. 82-11—82-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION OF PAYMENTS
Sec. 82-21. - General charges for utility services. All persons shall pay for all utility services (water, sewer, garbage, collection and related services) based upon the rate of charges set for such services by the city commission, through its determination of the rate of charges, schedule of fees and related matters necessary to operate such services for the city. All revenues derived therefrom shall be used for the operation, maintenance, debt retirement and other authorized expenses of the utility systems of the city. These rates of charge are set forth in appendix C of this Code, designated as rates of charge for such service, and are incorporated as part of this section by reference. Any taxes or charges as set forth in Appendix C of this Code shall constitute a lien on the property served by said utility services. (Ord. No. 20-1998, § 1, 6-8-98) Sec. 82-22. - Billing; delinquencies and penalties. (a) Bills to customers for utilities shall be mailed out on such day or days of each month as may be determined as desirable by the city. Bills shall be paid at the city hall. (b) Failure to receive bills or notices shall not prevent such bills from becoming delinquent nor relieve the consumer from payment of same. (c) The failure of utility users to timely pay charges duly imposed shall result in the automatic imposition of the following penalties: (1) Nonpayment after the tenth of the month following the bill date will be subject to a penalty of ten percent of the delinquent account charges. (2) The past due amount must be paid before the 25th of the month to avoid a delinquent payment fee and/or disconnection of service. (Ord. No. 10-1995, § 2, 4-10-95; Ord. No. 2-2009, § 2, 3-9-09; Ord. No. 1-2011, § 2, 1-13-11; Ord. No. 1-2014, 6-2-14) Sec. 82-23. - Disconnection of service; reinstatement. (a) Pursuant to subsection 82-22(c)(2) above, if an account remains delinquent 30 days from the date due, services shall be discontinued. Notice of discontinuance of service shall be made on the premises at the time of the disconnection. The city shall have the authority to assign delinquent accounts to a collection agency and may otherwise utilize any legal remedies available to improve collection of delinquent accounts. (b) Service disconnected for nonpayment of bills will be restored only after bills are paid in full, such security deposit or additional security deposit as may be required by the city manager and a reconnection fee as provided in the city's fee schedule is paid for each meter reconnected. (c) Upon discontinuance of service for nonpayment of bills, in the event reconnection is not requested within 30 days, the security deposit will be applied by the city toward settlement of the account. Any balance will be refunded to the consumer; however, if the security deposit is insufficient to cover the bill, the city may proceed to collect the balance in the usual way provided by law for collection of debts. (d) When service is disconnected, the service technician shall record the water meter reading and lock the meter. When service is reconnected, the service technician shall verify that the usage indicated on the meter is consistent with the reading at the time service was discontinued. If there is an increase in water usage, the water service supervisor shall issue a citation for interference with utility property pursuant to section 82-1 of this Code. An additional restoration penalty shall be charged as set forth in appendix C to this Code. Water service will not be restored until this penalty is paid in full. (Ord. No. 10-1995, § 2, 4-10-95; Ord. No. 20-1998, §§ 2, 3, 6-8-98; Ord. No. 2-2009, § 3, 3-9-09; Ord. No. 1-2011, § 3, 1-13-11) Sec. 82-24. - Delinquent account payment schedule. The city clerk shall be authorized to establish a payment schedule for collections of utility delinquent accounts with any meter account which can demonstrate a justifiable need. This payment schedule may in no way exceed four equal payments and the account must be kept current. The payment schedule shall be signed by the city clerk and the delinquent meter account. The city clerk shall further be authorized to waive the two-month deposit for just cause. (Ord. No. 10-1995, § 2, 4-10-95) Secs. 82-25—82-30. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - WATER SERVICE
Sec. 82-31. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Unit means and includes, in determining the minimum charge to be paid for water service, any household, family unit, apartment, industrial plant, factory, office or other place of doing business. A separate unit shall, as may be practicable, be placed upon all separate meters. When water is supplied to more than one party through a single tap, then each individual party shall pay the unit charge for any multi-rate meter service. Any place of business shall be considered a commercial unit for purposes of this section. Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2. Sec. 82-32. - Meters furnished, owned by city. All meters shall be furnished and owned by the city. Any unauthorized use, tampering or alteration of the meter, box and all associated apparatus shall be unlawful and punishable upon conviction as provided in section 1-13. (Code 1969, § 22-10) Sec. 82-33. - Ownership of meter; meter failures. The stopcock, box and meter at or near the curb, or other portion of the city right-of-way, shall be purchased by the property owner, but remains the property of the city. The city shall keep the same in a good state of repair, and replace any of such apparatus, so as to ensure that the meter accurately sets forth the reading for a rate of charge for the property owner. Should the meter be damaged, fail to properly register or otherwise be defective, the customer shall be charged the average daily consumption for the three previous meter readings before the apparatus was damaged. (Code 1969, § 22-11) Sec. 82-34. - Installation of meter on private property. Wherever it becomes necessary to put water meters on the private property of the person using them, and they are put there without objection on the part of the property owner, it is understood that the water meters are to remain the property of the city, and the city by its proper officers shall have authority to remove them at any time. (Code 1969, § 22-12) Sec. 82-35. - Discontinuation of service for rules violation. The supply of water may be withheld from all premises when the ordinances, rules or regulations adopted by the city commission have in any manner been violated, and the supply shall not again be turned on except upon a rectification of the cause of withholding the service, and satisfactory assurance given that no further cause of complaint shall arise. (Code 1969, § 22-13) Sec. 82-36. - Enforcement authority of employees. The employees of the water department shall have the same power and authority as regular police officers of the city for the purpose of enforcing this article. (Code 1969, § 22-14) Sec. 82-37. - Fluoridation of water system. The city commission is hereby authorized to provide equipment and installation facilities in order to fluoridate the potable public water supply of the city. The city may enter into such contracts with the department of natural resources, or other state agencies, to provide for the funding of the cost of any and all fluoridation procedures. (Code 1969, § 22-16) Sec. 82-38. - Water deposit requirement. The city shall be required to collect a deposit from the occupants of any water unit, as defined in this article, prior to furnishing such premises with any water from the city water system. All deposits collected shall be accomplished pursuant to the deposit fee schedule in appendix C of this Code. (Code 1969, § 22-31; Ord. No. 1-2014, 6-2-14) Sec. 82-39. - Water service application; liability for payment. Water service applications shall be made by the owner, lessee or authorized agent for the commencement, reinstatement or transfer of water service. The person making application for water service shall be liable for all applicable charges for sewer, water, garbage and other included services which may be a part of city service fees. The applicant shall be the only person authorized to discontinue water service to the location, and no applicant shall be permitted to apply for service in the name of a third party, unless the applicant is an employee, authorized agent, or relative of said third party. (Ord. No. 20-1998, § 4, 6-8-98) Sec. 82-40. - Water shortages; restrictions. The city commission, city manager or other appropriate designated official of the city may place necessary restrictions upon the types, times and method of use of water within the city system as may be appropriate in times of shortage, scarcity, drought, contamination of the system or other similar emergency. Any person who fails or refuses to comply with such restrictions shall be guilty of a violation of this section and punishable pursuant to the provisions of section 1-13. Further, in addition to this punishment, after notice to the appropriate applicant for water service, service to the unit may be discontinued. Sec. 82-41. - Cross connection; agreement for water supply. The city shall be authorized, by agreement as deemed appropriate by the city commission, to enter into cross connection agreements, contracts, leases, licenses or similar written understandings involving the selling of water service, purchase of water service, joint ventures for water service or any other matters concerning water use or service as may be deemed appropriate by the commission with other public and/or private agencies. Sec. 82-42. - Fire hydrant meter deposit. The city shall be required to collect a deposit for the use of any fire hydrant meters. The fire hydrant meter deposit will be refundable upon the return of the meter. All deposits collected shall be accomplished pursuant to the deposit fee schedule in appendix C of this Code. (Ord. No. 1-2014, 6-2-14) Secs. 82-43—82-60. - Reserved. ARTICLE IV. - SEWER USE DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Sec. 82-61. - Definitions. Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meaning of terms used in this article shall be as follows: Biochemical oxygen demand and BOD mean the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under EPA approval laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of buildings and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building wall. Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal, also called house connection or service connection. Combined sewer means a sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. Customer means every person who is responsible for contracting (expressly or implicitly) with the city in obtaining, having, or using sewer connections with, or sewer tap to, the sewer system of the city and in obtaining, having, or using water and other related services furnished by the city for the purpose of disposing of wastewater and sewage through said system. The terms shall include the occupants of each unit of a multiple-family dwelling unit building as a separate and distinct customer. Easement means an acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others. Floatable oil means oil, fat, or grease in a physical state such that it will separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable oil if it is properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection system.
